reviewText:
[Review written after completing all 5 episodes]

tl;dr - Awesome story, amazing and likeable characters, a surreal emotional rollercoaster, if you get attached to the characters. Would happily pay a lot more for the game.

Coming from a gaming background with years of mostly multiplayer FPS and MMORPG games, Life is Strange still managed to be the game with which I identify myself the most. With well-written characters, an interesting story and a lot of though decisions to make along the way, the game really struck home to me, emotionally.

Life is Strange puts you in the shoes of Max Caulfield, a 18 year-old aspiring photographer who returns to her hometown of Arcadia Bay after 5 years, to study photography at Blackwell Academy. The story initially appears to be the typical high-school drama, with pretty much every stereotype character in it, but you soon realize that there's a lot more to it. As the game progresses, you are presented with a series of choices that may or may not alter the course of history.

Personally, I immediately resonated with Max's personality, from the start of Ep. 1. That made me care even more of what was happening to her throughout the story and urged me to really think through each and every decision that would affect her and her friends. And believe me, you will probably take a very long time to make up your mind in some of the decisions, if you really care about the characters.

The relationship between Max and her bff is heart-warming, to say the least. I really enjoyed seeing their friendship re-bloom after Max's 5-year absence period, in such a meaningful way. After both being through all sorts of shenanigans (and some horrific moments)  together, the game shows you the pure core of their friendship and how much they really care about one another, which I found beautiful...probably because it's the type of relationship most of us would actually strive to have in our lives (and probably only comes true in movies).

The story is complimented by amazing hand-painted scenery. It is clear that the devs put in a lot of effort to get the mood of each scene right. From the lighting to the top-notch voice acting, it all comes into place nicely. And don't get me started in the soundtrack! I'm mostly a hard-rock and metal guy, but I couldn't imagine a more perfect set of songs for this type of game. The most emotionally intense scenes along with the soundtrack can't help but to get me teary-eyed.

One of the minor negative aspects that most people mentions is the lip-sync. Recent patches improved upon this issue, and, although it's not as good as the lip-sync in TLoU, for example, it is still pretty accurate.

With this all being said, the season pass really is a bargain at 20€. I would happily pay 3 times as much for it, given all that I've been through with Max, playing the game. If you're still unsure about buying this, I hope this review will convince you to do so :)
You can also watch a playthrough of the game, but I really advise you to experience the game on your own. I watched a playthrough of ep. 1 before buying it and it felt much more emmersive to make decisions on my own.

[Mention about ep5 ending. Spoilers ahead!]
After reading a bunch of posts in reddit and the steam discussion forum, it appears that there's a lot of people disappointed with the two possible endings. The two main reasons are the many questions remaining unaddressed and the lack of actual consequence of all decisions made in the story ending.
As for the unanswered questions, one may argue that it is a bad and lazy writing choice to let the player draw his/her own conclusions. But, as someone on reddit said, this game taught me that sometimes the journey is the goal, not the destination. And, for me, the journey blew all expectations, as it hit me in more ways I would ever imagine. With 2+ months of waiting for the season finale, a lot of speculation and theories on how would it all end probably led to a bigger disappointment, when you realize some of the aspects we were all so intrigued about weren't addressed in the end.
As for the story endings, the lack of more possible outcomes may feel like the story ends up being more linear" as one would hope for

reviewText:
A episodic atmosperic mystery-crime time-travelling teenage drama kinda game.
You play as Max a teenage girl who suddenly has the ability to rewind time .

Story 8/10
The first episode is very laid back , you get to know Max , her strange dreams, her friends , the campus of Arkadia Bay , her daily life ..and you learn of the missing of a girl named Amber .

Graphics  8/10

It has a very unique style , very warm colors ,

Sound     9/10
Indie style rocky tunes ..add a lot to the campus atmosphere .

Gameplay 8/10

Full controller support
I can't say a lot about the overall gameplay , as it is episodic and this is just the very first Episode  of five . Let's wait and see. I personally like the laid back atmosphere and the time travelling .
I have to say for the older folks ..it kinda feels a little playing Twin Peaks ...if you know what I mean ..a little surreal .
but wonderful somehow ..

If you like story driven adventures and don't mind waiting for all of the seasons to be released , then this is a must buy . It's very fun and entertaining and promising  :)

reviewText: After playing the whole thing from start to finish over these past months, it's safe to say that this game is one of the best story-driven games I have played so far. It is told so well and presented in such a way that you can't help but get lost in this little world. The colorful visuals, amazing soundtrack, good story, and likable characters will get you hooked. The game does a great job setting the theme and atmosphere. With everything going on, you'll see why they say, life is strange. If you truly want to soak in everything, I'd suggest you find some free time alone without interruptions and let the story unfold. It's meant to evoke emotions in the player. Try to explore everything, check every possible conversation option, and find the nice little details within the game. Do however, take breaks between episodes since they can be quite lengthy. While this game is being highly praised, everything isn’t executed perfectly. There are some dull moments here and there, and parts that will slow down the pace of the game, but that isn't enough to keep you away from playing this masterpiece. This game is definitely worth experiencing and I would highly recommend anyone to pick it up.\n\nI'd rate this 9/10.

reviewText:
Life Is Strange is about an 18 year old female called Max. Max is on a  journey to become a photographer, and on her journey she encounters situations, that needs her intervention to change the out comes, you get the option to rewind to change the out comes and try to make things right. The game will guide you and let you know when your at a scene or you can miss some scenarios, which I have done, and I also have missed my photo shoots for some achievements, so replaying to get them will be nessasary as i have found, i do not mind doing this as  the graphics are lovely and a pleasure to see, so remember to explore in the game.

This game is not a game to play around young children as it has very bad language, slag and drugs in it, so i would recommended playing this game when they are a sleep or at school or just away for the time being. But the lovely screenshots would be fine to share with your children no problem there.

Also remember your Playing as a female character, not a male character so dont let that discourage you in anyway, I play games that have male characters and that is never a problem for me.

I was not going to write a short review for this game given its not complete, but for the lovely graphics and the screen shots I had taken, sorry about the spoilers, I felt I must share my thoughts about the game. I have so far enjoyed this game and so look forward to getting the rest of the chapters as they are completed and released, as i purchased the full unfinished game, and i feel that was a better deal, than to purchase them individually.

I feel the team at Square Enix, are doing a lovely job bringing this game as close to life as they have, and i hope they dont give up and so finish the game, to make the story complete. I now must wait for chapter 2 which I look forward to, as now things are starting to heat up, and so its left to be continued, I will wait patiently for chapter 2 :)

So I guess Life Is Strange O-O

reviewText: One of the very few games/movies I've encountered in my life that had a real impact on me. The game structure is simple, the story, in some parts, is not completely unique but the atmosphere and the presentation is mind blowing! After finishing the game, considering my choices made in game before, I've had a solid feeling: that was awesome! With some games you test your reflexes, your logic or sometimes both, but with Life Is Strange you'll have to face decisions that comes from your inner self. This can only be done if the game helps you to connect with the characters, which is perfectly orchestrated here. I would highly recommend to read all the journal entries and try to explore the world as much as possible as this will enhance the experience a lot. Don't rush, this game is not about time... oh wait! It is ;)

reviewText:
Note: I have beat the game and all of the achievements.

This game is amazing. It leaves you with feels for even the worst of the worst characters. It's the story of a girl trying to save the world. And in so doing, fu**ing everything up so that she has to keep trying to save it some more. The music and voice acting in the game were wonderful and the characters are unique and complex.

As a female gamer, I love seeing a strong female lead, or I should perhaps say leads. There are times when I look at Chloe and Max and roll my eyes, but trust me, they do grow.

This game has replayability because you can change your choices. After beating the game, I see several places where I might have done things different had I known the end. That in itself gives credit to the game --- As clever as I think I am, I didn't foresee the end.

I hope they make a Life is Strange 2 or something similar, because this was a true joy to play.

Warning: Stay off the Life is Strange Forums until you beat this (if you do plan on playing it). If you have a question, Google it. The forum is full of spoilers in the thread titles alone. I also saw a slight spoiler by reading a post in the news section that pops up in the game library.

reviewText:
A wonderful game that is experimenting with the episodic structure. Each episode gives you a little bit more information to the mysteries of Arcadia Bay. Who and where is Rachel Amber? What are the events that seem to be unstoppable? What is the significance of time travel? Who is Max going to kiss? All equally important question.

The story can seem straightforward to the player who simply walks from point A to B. But the real tale unfolds in the details. Observant players are rewarded often with dark secrets and hidden meanings. Choices impact the world around you in more than just the present. But also in your past and future.

One can easily replay this game and notice new things and uncover new plots. A new IP for an episodic game is rare these days. I appreciate the boldness in the creativity.

reviewText:
TL;DR: I want to recommend this game so badly, but as the final episode stands, I simply cannot. It seems the writers/developers either ran out of ideas, money, or time, and the Episode 5 finale is noticeably lower quality than Life is Strange's other 4 installments. The ending is a huge slap in the face and goes aginst the whole premise of the game itself. It's like having a full course dinner at a fancy restaurant, only to have the chef come and sh*t on your plate for dessert; the appetizer and entree may have been amazing, but you sure as hell are not going to leave that restaurant happy, much less encourage others to indulge themselves.

MILD (VAGUE) SPOILERS AHEAD

Let me just preface this review by saying that I enjoyed the majority of this game very much. I am a big fan of the Telltale games, and it felt like this was a step above and beyond anything Telltale has done; my choices, no matter how small, seemed like they actually mattered. The butterfly that lets you know your (perhaps seemingly insignificant) choice will affect something down the road, combined with the ability to rewind and choose differently, provides an extremely unique experience. I was often left sitting, weighing the potential pros and cons for each decision, debating whether or not to go back and pick a different option. The artwork in the game is stunning. The musical choices are outstanding and often add more to an already emotionally-charged game. I became emotionally invested in the story of Max, Chloe, and the mysterious forces of Arcadia Bay. I flew through each episode the day it was released, often sacrificing valuable time which could have been better used for sleeping.

That being said, my enjoyment of the game halted abruptly with the release of Episode 5. I don't want to go into too much detail, but essentially, every choice made in the game up until the last 5 minutes or so has absolutely no meaningful impact on the ending whatsoever. I was led to believe that each decision I made was perhaps sending me on a different path that would ultimately lead to a (somewhat) unique ending that would differ with each playthrough. As it stands, you are thrown one final decision which renders all other choices irrelevant, and then are played one of two endings. There are no branching paths. Your choices do not matter. You pick one or the other, and you are done. Which leads to another issue.

The disparity in quality of the two endings is, frankly, staggering. One ending -- the one I am assuming the developers deemed the good ending" -- clocks in at over 9 minutes long. The other
recommended: is around 3 minutes long. The good ending provides a somewhat-fleshed-out conclusion to the story, while the bad ending provides an overwhelmingly cliche, ride-off-into-the-sunset conclusion that provides absolutely no further insight. In my opinion, neither ending should be seen as the correct" one. Both endings should have been fully realized and provided a satisfying conclusion to my journey
hoursPlayed: rather than essentially saying
voteText: "You picked the bad ending
helpfulPercent: so let's just cut this sh*t off abrubtly and give you no closure." Both endings
votesHelpful: however
votesTotal: are plagued by the fact that they leave a myriad of loose ends and do nothing to tie up any of the interesting story lines or provide any more insight into the things which you were investigating the entire f*cking game. The big plot point of "What happened to Rachel Amber?" is
votesFunny: thankfully
commentsCount: answered earlier in the episode
column16: but the answer feels like a complete afterthought and is not satisfying in the least considering how big of a part of the game it was. Other plot lines ("What's the deal with the seemingly villainous Prescotts?"
column17: for example) are just abandoned.\n\nI understand the limitations of a game; a story with an ending for each unique combination of choices simply isn't possible. However
column18: after touting Life is Strange as a game where your choices matter and have a meaningful impact
column19: it seems that the developers have pulled a very obvious bait-and-switch; 2 arbitrary endings where each previous episode means f*ck-all hardly makes it seem like your choices matter at all. I don't know if this was due to time constraints
column20: a lack of funding
column21: or simply a complete lack of effort
column22: but at the end of the day
column23: I feel cheated."

reviewText: One of my favorite story based games. The characters may seem quite generic at first but there is some depth to them and you eventually feel connected to Max and the supporting characters. The time travel aspect adds so much more to the story and by the end you of the first episode you really don't know what to expect. The whole butterfly effect makes you question whether your decisions are the right one and what they will eventually lead to. The soundtrack is also a huge plus to this game. It matches the general feel of the hipster teenage high schooler and plays at the right moments. Defintely recommend this to anyone who enjoys telltale esk games
voteText: 26 of 31 people (84%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Ever wanted to timetravel? Well here is your chance.

The story is about a introverted 18 year old girl called Maxine Caulfield or short Max. Recently she started at a new school and is struggling to fit in. She has a strange power that let's her reverse time for a couple of seconds. This ability allows Max to learn information and redo conversations to get a better result for herself and to change her decisions.

I enjoy these types of games. You make important choices that will influence your faith and that of the living beings around you. Amazing storyline that sucks you in from the first moment. Geniusly athmospheric, amazing soundtrack and beautiful art.

After playing episode 1 I was very impressed by the storyline and immediately purchased episodes 2-5 straight after. This game does, what I miss with Telltale games (in my opinion) and that is, allowing you to redo/undo your choices/conversations/mistakes and see a different outcome. This does not mean that this game is not worth a replay. The choices you make, will have consciences for future episodes. I am looking forward what the future might bring.

reviewText:
Possibly one of the most amazing and well written games I have ever played! Don't listen to IGN this game is up there with the walking dead in my book. If you are looking for an enthralling and very well written emotional game this is the game for you!

This game can only be experienced once, and is one of the best experiences I have ever had! I have just finished episode 5 and it has left me in overwhelming grief but brings to thought the fact that it’s over and I (And many other people) will never get such a eccentric and intensel emotional adventure again.

The building of character profiles creates an almost personal family like bond between you and the main personalities in life is strange, And when this bond is broken throughout the experience, well I’ll let you decide for that!

All this complemented by an outstanding handpicked and tailored indie-Rock soundtrack that only boosts the concoction of emotions that arise from this extraordinary artistic piece. If life is strange was an art piece it would be priceless.

This game is truly unique and will leave you in tears (As with me). Finishing this game has left a hole in my heart, one that can never be fully repaired. I want the memory of this experience to exist forever, anybody who is contemplating buying life is strange, Stop thinking and click that purchase button, it is the best decision you will ever make. Trust me!

reviewText:
Life Is Strange is an episodic point and click adventure where your choices truly matter and will change the storyline! The story centers on Max, a normal High School student who stumbles onto the ability to rewind time, and her life changes drastically.

While the character models are nice, the environment isn’t great. Trees look strange and water is rather ugly, though the engine does a great job overall. The soundtrack is a major strong point, and I feel it suits the game perfectly. Even now, after finishing the first episode, I still go back listen to the tracks on YouTube. It really is that amazing!

The first episode lasts 2-3 hours, and I really feel that the $5 asking price is worth it. It would be best to purchase the entire set after they've all released especially if you'd like to play with less wait time between, but I'm still quite pleased with my purchase.
If you are interested in a story-rich game with a great soundtrack where your decisions really feel like they matter, this is a great choice!

reviewText:
Short version: 77%(Episode breakdown: 97%, 93%, 58%, 65%, 72%)
Life is Strange may have issues with its plot, but it hides most of it well behind great dialogue and touching moments. If you love character drama, this interactive miniseries will surely captivate you and make you care about its characters as they slowly drift towards an inevitable tragedy.

Long version:On the surface, Life is Strange is a standard time travel story, presented in an interactive film format: a shy but nosy teenage girl discovers she can rewind time and uses it to save as many people around her as she can, but always ends up in deeper and deeper trouble.

Like with most similar products, there isn’t any gameplay to comment on, the entire thing is the story and its presentation. And in our case, we have somewhat of a mixed bag.

Let’s get the bad side out of the way first: the plot is weak. More than half of it (including an entire episode) is pure filler with no story advancement. It is also riddled with issues like tired high school archetypes that never get past their one-dimensional role, and a B-grade slasher movie serial killer who even has a clichéd bunker hideout.
On top of that, it feels like as if the story was originally written for television, as all so-called interactive elements have no real influence on anything. No matter what you choose, all but two scenes have the exact same outcomes with some minor dialogue changes here and there.

So what is good? The script is. The dialogues are excellent, and the cast made a flawless job at capturing all the wonderful small moments, the tear-jerking character drama that easily elevates this story above many similar products we saw in recent years. These things may seem small compared to the plotting issues, but in reality they make sure that you will hardly regret going through Life is Strange, not even for a moment.

reviewText:
[N O   S P O I L E R S !]

[UPDATE AFTER FINISHING EP5]

An awesome ride and my personal GOTD (Game of the decade)!

I'm totally biased as I've raised this game up to my personal GOTD. Which means something as I've played like TONS of games in my lifetime. But for sure, none has ever hit me in the feels so often like this pearl. Rarely did a game make me care about the protagonists. And I'm usually a stone-cold ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Seriously.

I admit that, if all feelings put aside, the game has some flaws in many aspects. But <beep!> that!


What's it all about?
Best way to describe it quickly: A Telltale-game without the pressure of timed events that hits you right in the feels. Regularly. Until the end.

And in case you've never played one of the aforementioned:
It's an adventure. You play as a young dudette who discovers that she has a ...nah, see for yourself!

One thing's for sure: I'm totally not the target demographic, so for me it was a bit awkward to play an 18year old girlie geek-hipster, coz i'm
a 40+ year old male geek-nonhipster. But hey, at least I'm as introverted as she is. You gotta
start somewhere :-)
Did it matter? No.
But it helps if you're fine with tons of teenie-clichés and modern day references. Yes, the game drowns in clichés but it still manages to be damn lovely all the time.

Adventures like this totally depend on their characters and the story (as there is no real action" or anything else)
date:

The characters are all believable and authentic (even with all those clichés) and the story always has this subtle "wtf is this about?"-tone swinging along even while you do seemingly meaningless tasks. The epic soundtrack (that made me even get the OST) does a big part in setting up the atmosphere.

So if you're ready to ignore some regurgitated stereotypes and

reviewText:
Why a bad ending doesn't have to ruin a great game?
Players have been worried that Life Is Strange might not be able to stick the landing from the moment it started flapping its chaos-theory butterfly wings. It’s annoyingly common for time travel stories to fall apart in their final moments, whether by breaking their own rules about how time travel works—the rules they spent hours establishing, explaining, and demonstrating—or by using time travel to conveniently undo everything that happened so you wonder why they bothered at all. Science fiction stories love to show off some cool concept and then tell you that cool thing was really bad and no one should ever do it. Cloning dinosaurs? Bad idea. Alien contact? Bad idea. Time travel? Even worse than both of those ideas combined.
Even though I’m angry enough about the ending to write a whole piece about it and then have enough crankiness left over to argue in the comments, when I think back on Life Is Strange the ending is not the only thing I remember. I think about how much fun it was playing at Scooby-Doo while sneaking into the high school at night to investigate, how connected I felt to the characters as they grew from slangy stereotypes into real people, and how heart-wrenching it was tumbling into an alternate timeline where changing the past twisted the present into something unrecognisable.
Even episode five has a lot going for it if you ignore its closing minutes. The creepiness of The Dark Room was worthy of Twin Peaks, which Life Is Strange has referenced almost as much as Deadly Premonition did. The previously dickish spoilt bully Nathan Prescott left a voicemail that was surprisingly touching. Using Max’s powers to save people from the tornado in a possible future was a fun bit of adventure game puzzling. Being trapped in the retro zone of Max’s nightmares and tortured by her subconscious was an effective detour into horror, lightened by a set of surreal text messages received from sources as unlikely as one character’s dog.

Life Is Strange is far from the first video game to have a disappointing ending. Even a classic like System Shock 2 has a final cutscene that’s hilariously out of sync with the rest of the game's tone, and their somewhat underwhelming conclusions don’t stop Knights Of The Old Republic or Half-Life 2 from earning their place on lists of the best games ever. The original ending of Fallout 3 was so rough that an entire DLC add-on was created to rewrite it, four years before Mass Effect 3 did something similar, but we’re still drooling at the thought of Fallout 4. We’ve forgiven those games because we enjoyed the hours leading up to those endings so much we focus on that instead. We can choose which memories are the ones we care about preserving and, like with photographs, build our albums out of the moments that mattered to us. Life Is Strange is just another game for the “Flawed Masterpieces” section of the album.

reviewText:
Max Caulfield is a student at Blackwell Academy, located in Arcadia Bay. There she learns a lot about her photography hobby. She thought she had a normal life, until some mysterious situations start to appear and YOU, my dear player, will solve them.
Max has her own way of life. She's called a hipster by some girls which are always making fun of her. It's amazing the fact that you can rewind to change your decision, but it's not that easy: sometimes Max'll persuade you, like I shouldn't have done that" or "Why didn't I do that?"

-The graphics aren't the best

reviewText:
There are so many things I really want to say about this game, but every time I start, I get side tracked.

This game is so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ good that I can't really put this recomendation into cohesive sentences.

This game isn't groundbreaking.  It doesn't add much to the adventure game genre.  It doesn't have a very original story, or even original characters.  But the narrative is such a mind♥♥♥♥ and the characters so well written that you can't help but sit and wonder about everything you did in the story.  Everything is set up perfectly for the player to understand what happened, but open ended enough for the player to create their own interpretations of what actually happened.

Even if you don't appreciate the setting or the characters, it's still worth it to play just to marvel at the narrative the developers created.  My advice? Don't take everything at face value, and try to imagine yourself, the player, as a character in this game.

reviewText:
I just beat the first episode and wow, I throughly enjoyed that game from top to bottom. The characters feel like real kids going through the horrible transition period we go through where we aren't teens anymore but we aren't yet adults. The music is great, really nails the indie feel this game is going for, some of the tracks are good enough I am seeking them out to listen to outside of gaming. The gameplay is fairly inline with what Telltale has been up to, except there are no quick time events, and dialogue choices aren't on a timer. If you make a choice that you aren't satisified with, rewind time and make a better choice for yourself. I could go on and on about this game, but I don't want to spoil anything.

I will just point out a quick gripe, the mouth movement isn't syncing with the dialogue, but that seems patchable and wasn't a big issue for me but mileage will vary from player to player.

If future episodes are as good as this one was, we are all in for a great new episodic game that would fit comfortably with the likes of The Walking Dead or Wolf Among Us, as well as a great game across all genres.

reviewText:
Life is strange is such an amazing game for such an amazing price. I dont know where to begin with the positives.

Its a mix of Heavy Rain (Only without the mellodrama of David Cage), A TellTale Style Adventure game, Alan Wake esque setting and story telling in a High school slice of life drama with the feel of an Indie Film with incredible music, acting and writing.

You Play as Max (an 18 year old girl who moved back to her home town of Arcadea Bay to study Photography. Waking up from a nightmare in class Max whitnesses another student being shot and she realises she can reverse time to prevent it.

Thats all I can really say without going into spoilers.

Every character here is amazing, From your main cast to your typical Jocks, Teachers, Fellow students its just amazing.

Game is packed with funny geek humour, softer moments, action and you might even get the feels here and there. You might even learn a bit about Photography here :) I feel like I did.

You really feel like these characters know each other for years, they have there own live and hobbies and circles of friends and nothing is hammered or forced unnaturaly in. (Atleast I felt like that from Just the 1st Episode)

I am totally hooked and cannot wait for more episodes to come out.

I am absolutly recommending this game to anyone who loves story ritch adventure games.

reviewText:
I have to give this game a negative review. Do I regret playing it? No. Would I recommend it to you? Yes. Let me explain...

This spoke to my soul on so many levels. I had a best friend who was I felt was altogether more interesting than me, she was always getting herself (and me) into trouble whilst I just wanted to kunckle down and get an education. I think even if you don't have this perspective, you will find a part of yourself in Max and you will see someone you know or used to know in Chloe - the writers were very smart about the way they approached these two characters, they are absolutely intoxicating. The supporting characters are also extremely well written, add to this a completely mind bending story-line, the ability to undo time (let's face it, everyone at some point in their lives wishes they could rewind something and try again) and a skin-tingling soundtrack and you have one of the best story-based games I've ever played.

So why am I giving it the thumbs down?

During your journey in this game you will make some absolutely nail-biting decisons. Your cursor will be hanging for minutes between two crucial decisions which you know will impact the story in some massive way. And impact the story it does. However, if you're looking for a game with a huge range of multiple endings based on those chain of decisions you've made, well - you're going to be disappointed. In the end, none of it matters and it all comes down to one ultimate decision that decides one of two endings for you. Now, I know its all about the journey, blah blah blah (I've heard it all before with Mass Effect 3) and you can look back and say, well
date: clearly the message is - don't mess with time or time will mess with you" but no
recommended: I'm sorry. This game could have been so much more with multiple endings."

The first time i played it, there were several moments that touched my emotions in a way that no game ever did before. Or any movie or book. I was captivated by the characters and story - I could not and did not want to stop playing the game after every episode - I wanted to know what will come next.

I was suprised positivly, how a game could do that. This game had a huge inpact in my life. It´s so incredible!

Moments that touched me most (SPOILER!):

- The final of the game

- Saveing Kate from her terrible fate (second playthrough)
- Finding out who Mr. Jefferson really is...
- Ending of Episode 3
- Paraplegic Chloe asking me to end her life...
... and so much more....


For everyone who loves really great storys, characters you can feel close to and a plot-twist filled storyline - this is your game!

reviewText:
Life is Strange is a adventure games with choices that has a consequences, there is no right or wrong, just choices. Yep, the choosing mechanic is very similiar with Telltale Walking Dead series, but don't get it wrong, its similiarity is like Halo has a gun that can reload, just like Call of Duty. Soo, Life is Strange is not a Walking Dead clone.

It tells the story of Max, a geeky girl that have the abilities to rewind time, how did she get that abilities ?? its still a mystery. There's some mystery here and there like why is he like that, or why did she knows that, and why did she get that strange vision at the beginning of the game ?? Of course like all super hero story, when the main character get that super hero power, they tend to use it on everything even the little things. The episode 1 stop with the main plot unfolding, very cliffhanger, but its an episodic game and i expect no less.

The characters in this game is really good, all of them is really lifelike, their behaviour and everything about them is very lifelike, and we even got some anti mainstream main character, that is not really confident with herself, very geeky, not perfect, and like to talk to herself a lot. She even kinda talk to herself about her being nosey when a player go to places they are not suppose to go, like when she go to her friend parents bedroom for no reason whatsoever, except because the player want to go everywhere.

The gameplay mechanic is like i said before, bear the similiarity with Telltale Walking Dead series, like you pick a conversation choices and the game will tell you that there will be a consequences with that choices... But instead of that button smashing dumb quick button event, we got a really cool puzzle that could be solve using the rewind time mechanic, like you don't really like what you said to someone ? Just rewind the time ! Or you really need to hide and crap !! you messed up your hiding spot, just rewind the time and avoid that ! that kind of stuff. Its really soothing because you can take all day to solve the puzzle because if you mess up, just rewind the time and you good to go.

The visual and audio in this game is design to be soothing and beautiful. The soundtrack is absolutely beautiful, i could listen to all of that all day long just to calm myself. the visual is well. Not AAA good, there's some low poly texture here and there, but its usable. Its very pretty in some area and again the visual is design to give the player that soothing atmosfer and combine that with the audio make this game really calming.

In the end, this is a really good game and definitely worth your time and money. I don't know what to say, i'm amazed that the developer really know how to give the player a good atmosfer and they didn't afraid to make the main character not the usual confident heroine type. Its really nice just to see her diary and listen to her rambling about stuff. Buy it now or wait for all the episodes to come out. If you like a good story telling, definitely don't miss this one.

Updated for episodes 2: Episode 2 is still good, in my opinion. This episode explore a bit more about all the characters in the game, and how they react to each other. There isn't a character that just mean, or just nice. All the characters have some depth in them. Each of them has their own problem and reason of why they did what they did. again, making choosing the right decision a lot harder. Its still didn't explain a lot of things. But, thats why there's episodes 3-5 right ? Still recommended.

Updated for episodes 3: Episode 3 just... awesome. It really depend the story that everything is connected in this big mystery that has yet been revealed. It also really know how to make time traveller nerds (Like me) drooling after finishing the episode. My big complain yet understandable complain is that there's one big plot in game that could change the story as a whole, It could be fun if you can choose a different path and not save a particular someone from dying but the game didn't give me that option. But i know why they didn't give me that option because if i can choose that plot, the episode 4 and 5 plot will be different entirely, and they couldn't make a 2 completely different path for the last 2 episodes.

reviewText:
Do you remember “Remember me” - a debut company project? That action game was criticized a lot for gameplay and combat, unique realization of human mind manipulation idea and gorgeous futuristic universe were totally ignored.

Main conception of “Life is strange” is similar - playing with person mind to build chain of future events in way that we need(in simplified mode comparing to “Remember me”). Developers drastically switched genre, now it’s interactive_high_school_drama_story game with mix of detective. The main problem for such sort of games is gameplay and this one not an exception. Fortunately plot is not bad and in some way compensate poor gameplay but story final - сomplete disappointment.

Don't misunderstand. “Life is strange” is OK. Development team - gifted and wise people. They don’t thrown in garbage the gorgeous idea just apply it a different view. To please mainstream consumers and overall trends in game industry. Critics and gamers now happy, game got lot of awards, well, definately...

Life is strange.

reviewText:
Reviews for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing
Overall Rating: 9/10
Gameplay Rating: 8/10
Accessibility Rating: 9/10

NotesOverall rating is a combination of the gameplay (mechanics and story) and accessibility (how the game includes deaf/hoh gamers).  If you disagree with my take on the game or if something is factually incorrect, please leave a comment below!

Ratings for this game at this time are through chapter 4 only.  Review will be updated when each new chapter comes out.  (28 July 2015)

Game OverviewIn Life is Strange (LIS), you are Max, an 18-year-old senior at Blackwell Academy, a special seniors-only high school where talented students go to hone their skills in a creative outlet.

Gameplay Mechanics
The mechanics of LIS are not difficult.  The camera and movement controls are easy and generally do not interfere with gameplay.  It is occasionally difficult to properly center the mouse on an object, but this is rare.

In general, it is mostly a WASD/point-and-click game with time to make choices and a low stress level.

Storyline
In LIS, the game revolve around you making decisions, some easy and some not.  These decisions have immediate and long-term effects that you discover as the game goes on.  These types of games can be fun in that you can play out your own personality or try out something much different from what you would do - sort of testing the water for what it's like to be someone different.

LIS plays out through a series of causal relationships - things happen that shape the rest of the game - and through Max's own thoughts and feelings about the events, captured in her inner monologue and in her journal, which is updated each time you go to a new 'section' of the game (i.e. crossing to a new area that wipes your rewind ability).  Max's journal entries reflect the choices you make.  In her journal, Max uses English puns more often than any other game I have played.  If you're like me and you don't get puns very often, be prepared. :)

Each of the chapters take around three hours for a moderately in depth gameplay style.  I really enjoy the game, even if this is not my favorite game type.  It is VERY creative, often very beautiful, and it pulls you in to the characters through development and storyline progression.  At times, both the story and character feel a little two-dimensional, but it is handled well by key moments where they begin to shape up again into more believable people.

Each chapter has improved in both the choices you have to make and the storyline.  LIS feels as though it is building to something epic.

Gameplay Rating
Life is Strange is rated 8/10 for gameplay.  The story is fantastic and the effects of the decisions provide a high replay value.

Accessibility Overview
Game Options
Options are available before starting a new game for audio, video, or control changes as required.

Deaf/HOH
This game is fully playable for Deaf/HOH gamers!

Pros:
+ Subtitles are on by default
+ Subtitles cover all speech in game.

Cons:
- No variation in subtitles for speakers (names, color scheme)
- No variation in subtitles for Max's speech vs thoughts

Notes:
Subtitles are stylized rather than typeset, but very easy to read white on black.

Mobility
This game is fully playable for gamers with mobility issues!

Pros:
+ All keys can be rebound
+ Keys have primary and alternate binds for left/right dominant hands

Cons:
None!

Notes:
None!

Accessibility Rating
Life is Strange is rated 9/10 for accessibility.  The only improvements are in subtitle indicators for speaker and captions for background noises.  The game is highly playable for all gamers.

---
Visit Games Reviews for the Deaf/HoHhttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/gamereviewsforthedeaf

reviewText:
There are only 5 or so games, films, or TV shows that have moved me as much as this game, Life Is Strange has. It is a hard feeling to deal with. The characters feel very real. You come to know many of them, and love them almost like real friends. Then the game is over, and those characters are gone. This causes a hurt inside you. Very much like losing dear friends, because there is no continuation for these characters.

This game is VERY emotional and deals with some very dark, and unfortunately very real things in our world. If you feel for other people, and nature, and the things only humans can cause, whether they are good or bad, this game might make you feel very sad at times, because it puts these things right in your face.

I cried so many times going through this game. I'm a pretty emotional person, but I think these feelings are totally intentional, and so I think the people who made this game did a damn good job. I wish to explore that world and those characters forever, because they seem that real. But, you can't. Much like the themes in this game about how little control we all have over time and events we can't foresee, this game ends and I have to find a way to move on.

The world in this game is pretty to look at. The graphics aren't amazing, but they are done in an artistic way that reminds me of watercolors or something. The gameplay is very similar to Telltale Games style, in that it is mostly walking around areas interacting with a limited number of objects, and talking to other characters. The real point of the game is the storytelling, and they do SUCH a good job in this one, as I've been over and over here.

I would recommend that if you do play it, take it slow, take long breaks if you need them. I took almost a year break and then several week breaks in between some parts, and it is still messing with me that I can't see anything more from these characters. Only replay the game again. Which, much like replaying a moment in the game with the unique rewinding power, only allows me to see that world again, and not live in it forever.

This review isn't much of a review, I know. But I don't want to reveal much and I just wanted to put my thoughts on this game out there somehow, even just to help me get through it. Thanks for reading if you do, though, and I hope you can enjoy this game that it seems to me a lot of work and love went into. :)

reviewText: An episodic point and click adventure game where the protagonist Maxine Caulfield has a special ability to rewind time. She develops more abilities and uses her abilities to save her best friend and help solve a mystery surrounding Arcadia Bay as the story progresses. For the first four episodes, the choices she make will affect the storyline. Each episode will take approximately 2-5 hours to finish. As Max progresses through the story, she can form friendships with many characters, have romantic relations with two characters and have a few enemies in the game. The game had great soundtracks and the character models and animations are also well-done with a lot of attention to detail. All achievements in the form of taking optional photos in-game are also easy to find and obtain. The only complaint I have for this game is that the final episode was a disappointment as there were only two bad endings and it had many unexplored plot twists and unanswered questions.\n\nOverall, highly recommended as the best game for 2015.

reviewText:
Warning: This whole review will sound pretentious but here goes.

I hate to throw around superlatives. They become meaningless if you do so but to me, this game is a real pice of art. A lot of different elements come together to make something that's very special.

I don't want to get bogged down in details but Life is Strange is basically a story based game very much in the vein of Telltale games like The Walking Dead or The Wolf Among Us. What differs Life is Strange from those games in that the setting is far more down to earth and mundane, which actually in my mind, counts as a huge strength. Every single one of us has experienced being a young person and dealing with problems, both big and small, in life. I consider this a strength as the story is so much more relatable and immersive. The player character, Max Caulfield, is likeable and easy to relate with. She finds herself in instantly recognisable situations and feels familiar emotions. On the surface, it would seem the opposite. Yet, in keeping within the realms of reality (apart from the time travelling mechanic of course) the characters and plot lines are so much easier to idenity with. To compare with The Walking Dead, the choices there concern such abstract situations in comparison. The vast majority of people never have to act in life or death situations, to kill people or make choices in harsh moral situations. Life is Strange's story is of such familiarity, that the themes are far more intriguing. We've all had to deal with difficult things in regards to growing up. What we want to do in life, who our friends are, the trials and tribulations of education, wishing we could make different decisions and interacting with people. This is the best strength of the game in my opinion.

The other mechanic that sets it apart from the rest is the time travelling mechanic. It allows for some really amazing plot scenarios and works very well in the concept of your choices mattering. Never mind having to make the initial choice, seeing the consequences and being able to go back in time adds a whole new layer to the system. Again, this initially seems like a bad idea but it works very well in practice. As the story progresses, it has a bigger and bigger impact. No spoilers though, experience it for yourself.

I'd also like to heap particular accolades on the audio/visual department. The graphics and art style do an excellent job of conveying a dream-like, surreal state. The environment looks superb, especially the vivid sunsets and rays of light. The sound is well done, with the voice actors being of high quality. The music is well-chosen and fitting to the atmosphere of the game. The only complaint I have in this department is that the DOF and blur effects are sometimes a bit overdone but that may be my personal preference.

Overall, I can't reccommend this game enough. One of the best story based games I've played, with a huge emotional punch to it. I can't wait for the finale of the story.

reviewText:
There's little to say, that hasn't already been said about Life is Strange.

It is, for me, one of the best games I've played - not just this year, but in my lifetime of gaming. The visuals, the characters, the soundtrack, the choices - everything ties together beautifully, and painfully. I've a lot of love for this game, that it's unreal.

Without repeating what many others have said - if you like adventure games, that are story rich, puzzle light, with characters who will stay with you long after you've completed it, with great voice acting and a great soundtrack - both ambient and where songs are used, then this is for you. The mechanics are quite unique and give a true thrill of what you are doing, and the ability to really make choices - if you don't like a choice, you can go back. Your choices aren't rushed, which in turn makes them more painful at times, but all the more worthy.

It's a rollercoaster of a ride, there are some weak spots, but even with those - the beauty of the game, just being in the moments it provides makes up for slower progression, or clunky puzzles. I loved just being in this game, soaking up the atmosphere, which is something I've found in very few games.

While I picked this up on sale - it is worth the full price, without any doubt. If you like the narrative focussed Tell Tale games of late (Walking Dead, etc) then, definitely buy this.

reviewText:
Just to begin with, this game hit me with chills right before the credits rolled for episode one.  I want to say this is comparable to a Telltale game but, honestly, the writing and narrative style can't be compared.  However, if you enjoy episodic video games you'll probably enjoy Life is Strange.  I've heard it has a similar feel to Gone Home, but I can't comment on that myself.

So what can you expect with Life Is Strange?  After the first episode I can say that I hope you can expect meaningful choices that matter.  I would be supremely dissapointed in this title if your choices didn't really affect the overall narrative.  A core aspect of this game is the rewind system and I'm hoping that it was put there for reasons other than an oopsie" button.  It does feel like the rewind system has more purpose than to drive the narrative but we can only wait and see.

You may notice this game looks hipster as ♥♥♥♥.  You probably aren't wrong and the pop-culture references do get a little old but they fit the characters and the story.  They don't feel tacked in at all.  Hey

reviewText:
This review is based on episodes 1 through 5. Life is Strange is an absolutely fantastic experience that I would readily recommend to those who already enjoy Telltale-style decision games, as well as newcomers to the genre. When compared against similar Telltale offerings, I would say that the impact/emotional weight of the choices in Life is Strange is a clear cut above the competition, though I did have some minor gripes regarding episode 5's culmination. The sheer brilliance of the narrative shines through with the game's rewind mechanic - while the idea may seem like cheating at first, it quickly becomes apparent that there is never a clearly 'correct' choice to make and you may find yourself rewinding upwards of three times, still uncertain of how to proceed. Max Caulfield is a strong, likable, and well-defined heroine, and the player will doubtless feel a connection with her and her situation as the game progresses.

The game has a distinct art style that is very appealing, from character designs down to the font used for interactions. The soundtrack is nothing short of brilliant - both the original score and assortment of licensed indie tracks that comprise it suit the world of Life is Strange wonderfully. Although the voice acting can be shaky for some minor characters, and the dialogue sometimes seems forced, Max and Chloe's voice actresses deliver some of the most convincing and emotional performances I have ever heard in gaming. Ashly Burch did an impeccable job as Chloe, and her performance in later episodes is simply astounding. The narrative itself is impressive, ranging from everyday problems that teenagers experience to some very dark and mature themes, all handled remarkably tastefully and in an uncontrived manner.

A consistent strength of Life is Strange's gameplay is the freedom to walk around and interact with others at your will--often allowing you to learn about various characters' inner struggles and also attempt to befriend them--as well as optionally examine objects throughout the environment. Doing so allows the player to get some insight into Max's inner thoughts, and also provides you with information/the ability to perform minor actions that may prove pivotal later in the story. Commendably, many characters with whom you interact often left me confused as to whether I can trust them, or whether they are good people. Having that sense of doubt when choosing a course of action that could implicate someone adds weight to the decisions you are making. In various places throughout the game, Max may sit down, providing time for introspection. These are some of the most beautiful moments in the game - the acoustic guitar-laden music and camera angles all accentuate these brief scenes where Max contemplates the world before her.

The consequences of multiple decisions are made clear quite early in the game, and new gameplay considerations are introduced that will take the player by surprise. The climactic sequences of most episodes resonated with me greatly, sometimes making me feel extremely vulnerable or agonized, and always left me in dire anticipation of the next episode. Although the consequences in the game are generally quite meaningful early on, episode 5 falls a bit short of expectations - though it is by no means a weak ending. Still very impactful, the final episode has what I believe to be some of the best sequences and dialogue in the entire game. Ultimately, the series proved to be an emotional experience that captures the essence of teenage struggles remarkably well. While some of the puzzle solving in Life is Strange leaves something to be desired (certain segments are tedious instead of creative), the game's gorgeous art, strong character interactions, beautiful indie soundtrack, and overall atmosphere excel, ensnaring the player deep into its unique world. I look forward to seeing what Dontnod has in store for us in the future.

reviewText:
Yeah I know, I've only played this game for less than an hour, but I just can't wait to write a review and recommend this awesome game to all my friends.

First thing first, I LOVE the graphic of this game, for which I decided to buy it immedately at my first glance. This game also has great music which perfectly match the character's mood.

Besides, I am a huge fan of galgames, and I love games in which you can make choices that affect the story. This is exactly what this game does: you got many characters and objects to interact with, and your choice will really affect the story.

And, more personally, the main character Max is kind of a nerdy and introverted girl just like me, who prefer to stay alone but still care much about what others think of me. So when I play this game as Max, I really get involved in it, and the feelings and moods of Max can really touch me.

Overall, it's a materpiece, 10/10. Just buy it now, and you won't regret.

reviewText:
A bit of a surprise hit.

Awesome visual novel/adventure game hybrid with great production values: excellent minimalistic and intuitive UI and controls, interesting art style with a slightly water colorish touch, mostly solid voiceovers and a soundtrack that fits the action rather well.

The ultimate WHAT IF? gameplay experience - if you catch yourself reloading games to try out different choices this title has your name on it...

reviewText:
This game is like a piece of candy. Not any candy, mind you. It's the candy you eat when you crave for a very certain sweet. It's one of those games you'd want to experience every second of.  Enjoy every bit of it. Do I recommend it? Ofcourse I do. For the following reasons.
☺ It's affordable. Price is quite reasonable.
☺ The soundtrack is amazing. Probably one of the best in a while.
☺ The story is unique and easy to follow.
☺ The thing I loved the most about this game was the characters. Once in a while you really want to connect with your protagonist in a special way. You know, laughing and enjoying the moment as she does, crying your eyes out when everything just goes to hell. The determination she's feeling. Just feeling this rollercoaster of emotions.
☺ You get to decide your faith! Ofcourse, it's not all on you but when you have the opportunity to choose - naturally the entertainment value of the game raises. At least in my eyes.
☺ Very stylized. It might not have the best graphics but the world it potrays has been done extremely well.

reviewText:
So here is in all sense MY OPINION on this game.
In categories


Story----------------------------------------------
+ Has a catchy begging, attracting the player.
+ Nice plot twists along the way.
+ Allows the player to figure the puzzle out for themselfs by having positive and negative affects.
+ The story is actually kinda emotional, allowing the player to attach to the characthers.
- Some of the polt twists don't make sense
- The plot of this game has been done over and over and over, some adverage Joe gets a power they have to learn how to control over time through friends and family, so I can already guess what is going to go down in the next installments.
- Some plot holes.

Gameplay (Controls)-----------------------------------------
+ Smooth controls (although I have heard that for mac users, bugs have occured)
+ Simple point and click adventure.
+ Doesn't spam quick time events, but uses them once in awhile.
- Some of the controls catch you off gaurd.
- Bugs at certain moments.

Price-------------------------------
+ Its cheap when you first buy it.
- You have to pay for the other installments.

Graphics-----------------------
+ Very beautiful atmopshere and surrondings, this is such a feel good game when the game zooms out onto the surrondings.
+ Easy to run (Desktop wise)
+ Easy to adjust graphics
-  Glitchy bugs at times with the options.
---------------------------------------------------
So yea, thats basicly all I can really say for this game with out spoiling it.
If my grammar is incorrect or off, please tell me so.
Also this is my first review in this format so tell me if you enjoyed :D

My Personal Rating: 7 Snob ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s/ 10

reviewText:
Muy buen juego, la verdad me encantó. Hacia bastante tiempo que estaba buscando este tipo de juegos y que fueran mas al estilo del Heavy Rain.
El problema del primer episodio es que fue DEMASIADO CORTO. Y practicamente te contaban todo lo que pasaba en el capitulo en los gameplay que fueron pasando desde que anunciaron el juego. Habria estado bueno que hubieran buscado algo más con lo que dejar al usuario más pegado. Si esto persiste en el segundo capitulo, mas vale comprarlo más tarde entero. AUNQUE ESPERO QUE NO, porque seria una historia corta que no podrías disfrutar de nada.
Los juegos cortos, aunque sean episodicos, son siempre un fracaso. ¿Por qué? Porque mantienen al usuario pegado por poco tiempo, y entre esperar a los otros capitulos que salgan, generalmente se rompe el estado de flow.

Espero de corazon que en el segundo capitulo te dejen tan enganchado que sea tan dificil de olvidar o pasar por alto, sino seria una gran lastima que un titulo tan prometedor quede en la nada.

reviewText:
There is little I can say to truly describe how I felt while playing this game.
It was a rollercoaster of emotions; a story that while amazingly interesting, still managed to feature actual consequence of choice, and yet also managed to be introspective and beautiful.

It probably doesnt help that I just finished the 5th episode though so I'm a little emotional...and I'm a sucker for ambient alternative music, so they nailed the atmosphere and aesthetic setting.

...excuse me while I go cry to the soundtrack for the next two hours.
Play this game.


P.S. though I didnt really appreciate the way the last episode made it boil down to less choices than anticpated. stillagoodgamethough.

reviewText: Episode 1 :- I wasn't sure what I was quite expecting when I came into the townof Arcadia. Withing the first few monutes, however, I knew that I am going to enjoy these episodes. The Time rewinding mechnic is a lot of fun and makes your choices that more complicated rather than easier. The characters introduced in episode 1 are very much alive and each have thier own lives, opinions and storied for you to look into and comment on or ignore. The soundtrack adds so much to the game that makes me more connected to both the world and Max and I cannot help but become attached to Max having access to her thoughts and personality. She deals with the struggles of college life which are prominent in both our own lives and movies and it is interting to deal with them with this time rewinding mechinic. I can only hope that the pure fantastic atmosphere and storys continues through the episodes and I cannot wait to see if my choices have doomed or saved realtionships in the future. Time may have felt like it was on my side, but only time can tell me whether  I have made some terrible choices.\n\nEpisode 2 :- After the cliffhanger of 1, I was wondering how the world would have changed. Well, more like how much Max's world would have changed. We see more of Chloe and have a seemingly pointless fetch quest in the middle of the episode (involving beer bottles) but while fetching these bojects you stumble upon some more story about Chloes life and her realtionship with Rachel and also hearing Max's thoughts on leaving Chloe behind. However, Chloe really takes a back seat for what is really an episode that deals with another character that was introduced in Episode 1. The episode is much harder hitting and your choices from episode 1 will come and hit you in the gut here if you have made some wrong ones, and when the episode closes you will either feel like a Hero or feel helpless. Rewinding time cannot help you all the time, and Max's ability can only go back so far. Either way, if episodes continue like this, we are going to be in for one hella ride.

reviewText:
This review is for the entire season of Life Is Strange.

Episode 1:
Life is Strange is an episodic adventure game made by Dontnod studios from the same people that made Remember Me. In Life is Strange we play as Max. Max is a teenager at blackwater acedamy where she is studying photography but one day she witnesses a murder and finds out she can rewind time to a certain point to change the consequences. So how is Life Is Strange episode 1 ? This game is really good and Telltale has found its worthy rival. The game looks incredibly good and the soundtrack is very good as well. The game would be a mix of Gone Home and The walking dead and the story is very intriguing. The game still has 4 episodes to go and i cant wait to see how this thing wraps up. There are a few problems i find with this game. I dont like that you can rewind time to choose a diffrent option for a major choice. It kinda makes me feel that the choices i made were meaningless and if i didnt like em i could just rewind and choose a diffrent option. Overall Life Is Strange is a fantastic adventure and without a  doubt if you like adventure games where youre choices matter get this game straight away. I give Life Is Strange Episode 1 a 8/10

Episode 2:
This is where the story picks up. We understand how to control our powers and we try to use them for good but we start to find weird stuff happening around us. The first episode was a slow start just to establish the characters episode 2 is where the story picks up and gives us more tougher choices to make. I don't want to spoil what's gonna happen so i'll just say if you haven't bought this game, go do it now cause episode 2 is amazing. I give Episode 2 a 9/10

Episode 3:
Wow. I am really impressed how every episode gets better. This episode is about more puzzle solving and I can't say I don't like it. Simply put it episode 3 is the best episode so far. The story in this episode is really well written. The story picks up as soon as episode 2 ends and we are tasked to find out who is behind the disappearance of Rachael. There is something wrong with this episode which I don't like. I found a lot of bugs like Max not picking up certain items and the rewind ability not stopping when i try to stop it. Overall if you haven't checked out Life Is Strange you need to do that straight away. I give Episode 3 a 9.5/10

Episode 4:
I'm literally speechless. Episode 4 is a nail bitter from start to finish. The wait was worth it and without a doubt Episode 4 is by far the best episode (notice a pattern yet ?). Ep 4 begins straight away after episode 3. Max is tasked to put every clue together to find out what happened to Rachael and Kate. I really can't go into detail about this cause I will ruin the entire plot. The story this time doesn't take any breaks. Everything wrong that could happen does happen and also this episode has a very shocking ending. The previous episode had a lot of puzzle solving but this one has even more. You have to think a lot and put together a lot of clues like a detective. This episode by far is fantastic and without a doubt I can't wait to see how the entire story wraps up. I will say episode 4 is perfect every possible. This game is a must own. I give Episode 4 Dark Room a 9.5/10

Episode 5:

After finishing the final episode of Life Is Strange I felt a bitter sweet feeling. I knew I did what needed to be done, but it also felt like what I did was wrong. When the ending scene started playing, I noticed how my heart started sinking and I knew that this one experience I will never forget.

Episode 5 is a no stop shop. All you did in the previous episodes comes back to haunt you in every way possible. It makes you feel that the choices you made were wrong and everything that went wrong was your fault.

The ending at one glance is a very disappointing finisher, because it makes you feel that everything you did in the previous episodes didn't matter in the end, but trust me this isn't the case.

Life Is Strange is one experience I can't recommend enough. This game is a must play for everyone. The heartbreaking story is absolutely amazing. This game should be considered for a GOTY award.

This journey was incredible and I loved every waking moment. Without a doubt one of the best games I have played to date.
Episode 5 gets a 9.5/10

Final Rating for Season 1:

9.5/10 - A must own

Without a doubt a game for the ages and I can't wait to see what Dontnod come up with next.

For more reviews follow Snort's Review curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
Note: I deleted my initial review and have rewritten it.

Life is Strange, developed by Dontnod Entertainment that contains five episodes, is a story-driven game dependant on choices of the player. This game is set in Arcardia Bay. You, the player, play as Maxine Caulfield, who is an aspiring photographer that has just been accepted into Blackwell Academy. This game in a nutshell, is just absolutely incredible. The many elements of artwork to the dialogue to the environment makes this a game that must be played. I will discuss the story, the artwork, the dialogue, sound and negatives of the game in a condensed review.

The story of Life is Strange is phenomenal primarily due to the choices that the player has to make. These choices you decide twist the story completely that it makes things emotional within such a short playtime of the overall game. There are several stories in the game that there are several main stories, not just one, and there are an abundance of side missions that affect the main story. There are many games where side quests do not matter in relation to the main story. However, in this game you will know that the majority of your decisions will mean something in the end. For choices that do not overly matter, your choice is compared to all other players that have made decisions through percentages. This is quite comparable to The Walking Dead series by Telltale with the choices and what players globally chose. This game most importantly that I do commend the developers for is how important your choices matter for the end game. Here are minor spoilers but all your choices throughout the episodes culminate into various cutscenes in episode five that lead up to the final scene, therefore, I do love this aspect because it questions the players choices from decisions throughout all episodes. Also, little things like Maxines journals and texts on her phone added some context to the various stories occuring in the game, which I liked because it was such a little thing that mattered. Overall, the story is simple, relatable, and very effective. It captures the modern time of students going to College, well in some aspects.

The artwork in this game is excellent. The artwork again is best compared to The Walking Dead series with sketch-based drawings. The artwork is just beautiful. All characters are distinct in their design and all are accompanied by various traits. This adds into the story of choices because all characters have different personalities, which add variety of dialogue and art. The artwork captures the emotions in characters depending on events that have happened in the game. For example, the diverse personalities of characters made a very emotional scene intensify as you had the bullies that did not overly care but showed some ounce of compassion while others were extremely sad. In other words, the artwork of characters captured their personalities with the various events in the game.

The environment, scenery, and atmosphere are beautiful. Yes, I am overly commending this game but this game deserves all the praise it recieves. The environment is beautiful. All of the artwork complements the areas that the game progresses through. Visuals are expressed elegantly like the Tornado and Arcardia Bay, allowing the player to further invest themselves into the city and events happening.

The soundtrack captures the essence of the game as it progresses. Small things like Maxine walking down the hall at school playing music from her phone to bigger things like the music when a major event occurs showcases the variety of severity in all decisions and events in the game. Alternatively, the soundtrack complements the environment and atmosphere.

The voice acting is very strong. The voice acting fits the personalities of the characters and adds to the story. My only gripe is the lack of variety in voice tones with some characters. When there is a very emotional scene occuring, there would be minimal transition in a character's voice tone. That is only small but the voice acting for the most part was very good.

There were very minor issues with the game. I experienced some rare unstable framerates with the FPS dropping from around 60-35, which would make the cutscene slightly unstable, but for the most part this was very minor.

A side comment I will make. I posted a negative comment in the first review. I stated that in episode one I didn't like the basic nature of the game due to a lack in building in relationships. For example, I stated that my decisions on Kate did not affect her at all, such as defending her in a situation did not matter by the end of episode one. However, I will clarify that whatever decision I make throughout the game will pop up in some way or form, so decisions do matter - I want to emphasise this.

Another negative in Life is Strange is the basicness of the game. For one, it is through the lack of builiding on relationships. As a player, I would have loved to know how much decisions impacted the story and what its relations on people were. For example, I defended Kate in her situations and was a good friend to her, but at the end of the game, it made no difference on my decisions affecting her. I felt this takes away from the game.

Overall, this game is a masterpiece. Just an absolute great game with the overwhemingly positive story and the other aspects like artwork and the soundtrack that complement the story. Just exceptional and I highly recommend this game at full price. 10/10 for the full series.

Thanks for reading my review! If you like my reviews and care to read more, feel free to join Antwog's Analysis (Reviews). http://steamcommunity.com/groups/AntwogReviews

If you have questions comment below or post in Antwog's Analysis (Reviews) general discussion page. If you liked it, give it a rating.

reviewText:
I've never written any reviews for any game but this one really deserves it. What can I say ? Awesome story, great and interesting characters, the soundtrack is just PERFECT from Syd Matters to the Foals, super immersive experience, it really felt like I was actually in the game !
I've played it two times, and I enjoyed every part of it. My only regret the first time was that  I couldn't save Kate and it made me so sad. :'(

Now the downside of the game (it was still a perfect gaming experience for me nevertheless) : I didn't find the last episode as good as the others. It began in a really good way, then it got a bit boring (the nightmare part was a little too long for my taste) and in the end, no matter what choices you made, you'll end up picking one of the only two possible endings.
The first time I decided to sacrifice Chloe. This ending was made in such a beautiful way, I was still crying about it weeks after I've finished it. Then I wanted to see what the other ending looked like... And what a disappointment. Way shorter than the other, we don't really see a lot happening because they just leave the city not even wondering if Joyce, Warren or the others might still be alive... Weird.

Other than that Dontnod made a reaaaaally good job with this game, it was realistic, and there are many references here and there it's always funny to see. The incredibly good voice acting gets you even more into it.  Chloe's voice in the Junkyard scene completely broke my heart. :( One thing I particularly loved is all these moments where you can just sit somewhere, relax and listen to Max's thoughts and the wonderful music while looking at beautiful sceneries. *-*

So yes, this game is a straight 1000/10 for me, will play it again for sure. ♥

reviewText:
What if you could go back in time and change history? Would you fix your mistakes? There is only one catch, fixing your mistakes might cause severe problems in the future. This is the basic premise behind Life is Strange, a charming adventure game from DontNod Entertainment, where mistakes are a trial run and friendships last forever.

Set in the idyllic seaside town of Arcadia Bay, the story centres around two great friends who are searching for a missing girl. To find her, they will use a time-rewind ability that allows you to change conversations and solve non-linear puzzles. You play as Max Caulfield, a softly-spoken photography student, who is joined by her best friend Chloe Price, a rebellious teenager. Together they experience joy and sorrow across 12-15 hours of memorable adventuring in five substantial episodes.

From a gameplay perspective, it is most similar to the Telltale games. This means lots of conversations and basic puzzles. But rewinding time changes things for the better, and is used cleverly in some of the earlier episodes. It also has some exquisitely crafted scenes with brilliant camera angles and compositions. Also worth mentioning is the charming music, featuring slow guitar strumming and gentle voices, perfect for those emotional moments. Lip-syncing is really the biggest disappointment, not up to standard for a game with this much dialogue. It also needed more voice actors.

Aside from these minor pitfalls, DontNod Entertainment has crafted an endearing, time-bending and memorable adventure with Life is Strange. It takes players on a quirky sci-fi adventure through time and space as they uncover the truth. It will be hard to forget the special moments these two great friends share.

Read the full review[www.newgamenetwork.com]

reviewText:
Life Is Strange tells the tale of a young photography student Max. She has just started in her new school. Things are already complicated for her but her life takes a strange twist when she gets the power to travel back in time.

Max can only rewind for a few minutes and this is also a gameplay mechanic to be used in puzzles and choices in dialogue. It's really interesting mechanic and it makes the game standout from other modern adventure games. Even though it bothers me a bit that Max always comments when time could or should be rewinded. It would be more fun to figure out these things myself. Also sometimes the story forces you in time more than just few minutes.

There's plenty of things to look at and interact with, for example posters and notes. Or you can just chill for awhile and play some guitar or sit at the fountain on the schoolyard. There are many characters you can have dialogue with, however those conversations aren't unfortunately very long. But many of the characters were really interesting with their own backstories and mysteries. When you make choices in the game, it will notify in the upright corner this action will have consequences". Unfortunately these choices very rarely affect the game in the long run. In the end you have two choices to pick the ending from. But that being said
date: every choice you make is part of your personal story. You made the choice and it happened. Just because they don't affect the ending cinematic they shouldn't be disregarded. As they say
