reviewText:
This is an impressions review. As I play through the rest of the episodes, I will adjust the review accordingly, and will archive past impressions in the comment section.


So, episode two.

Obviously, the pacing was better with the second episode, as it should be, since the major, initial character development was no longer necessary.

This one focused more on providing a solid direction for the plot to follow. The rewind feature was less prominent, but the story itself took the front seat and ran with it.

This isnt to say the rewind feature was non-existent. Quite the opposite. It was used often. It was however used more as a story device and less as a unique feature.

So, this episode featured some tough choices and one definitely story changing arc depending on how you handled a specific scenario. Surprisingly so actually. The variation should cause some increasingly divergant experiences for players through the remaining episodes.

Anyway, I thought the pacing was better, the characters were obviously more familiar, and yet some of the ideas you probably had from episode one will be shattered or at least make you revisit your past assumptions. I found that to be both interesting and compelling.

So, where I thought the first episode was okay with a lot of promise, I thought episode two was actually really good and continued to keep you interested throughout. It also encourages you to at least playthrough it twice given the very, incredibly different possibilities that come from a single event in the story.

I will eagerly await episode three to see what happens next.

reviewText:
*edit after final episode release at the end

This is the first time I even bothered to write a review here on Steam.
After playing the first 3 episodes I honestly can't understand why DONTNOD didn't ask for more money for the complete package. I am completely hooked after 60% of the story.
If they can continue the quality of storytelling for the last 2 episodes this game will definitely be my favorite of this year (if they end it on a satisfying note *cough*MassEffect*cough*).
The short point is that the complete package out of visual style, music, voice acting, tiny little details and the emotional impact of choices make me enjoy this game a lot more than most games in my library.

For the very reasonable price a definite must buy for everyone who loves adventures and/or fun storytelling.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
So, episode 5 finally dropped and the story has an end.
The only problem is that the ending(s) we got is imho relatively disappointing.....

So after leaving Ep.5 with a slightly sour taste in my mouth would I sitll recommend this game?
Yes, definitely yes. As a Journey, I still think the game delivers brilliantly, especially considering th low asking price. One of the best adventures I played in the last years even though it could have been perfect and ultimately wasn't.

Anyway, buy it ;)

reviewText:
MysterD's Assessment:
HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.


Mini-Review:
Life Is Strange is an excellent episodic adventure gaming series (which lasted me 17.2 hours according to Steam for my 1st playthrough of the entire season), though unfortunately squanders reaching complete greatness with the final 1/2 hour of Episode 5. With such a predictable conclusion; and especially any lack of either closure for the series or set-up for more LiS content (whether it would be another Episode or Entire Season), LiS never reaches the heights that it should ultimately ascend to.

With such an excellent premise, Max (our playable heroine) embarks on a jouney of finding out she - and you, as the player - have the power to manipulate time to find out information & even change events from actually ever occuring - which is absolutely awesome, as both a storyline hook & as a gameplay mechanic. Experimentation with the time-manipulation mechanic can often feel fun, rewarding, interesting, intriguing, nerve-wracking, and/or daunting depending on the situation at hand.

Set in a High School, important themes of how people (especially teenagers) are often treated and behave are front-and-center here, as you will make decisions (often, many of them have a lot of weight) will change the actual journey itself of how the game plays out. Not only this, but there's the story of a girl who went missing that Max and her life-long friend Chloe are trying to find. Unraveling the mystery of the missing girl, experience the journey, and making lots of decisions is - well, for the most part - is fantastic.

Like Mass Effect 3, Life Is Strange still should be played & not missed for its fantastic journey though-out all of Episodes 1-4 and most of Episode 5. The journey is absolutely fantastic and should be experienced for that alone, even if the conclusion to LiS is one of the most epic disappointments since the conclusion of Mass Effect 3 (base-game).

For more details and my thoughts...
...On this series, look at my thoughts of Life Is Strange in two places in my Steam Groups:

Episodes 1-4:
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/TGAEC/discussions/0/530647080133925863/

Episode 5 in particular:
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/TGAEC/discussions/0/483367798520665015/

reviewText:
Before I start I would like to say that I bought this game long time ago, as soon I saw the trailer I knew I would love the game, but it would be too much torture play each episode independently. So I wait until the last chapter was released and now I can absolutely tell you that all my expectations were achieved in this amazing game. =D

You are Max, a young photography student that has the ability to come back in time, and you will face many tough questions of life in your journey like crimes, drugs, bullying, the search for our own identity, friendship, death, and other life subjects of teens and young adults on your way to live your life in the most correct way, as you always had lived.

The excellence of the game shines through some very important aspects:

1 - the interactive narrative that always give us options to explore and advance in a unique way, with a great tree of decisions and consequences (choose wisely...);

2 - the amazing characters in the world, each one with a complete background story that we know as the game goes on;

3 - the totally awesome voice acting, that give us the ambience and the mood in every situation;

4 - the cool music and the sounds that keep us immersive in the world and in each scene.

5 - lots of notes and texts to give a more tridimensional view of the places, the people and our own choices and consequences.

The gameplay is pretty simple and works like charm like it is expected. The graphics and art style are also simple, in a celshading-like effect that I personally liked very much and works great to transmit the ambience of the game.

The only down point for me was a few puzzles that you can say the right thing always. It was a bit boring make a mistake in the end of the conversation and lose it all. I liked more the puzzles that we had to explore the scenery and use the power to change the situation and complete the goal.

In the end, I enjoyed it so much, and if you like a good interactive narrative, great story, excellent characters and a total immersion in a game and its problems (as much as I like) you MUST play Life is Strange. Certainly this game became one of my favorites of all time. ❤
voteText: 11 of 14 people (79%) found this review helpful

reviewText: The one thing I really love about this game is that the options don't give the false illusion of choice. I feel like with a lot of games like this, no matter what you choose you'll get the same major outcome only slightly different. Often in this game every different option can cause an entire different outcome. Most notably in episode 2 when it's actually possible to not save Kate. The story can be a bit melodramatic as you’re dealing with a bunch of private school teenagers and the dialogue can feel a bit forced but overall it draws you in and makes you want to know what is going to happen. Honestly can’t wait for the rest of the season to come out. The one thing I wish this game had was a lot more save slots since there’s so many different options and paths you can take. Overall 8/10. Will update when the rest of the episodes hit.

reviewText:
You should buy this and play it, right now. Only if you find everything presented about this game as being very off-putting should you even consider waiting around for a discount. This really needs to be experienced. Especially if you love the Pacific Northwest and great stories set in them, like X-Files and Twin Peaks.

Over the last few years, a lot of games had some story and some originality, but to many of us a few particular titles seemed rather pretentious. Or, rather, those heaping far more praise on the titles than they deserved seemed to be pretentious. Attempting to impress by affecting greater importance, talent, culture... than is actually possessed.

It isn't that all of these other games have been awful. In fact, many have been decent and enjoyable. They just did not seem to be the great revelation or evolution to gaming. Walking simulators (a label I do not use pejoratively) were slobbered over and deemed to be great leaps in story telling. When viewed more objectively, they seemed to only have good stories for a game". A couple of story beats climaxing

reviewText: I looked forward to this title, from the moment I saw previews for it. Life is Strange is a choice-driven, episodic story of a young woman named Max, who finds she has the ability to reverse time, enough to undo a mistake or even save a friends life. As an aspiring Photographer, who is enrolled in the elitist Blackwell Academy, Max see's the world through a photographers lens. Reunited with her childhood friend Chloe, she embarks on an adventure to find out what happened to a missing student, Six months prior, as well as to confront the terrifying visions of what is to befall the town of Arcadia Bay in the coming days. Having finished Episode One, I look forward to the rest of the season of, Life is Strange. Definitely recommend.

reviewText:
Finished the game a hour ago and let it all sink in.
I was really impressed by the art and the story is great.
The 'time' twist is worked out very well.
For all of this I would say the game is a great ride.

I know it's not always fair to compare but I know I really appreciate that kind of reviews from gamers so I know what I'm getting into. I didn't want to have missed this game but when you don't have much money to spend and you've got to make choices.......

....start with a few Telltale games. (Unless you're a teenage girl or a young adolescent woman...you'll totally dig Life is Strange). But for you guys out there!

1. Tales from the Borderlands (Telltale)
2. The Walking Dead (season I) (Telltale)
3. The Walking Dead (season 2) (Telltale)
4. Game of Thrones (Telltale)
5. Life is Strange
6. The Wolf Among Us (Telltale)

Telltale has more pace in his games and more 'balls' even when you 'play' a female role.
But then again, Life is Strange has tons of beautiful art and everyone with a heart will like the story.
And the influence your choices are making are bigger in this one than any Telltale game.
But my advice would be the above.

reviewText: I  LOVE  this game. I could write something really analytical, even pretentious; that just goes on and on about symbolism and themes and what it all means and how I really felt. I could defend what people see as flaws, but I'm just gonna do something a lot simpler.\n\nThis is a great game. It's not perfect, there are definitely moments that can detract, but it's all about perspective. It's really the kind of experience you have to draw personal connections to, really get emotionally involved with. It's the first thing in a long time that really made me question what I wanted to do in a game on the basis of morality or doing what I felt was right for the player character. The music is very often wistful, and carries emotion and sentiment that fits well. The art style is pleasing, although i can't say much for the actual graphics since I had to play on all low excepting texture size(although I still didnt mind the look of anything in the game honestly). The writing is good, but dialogue can have some questionable elements. The game tries to tiptoe between pop culture references and humor that reflect both classical approaches to subcultures, and the sort of hipster

reviewText:
WE ALL HAVE OUR OWN EXPERIENCES, BUT WE RARELY APPRECIATE THE VALUE THEY TEACH US
Life is Strange is an adventure game developed by DONTNOD Entertainment and published by Square Enix.

Originally posted by Edward Lorenz:Chaos: When the present determines the future, but the approximate present does not approximately determine the future.
To cut a long story short - the game is worth it, because it deals with problems we all faced in our lives in some way or another. I do not want to spoil anything as it really is a touching experience, but I guarantee that you will be moved by the characters' problems, because we can all relate to them. Suffice to say, we all knew or know someone dealing with drugs, depression, bullying (including social media), step-father issues, a person/friend gone missing, love and financial problems, and true friendship.
The game showcases these everlasting notions we face even now.

The choices we make in the game do matter and what we don't say or actions we ignore, will manifest themselves in the next episode; often with deadly repercussions. We cannot rewind time in our daily lives, try to experience what if we could change the decisions we make and see what will (would) happen. Chaos Theory at its best.

I honestly, and me being a gamer for 22 years, can give this game a 10/10. They say a 10 is a game without flaws and I see no reason that it shouldn't be considered as one:

Graphics - outstanding, the attention to detail even when characters are crying is phenomenal and the environment is so believable that it remembered me of my high school days (placement of bins, lockers, people chatting about school problems, love problems, making plans for the weekend, a football game on Friday)

Audio - in conjunction with the video aspect it fits perfectly. Dormitories sound like dormitories, school talk is so good that you can stand for 5 minutes in the corridor and feel the youth we all experienced (or we are about to).

Dialogues and Story - with graphics making everything so real and music creating the substantial environment of high school; the dialogues finish it off with a bang. Christian Davine and Jean-Luc Cano nailed it with teenage jargon (LoL, wowser, hashtags, sexting, Facebooking etc.) and creating a story that grips you from the moment you reverse time for the . . . first time.
I hoped I delivered the message and haven't spoiled anything.

The game is cheap for the value it offers - buy it and you will not be disappointed. After all, you can buy the game, play it and rewind before clicking PURCHASE FOR MYSELF"

reviewText:
I wanna to start this review by saying that this is definitely in my top 10 games that I've played, if u like story based games (like The Walking Dead for example) u'll luv this one!

STORY (Spoiler-Free & Short):

U playin' as Max Caulfield, a student in art school, who out of nowhere learns how to rewind time. And she sees her best friend from her childhood, Chloe, after a long time and they start to solve a mystery of a missing girl together n' w/ all of that comes an amazing plot w/ a lot of a stuff going Max's life & school with all the different scenarios & relationships.

The story overall was perfect, it had so many plotwists that it kept me interested all the way through, n' of course the humour was great as well.

They established a great atmosphere on this game as well, amazing job with that.

The characters in this game are as good as any game ever, they did all the different persons & personalities amazingly.

I won't spoil it, but there are 2 different endings n' I must say that I was kind of disappointed with the one that I chose... Not cos' of the actual choice but cos' the game kind of didn't do justice to it. The other choice was so well put together & presented deeply but the ending I chose just didn't really show what happened...

GRAPHICS:

The game was also very very pretty. The graphics & camera angles were perfect. The game was really artistic & I really liked that, ever.

GAMEPLAY:

The game is point & click game, very similiar to Telltale's games. U make ur own choices & find different stuff as u wander around that matter the story.

SOUNDTRACK:

I had to make soundtrack as it's own category. This game has one of the BEST sondtracks of ANY game that I've ever played! The soundtrack is just absolutely amazing.

VERDICT:

I would suggest this game to almost everybody, if u are into story rich & choices matter games, this is ur choise.
I just want to emphasise n' point out the excellence of all the characters & soundtrack of this game one more time, it was just mindblowingly good, this is truly a memorable game.

SCORE:
10 / 10

reviewText:
Life is Strange é uma experiência incrivelmente imersiva na vida de uma adolescente, Max.

Ele possui indiscutivelmente a melhor trilha sonora que já ouvi em um jogo e coloca vários memes espalhados por todo o jogo para zombar de um personagem ou elemento na história. O meu recurso favorito no jogo é que ele permite você se sentar, ouvir o meio ambiente ou apenas tomar um fôlego no meio da história.

Esse jogo facilmente brincou com as minhas emoções e literalmente me fez ficar triste, furiosa, em êxtase, e depois triste novamente em cerca de 10 minutos.

É profundamente surpreendente o quanto a narrativa muda até o final da história. Seus relacionamentos realmente importam com as pessoas e eu sinto por todos os personagens do jogo.

A única reclamação que eu e todos os outros tem é o fato de que suas decisões no começo não afetam tanto no final do jogo como gostariamos e como o jogo dizia que iria ser.

Mas de qualquer forma, foi um dos melhores jogos que já joguei e o que mais mexeu comigo. Não me importaria de dar replay nele minha vida toda. <3

Trilha Sonora.
voteText: 13 of 19 people (68%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
This game has to be my favorite episodic game so far... it's beautiful. The developers know how to bring out your emotions, I was full of hope then torn apart, I felt like a superhero then the next second I felt useless, I loved and I lost, I gained knowledge then felt played. This game made me feel it all happiness, sadness, love, depression, hopeless, hope, struggle, fear etc the list goes on... it's art and everyone should experience it at least once in their lives!

The game has a lot of good things about it and right off the bat is the options it's better than I expected it to be it has fullscreen, borderless and windowed mode. It has decent options plenty to play with but they only go up to high there's no ultra or anything like that. Keyboard and mouse work great and everything is rebindable, a controller also works straight out of the box with no problem. The graphics in this game are very pretty sometimes ugly here and there but for the most part it's gorgeous to look at. The gameplay is pretty much your typical episodic game type stuff except with a twist here you can rewind time giving you so much more possibilities to work with it's great fun! Plus the game has small time puzzles if your a fan of that. THE SOUNDTRACK IS BEAUTIFUL some of the best I've heard in a game to date, you can easily listen to it outside of the game... it's honestly worth a listen too. The story at first is your typical cliche teen flick but then rapidly changes... so don't be fooled by it's looks at first the game opens up a lot later on. The game is a good length I was expecting 12-15 hours and including 100% it's like 17 hours. The game does one thing right with collectibles they don't force you to go looking for them they want you to explore, talk and hell if you don't like that on the first run? You can simply always restart episodes in collectible mode which is super super super good plus one for that!

While I would love to say the game is perfect it's not I mean for one the puzzles there either too easy or too annoying it's not that fun to go through. Sometimes the story just drags on... I guess you get say they left in space to take breathers but honestly I didn't enjoy those parts. The game like I said before does have ugly looking textures, while I usually never complain about dumb crap like that... in this game though it is pretty noticeable like the hands GOD THE HANDS! While I'm sure some people like it there are things to the game that are so easily missable until you see them in the results screen making you scratch your head as in how the hell could you have possibly missed something like that. One minor problem I had was the game is screenshot madness which I love until an item you pick up gets stuck on your screen... bad design choice on that one should have made it a toggle off and on feature.

I think the game is wonderful and I would honestly recommend it to anyone like I said before it's something everyone should experience at least once in their lives... I cannot wait to see what's in store for us in season 2!

reviewText:
Pretty nice mishmash of sci-fi and teen drama with amazing music, decent voice acting and plot.

Basically its like that The Butterfly Effect" film which is in turn based on every single book featuring time travel and chaos theory.

I was satisfied with different choices and consequences presented in the game compared to Telltale games like "Walking Dead" or "Game of Thrones" where your choices often do not make any difference whatsoever. Though the ending did screw everything up by basically erasing everything you done previously and making your feelings towards characters inconsequential. But that's the frigging time travel for you - just can't get everything you want the way you want.

I would advise you to not repeat my mistake and do not look at forums

One of the few better games this year."

reviewText:
A story-driven point-and-click adventure in the vein of Telltale's current direction, but with an added twist: You can rewind time.

What starts as just a quirky, vaguely ominous Lynchian spin on your everyday teen's social minefields and petty high-school fiefdoms quickly becomes more tense, with frequent life-or-death consequences and plenty of tugs at the heartstrings. Things in Life is Strange are, on the surface, far less dire than in comprable games like Telltale's The Walking Dead, but it doesn't shy from world-shattering climax or a smaller, more personal apocalypse.

The time travel gimmick seems one-dimensional at first, just allowing you to correct mistakes. But there are some advanced applications. Since you stay anchored to your position while you rewind time, you can effectively teleport" with it or pick up objects so they remain unaffected by the rewind. It also allows you to see multiple outcomes when presented with branching choices. There's still no telling how one choice will differ from another if and when they carry over to later episodes

recommended: since you can use your rewind powers to check all your options

reviewText:
In this story-driven adventure you play as Max, a photography student who suddendly discovers she can rewind time and thus change any recent event she experiences: a fortuitous meeting will drag her into investigating not only events happening at her school but also some strange natural phenomenoms that seemed to be occurring in the city.
Life Is Strange puts most of its power into a story rather than puzzle-driven gameplay, thankfully said story is excellent and backed up by a strong, engaging narrative and a great protagonist.

PROS:

-the graphics are quite good, I loved how the style is a mix of realistic elements (most things) while some are styled like a comic (photos, posters and books)

-top notch soundtrack, the songs used to close each episode are especially stunning

-great voice acting

-Max is a nice character with a likeable goofy, geeky side: her psychological growth during the series is done well and feels believable

-a great story incorporating elements of coming of age, choices, destiny, investigating mysteries, love and grief

-the narrative sustains good momentum for most of the game and can competently jump between funny, emotional and serious scenes

-the time rewind power is put to great use both in puzzles and dialogues: the fact you're limited to knowing only the immediate impact of any choice will keep you on edge while preventing your powers from becoming an easy way out or making the narrative too predictable

-your choices are truly meaningful and will influence events, relationship, places, sometimes even across multiple episodes

-photography is treated with love during the whole game with reference to famous photographers, their books, photo equipment and technique: it's really a love letter to the medium

CONS:

-could have used a better AA, a few textures are somewhat disappointing and a some character skins look a bit like plastic

-some dialogues can be a bit verbose

-certain characters, scenes and dialogue lines can feel a bit too cliche and cheesy

-a couple puzzles can become a bit dull as you rewind over and over and try to get them right

-one of the two final endings feels a bit hurried and short compared to the other

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=544435083

It's hard to review Life Is Strange while maintaining this review free of spoilers as much of its power comes from the story, from investigating people and events, from the various and sudden twists you'll have to face. The puzzles are generally nothing to write home about but fit the narrative well and, at times, force you to think outside the box by using your power to solve them: overall they do a decent enough job and prevent the game from becoming just an interactive movie.

The time rewind power made me actually second guess myself more than usual to be honest, seeing the short-term outcomes of each action made me go what if" quite often and the fact your power never becomes an "I win" button is something I welcome: be sure your choices will sometimes affect things profoundly and you'll only know how much when you get there.

Things can be a bit cliched or cheesy at times
date: with moments and lines that'd fit a teen drama tv series
recommended: certain puzzles can feel a bit awkward and require lots of rewinds until you understand what you're supposed to do and there are times where lengthy dialogues overstay their welcome but these are just blemishes on an excellent game experience.\n\nLife Is Strange is a great journey
hoursPlayed: one worth taking no matter who you are and that is sure to stay with you even once you're done with the game: I fully recommend it even when at full price."

reviewText:
In this story-driven adventure you play as Max, a photography student who suddendly discovers she can rewind time and thus change any recent event she experiences: a fortuitous meeting will drag her into investigating not only events happening at her school but also some strange natural phenomenoms that seemed to be occurring in the city.
Life Is Strange puts most of its power into a story rather than puzzle-driven gameplay, thankfully said story is excellent and backed up by a strong, engaging narrative and a great protagonist.

PROS:

-the graphics are quite good, I loved how the style is a mix of realistic elements (most things) while some are styled like a comic (photos, posters and books)

-top notch soundtrack, the songs used to close each episode are especially stunning

-great voice acting

-Max is a nice character with a likeable goofy, geeky side: her psychological growth during the series is done well and feels believable

-a great story incorporating elements of coming of age, choices, destiny, investigating mysteries, love and grief

-the narrative sustains good momentum for most of the game and can competently jump between funny, emotional and serious scenes

-the time rewind power is put to great use both in puzzles and dialogues: the fact you're limited to knowing only the immediate impact of any choice will keep you on edge while preventing your powers from becoming an easy way out or making the narrative too predictable

-your choices are truly meaningful and will influence events, relationship, places, sometimes even across multiple episodes

-photography is treated with love during the whole game with reference to famous photographers, their books, photo equipment and technique: it's really a love letter to the medium

CONS:

-could have used a better AA, a few textures are somewhat disappointing and a some character skins look a bit like plastic

-some dialogues can be a bit verbose

-certain characters, scenes and dialogue lines can feel a bit too cliche and cheesy

-a couple puzzles can become a bit dull as you rewind over and over and try to get them right

-one of the two final endings feels a bit hurried and short compared to the other

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=544435083

It's hard to review Life Is Strange while maintaining this review free of spoilers as much of its power comes from the story, from investigating people and events, from the various and sudden twists you'll have to face. The puzzles are generally nothing to write home about but fit the narrative well and, at times, force you to think outside the box by using your power to solve them: overall they do a decent enough job and prevent the game from becoming just an interactive movie.

The time rewind power made me actually second guess myself more than usual to be honest, seeing the short-term outcomes of each action made me go what if" quite often and the fact your power never becomes an "I win" button is something I welcome: be sure your choices will sometimes affect things profoundly and you'll only know how much when you get there.

Things can be a bit cliched or cheesy at times
date: with moments and lines that'd fit a teen drama tv series
recommended: certain puzzles can feel a bit awkward and require lots of rewinds until you understand what you're supposed to do and there are times where lengthy dialogues overstay their welcome but these are just blemishes on an excellent game experience.\n\nLife Is Strange is a great journey
hoursPlayed: one worth taking no matter who you are and that is sure to stay with you even once you're done with the game: I fully recommend it even when at full price."

reviewText:
NO SPOILING AHEAD

I have finished the game, and I have to say that this was one if not the best gaming experience I ever got.
(I finished ALL endings, atleast I hope that have been all)
The game drags you inside, you become one with Protagonist Maxine Caulfield and you go through five episodes of pure emotion. By that I mean, I know there had been people crying because of the happenings of this game, I can tell I managed not to cry but there were numerous moments (almost the whole game) which caught me up really strong.

If thats not enough, you build up a relationship with every single character in this game (which is normal in most games to be honest).
On top of that every choice you make in this game is a 'Butterfly Effect', means every single choice you make ingame might change past, presence or future.
I just finished the game so my mind is still heavily blown and emotions are overflowing (to be honest I think I'll get emotional issues for the end of the week XD)
The price is too fair. I would pay three times more to enjoy all that emotion and experience.
In other words I must say this is a masterpiece, there is much more to the game as for example everyone has their spirit animal, the colors are bound to characters because they have specific meanings and alot of other things I could count up  if my mind wouldn't be too blasted from what I just experienced playing.

In short: Buy this game, let emotions slap you right in the face, build up a relationship to each character, get mind-blown all the time, go cry in a corner because the game wrecked your emotions.
Also, I have not encountered any bugs whatsoever, so technically this game also is a masterpiece.
I'd also like to spoil something I encountered at the end. On the title screen after finishing episode 5, there was a message saying 'Thank you for playing Life is Strange Season 1', which means there might be another season coming up next year, so more emotions, more people who got converted into emotional wracks, more relations, more slaps in the face, and much more gaming experience.

TEXT ABOVE IN SHORT- This game is one of the best games I have ever played
- Gets really emotional (really really really emotional)
- Drags you into the gameplay
- You might cry like a little b*tch but thats nothing to worry about when playing this game
- I can clearly say buy this game - you will not regret it.

reviewText:
I believe the common perception of episodic games is most people really like it to be fully released before they grab and play it in one shot. If you are that type, I have a good news for you. When you play it later on, whenever that is, you will like it enough if not totally enjoy it. The wait will be worth it.

Sure, I am only talking about the game by the first episode alone, and this review can be reviewed. To compare with other episodic adventure games, Life Is Strange provides a richer content in storyline in form of verbal choices and journal reading. A lot more character is involved and there is a lot more content for you to read and explore so to fully enjoy the game you shouldn't really rush through it. This also in turns give more game time for the you to play the game when new episode releases.

Aside from the ability that your main character has, the game is realistic which evolve around college students and all the dramas involved in college life. Aside from having pretty graphics and arts, the game requires you to make choices of which you can be given the chance to correct (with limit of course) and just make  your own story of how you want your character to be, to represent, and to progress with the story flow. To top it off, the game is also accompanied by a good theme and soundtrack.

reviewText:
So I finished the first episode of Life Is Strange a few hours ago and I was just thinking about the game all the time so I decided to write a review about it.

The story is about a girl who wants to start a new life by moving back to a town where she grew up as a kid. At her new school she studies photography since she loves to view her life through a lense where its safe, Just when she thought her new life was crap, she realized it was only just the beginning...

The music is seriously amazing and I am actually listening to it while I am writing this review.
I also really like the atmosphere and colors which makes the game look more alive in a happy way.
Life Is Strange is a point and click where you decide what's the best. The decisions you make can affect the story and the way characters act against you.

If you are reading this review because you are not sure if you should buy the game or not, BUY IT!

reviewText:
Ever had moments where you hope you could go back in time and, undo, something? Or do something that you think should have been done?

Well, this point and click adventure explores that idea, quite extensively. The idea sounds cliché at first, like this is some high school drama where you can use superpowers to beat everyone who is mean to you. But it's more than that, it goes much further down the rabbit hole.

Not only is the game great story-wise, but it also has more interactivity than just dialogue choices. You can rewind time and perform actions that you could not do before, due to acquiring knowledge about what is going to happen. Doing this kind of thing in i.e. a movie would be pretty confusing, right? But in the game, it being a game mechanic, it kind of made sense, in its own way.

So, in my opinion, this game is amazing. But opinions are subjective, so I can't say if you would feel the same. If you have played Telltale games previously, I suggest you try this out. I do hope Dontnod does more of these kind of adventures.
voteText: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
UPDATE: Episode 3 Review down below!

Life Is Strange™ is basically a third person point and click adventure like The Walking Dead from Telltale Games.

Story
You follow the story of young Max who is a student at the Blackwell Academy - a school focused on photography and arts. The story starts out of the blue (though I'm not exactly gonna write how) and puts you into the life of an eighteen year old girl. This obviously means teen problems, anxiety and the fear of not belonging to society. Shortly after the introduction you discover that Max has a supernatural gift: Time Rewinding. She can jump back in time and redo things (for example if she broke a glass or something she could try and prevent this from happening) With this comes the important aspect of the Butterfly Effect. (The tiniest difference could make a huge impact) What does that mean now? One little aspect of Episode 1 could make the outcome of Episode 5 totally different (in theory - we will see how the developers will implement this). In comparison to The Walking Dead I have the feeling that my decisions really matter and don't just swap out" some characters or items
date:
etc. It feels like everything is connected in some way. The cool thing about this is that you can try out all possibilities just by rewinding time. Not feeling okay with your decision? Rewind time and try again!

Gameplay
So as mentioned you play Max from a Third Person View. I used my XBOX360-Gamepad and it felt pretty nice. Interacting works decent enough. You move Max with the left stick and can look around with the right stick. If there is something interesting to see the game will tell you which button you have to press to interact. (Mostly A or Y from what I have seen) You can run slightly faster by holding the Right Trigger and you can rewind time by holding the Left Trigger.  (They get explained anyway during the game
recommended: so don't worry)\n\nThe game focuses on you making decisions and just checking out stuff in the school and around. I must say that the diary and documents scattered throughout are really well written and I enjoyed reading them. I recommend you all to take the time and read them. The episode is short anyway and it gives you some interesting insight on the world of Life is Strange. There are some "puzzles" to be solved
hoursPlayed: where you have to use your rewinding skills in order to move on with the story. Nothing brainmelting so far
voteText: but still pretty cool. The gameplay is mostly interaction with the environment and talking to people.\n\nOne important thing to mention is that you are mostly bound to an area. So if you leave the area that means that you are progressing in the story and can't just go back immediately. It's perfectly fine if you just want to see the story and move from point A to B
helpfulPercent:
but if you are a person like me that wants to check out everything possible you should take your time and be sure that you saw everything.

Graphics
So here is one thing that bothers me personally. I actually like the "drawn" style of Life is Strange but all the plants (bushes
votesHelpful: trees
votesTotal:
etc...) look horrible and awkward in my opinion. Indoors the graphics are perfectly fine for my taste.(though the hair of some people may look awkward at first) I do like however how the developers played with light and shadows. The sunset looks authentic and beautiful. So you can expect to take some screenshots!

Other stuff
The voice acting is great and authentic. Max is well written (like basically all of the characters from what you can see in episode 1) and there are some nice hidden details like a family TV that used to be in the living room been given to the child since the family bought a new bigger TV. It actually makes you feel like they took the characters from a real world family and put them into an interesting story. One thing that I experienced was that the lip syncing is not so well. Not so bad
votesFunny:
but I expect them to fix this in episode 2.

Overall Life is Strange Episode 1 is a promising start to a great story and interesting characters. If you enjoyed The Walking Dead you will have a lot of fun with this game.

EPISODE 2: Out Of Time Review
So finally episode 2 has been released and I couldn't wait to play it already. First of all for those of you who have trouble installing the second episode: If steam doesn't download the DLC automatically
commentsCount: check if you have any active downloads
column16:
pause those if needed. Untick the DLC and tick it again - restart steam and it should start to download the DLC. At least that worked for me.

Now to the game: So we start of the next morning after the finale of episode 1. The cool thing about this game is that your actions from the previous episode really matter. Often throughout the episode I was like "Oh so if I had reacted the other way in the past I could have done this better/worse". This is something that TWD for example did not do very good. (at least in my opinion)

The locations are really great and you get to know the last two characters that have not been introduced yet. I was entertained greatly by the little tasks I had to do. And again there is a hell lot to explore and read - and I recommend you reading everything and by that I mean EVERYTHING. I realized that it can matter quite a lot if you get any side information
column17: so take your time
column18: explore every room and check twice before leaving. It is nice that there is no sort of rush going on. And there were a lot of cute little details hidden. I recommend looking for them!\n\nSo the story did not get a lot more input for now
column19: I understand that they want to keep that for the last episodes
column20: though I expect episode 3 to be much more storydriven compared to episode 2. This one is more about the characters (as I said introducing the two missing ones) and focuses on the relationship between Max and Chloe
column21: but you also had to choose something
column22: which could make future relationships change - if in the good way or bad way you have to see for yourself! The dialogues were between good and great. One thing I noticed is that the lipsyncing seems to be better. The game feels more polished now after all these patches - so good job there DONTNOD!\n\nSo to sum it up: Don't expect a lot of story for now. It is like 70% character development (which they really need to build up the story in the following episodes) and 30% "story" and tough decisions. And they really are tough
column23: I was sitting for minutes thinking about the consequences. So if you haven't already bought the full game I recommend you doing so. So maybe one more question some people might ask: Is it better or worse than episode 1? Neither
column24: they are both equally good. They each serve their own purpose (E1: Story/Character introduction - E2: Characterdevelopment) Episode 2 is again a fun experience and makes you want to see more from the life of little Max.\n\nEPISODE 3: Chaos Theory ReviewI was really hyped for the third episode Chaos Theory and I finally got to play it. reviewText: I really, really liked this game. It does seem like fluff, nothing but highschool/college drama with some gimmick rewind ability thrown in but it didn't take long to realize it was something completely different. The story is excellent, even while some of the dialogue is kinda cheesy and it becomes clear it is adults trying to write for teenagers (or maybe teenagers/young adults really do talk like that, idk) and the lip syncing was pretty horrible (though supposedly this was fix some in a patch.)\n\nMany scenes are so beautifully done, you do need to take the time to stop and look at everything (which is driven home since you can have Max stop, sit, and just look at her surroundings.) The episodes just ramp it up, episode 3 blew my mind, episode 4 kinda ♥♥♥♥ed me up, and episode 5... well I was prepared to be disappointed but it went completely sideways and I did not expect a lot of what happened. The final end choice was somewhat disappointing, but otherwise I really, reaaaally enjoyed this game.

reviewText:
Ever had moments where you hope you could go back in time and, undo, something? Or do something that you think should have been done?

Well, this point and click adventure explores that idea, quite extensively. The idea sounds cliché at first, like this is some high school drama where you can use superpowers to beat everyone who is mean to you. But it's more than that, it goes much further down the rabbit hole.

Not only is the game great story-wise, but it also has more interactivity than just dialogue choices. You can rewind time and perform actions that you could not do before, due to acquiring knowledge about what is going to happen. Doing this kind of thing in i.e. a movie would be pretty confusing, right? But in the game, it being a game mechanic, it kind of made sense, in its own way.

So, in my opinion, this game is amazing. But opinions are subjective, so I can't say if you would feel the same. If you have played Telltale games previously, I suggest you try this out. I do hope Dontnod does more of these kind of adventures.
voteText: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game really caught me by surprise, at first I thought it was your typical game that you made some choices that in the end didn't matter. But now that I am at the end of the ride I can fully say that this game really impacted in my own choices IN REAL LIFE. The game carries a lot of thoughts behind it, and it's executions on how it delivers them is as close as I think games will get to art. I'm not saying it's flawless either, there's some hit and miss on the dialog but overall it managed to satisfy my suspension of disbelief long enough to develop some really deep feelings for the characters and that is sometimes very hard to do in a game. This is my opinion however so you might take it or leave it when it comes to you deciding to get this game, I completely recommend it and encourage you to go through this experience of a game.

reviewText:
This game is actually pretty awesome and the thing that made me buy it and give it a shot in the first place is that they give you the ability to buy episodes and not buy the whole season, like Telltale does with their games.
The story so far is kind of meh from my point of view, it's good but nothing extraordinary. It's good enough to keep you inside the game and click on every object just to hear Max's point of view about that thing. (at least that's what I did).
Compared to The Walking Dead and other similar games from Telltale, the gameplay is pretty fluid and full of things to check out. I keep comparing these games because let's be honest. They're quite in the same genre and style.
So far, I'm hooked. I'll be buying the next episodes as well. I loved this one and can't wait to play the others :)

If you liked The Walking Dead or other Telltale products, give this one a try, you won't regret it ! :)

reviewText:
SPOILER FREE
The game from episode 1-4 is fantastic.
This game is fantastic. It looks amazing, the story has weight to it (till episode 5) and it really makes you care. It makes you feel a connection to the characters, like all story driven games should do. The writing is very charming even though it feels like it's written by some adults in a meeting room trying to appeal to the hip kids. Life is Strange is Tumblr in gamefirm.

But....
All this work and effort into your choices. All the times I sweat out of my eyeballs. Lead to this lacklustre shoehorned in of a last episode. The finale was terrible. It makes every single choice void in a matter of minutes. All this hype seemed to dissapear in a very short episode.  All the effort of me going in blind and making my own theories lead to a very predictable ending and antagonist. I simply cannot recommend the last episode.

the game is fantastic except for the last episode. 7/10

reviewText: Life is strange, sure.  Also, it's sometimes a bit disappointing no matter how many do-overs you get.\n\nA review of the game really needs to start at the ending.  After four episodes (a few hours each) of making choices, seeing consequences and constantly double-guessing yourself the game culminates in a final episode that goes completely off the rails.  Setting aside player opinions on the climax and whether or not your choices were meaningful, the ending is bogged down in lengthy cut scenes interspersed with irritating mechanics such as a maze sequence or scenes that try to turn the casual interface into a twitch game.  Your rewind" power gives you infinite attempts to get it right but timing a kick or a trip just didn't feel right.  The pacing was off as well -- one moment you're leaning back in your chair doing nothing for five minutes as people on the screen talk
hoursPlayed: I didn't have much fun for the final hours of the game.\n\nUp until that point though
voteText: Life is Strange is an interesting enough journey and occasional puzzler revolving around a teenage girl
helpfulPercent: Max
votesHelpful: who learns in a moment of crisis that she has the ability to rewind time
votesTotal: using the power to attempt to solve the mysterious happenings at her school and re-connect with her estranged best friend.  With the plot focusing on the teens
votesFunny: the dialogue is sometimes eye-rolling and Max is a bit too precious and twee for anyone's good but the story has moments of genuine pathos and the mysterious story line has its own twists.  I may be a bit too removed from my teenage days to get "hit in the feels" (as I understand the kids are saying these days) but the story kept me playing despite this not really being my preferred genre of game.\n\nGame play is usually very simple and casual: You walk around
commentsCount: items of interest get highlighted with a circle
column16: you look at or interact with them in some way.  Interlaced with this is your ability to rewind time
column17: allowing you to prevent things from happening or alter the course of a conversation by presenting new information.  Many small instances of choice pop up as you play and each chapter ends with a break down of the decisions you made (or failed to make) and how many others did the same.  It's interesting to make a seemingly obvious decision and then see that only 35% of the players thought the same way.  The art is usually attractive and visually consistent although some parts looked distracting low-res.  The mainly acoustic indie soundtrack wasn't my cup of tea but fit the overall feel of the game.\n\nUltimately
column18: I give the game a somewhat reluctant recommendation despite its unwieldy conclusion. The road to that ending was interesting enough and had enough bright moments to make it worth taking even if ending falls flat."

reviewText: One of those exceptionally great games where the story was where it truly shined, and the only thing that mattered to me. Okay, not really, I liked the girls too (hey I am a man, okay?), and being able to play the game from a girl's perspective, once for the obvious curiosity towards girls (okay I'll stop now, I promise!), but most importantly for seeing how cruel people can be to women, for that it tells a great story. Okay I said that already, and sure you'd say, I've already seen a lot of movies like that already
date: so what's new?" But for once
recommended: this game takes things to the level where movies fail
hoursPlayed: besides
voteText: you still won't know everything you need to even when I add time travel or turning back time into the mix
helpfulPercent: which I love too by the way... I wish sometimes girls had that power or any other in real life too
votesHelpful: especially after this game. Actually by playing as a girl and see the world from her angle
votesTotal: you would see how right I am. This game is a message
votesFunny: a good one. It's nothing sort of a usual "thriller movie
commentsCount:
and in case you're wondering why the game starts with a big warning that you should stop playing the game something mental should happen to you (I was never really given time to read that text entirely), I don't believe in that stuff. The game is there for entertainment, and at the same time teaching you about real life, making this game a masterpiece with that so well working recipe. You just have to see the dark side of the world, in order to understand it. I believe these stuff happen anyway, and I think this game could help the next generation think twice before hurting girls. So that warning text should not stop you. Scary, or cruel, it's by far the best life simulator I've ever seen, although I'm not here to look down on Sims... Take it as an educational lesson of life. One that is well worth spending your time on. Finally, once a game that is not just about you doing nothing but increasing your chances of getting worse school grades. Yet it's nowhere near as boring as simulators like Arma. (Sorry, I had to make a comparison here.) Plus, solving puzzles is not only fun, it also makes you smarter. The game creators have set an outstanding example on how to create a great one.

Having said that, I have to say the graphics are great too, they add to the authenticity of the story, and man, have I ever got disappointed in a game using the Unreal Engine? Not ever. :) Play this game with a big enough monitor, a 5.1 sound system, and you are ready to take in a valuable experience. One that I am pretty sure you won't forget. :) So enjoy!

Edit: I left out some details intentionally, because I didn't want to tell the ending.

My advice:

My only qualm with the game was technical - when I first started it wouldn't save my progress and I ended up having to replay most of the first episode. After much troubleshooting I figured out that the game has a problem when you install steam games on a disk other than C: (I have a ssd + two hdds). You have to manually create the following folder: C:\Users\Username\Documents\My Games\Life Is Strange. Then right click on the Life Is Strange folder
commentsCount: properties
column16: and give full permissions. When you're playing and it shows the saving icon alt-tab to windows
column17: open the folder
column18: and make sure a save folder exists and it is writing a "LISSave" file in there."

reviewText:
Before Life is Strange, I've never played a game that kept me awake for hours on end.
Before Life is Strange, I've never played a game that had this much of a lasting impact on me.
Before Life is Strange, I've never played a game that really made me cry.
Before Life is Strange, I've never played a game that made me change the way I look at life.
This game is the most powerful piece of media I have ever experienced, and will forever hold a place in my heart.
EDIT:
I figured this review needed an update, just to mention that what I said here wasn't just a short-term effect of what the game did to me. Nearly a month later I still think about the game every day. The community is amazing and fun to interact with. It has completely taken over my life. Hell, I even still cry at the game. If you play this, don't expect to be able to shake it off anytime soon.

reviewText:
Life is . . . weird
Indeed. And this little work shows it in a poetic manner: with blossoming fancy and one of the most vivid depictions of human experiences and emotions I have had the pleasure of enjoying, this is a dear gem, lovingly wrought.

Here we may share the experiences of a few people in an intimate way that is quite rare in videogames: Few games are so focused on characters and emotion, while also relegating other typical details (like puzzle-solving, somewhat present in this title) to a little ornament; what is more, the remarkable elements of gameplay in the present case are so closely entwined with the themes and plots of the game, that everything is very seamless, smooth.

And so, life can be, and usually is, quite perplexing; beautiful, and dreadful; it can be so wealthy in its complexities and its many adventures that it truly is awesome: This game expresses it very eloquently and lovely.

We feel the little joys, the little thrills, the doubts and the small or great woes that last, haunt for ever, or die with a friend's shared delight; we feel the horrible depths of a human being, and a human being's trembling within, and their wonderful love, their illusions, and disillusions; we also feel the soul-rending moments, the decisions that crush you, and the tender resurrections that come sometimes; and all these hopes, and all these cruelties seemingly small, of tiny moments, that scar us, scare us, and the brief joys that grow long and feel eternized; we feel our own longings and raptures and sorrows, our own threats and our own kindness; and we feel glad or sorry for these imaginary people in the little town of Arcadia Bay, whom we could easily meet (or have already met) and maybe know, and like, and love, there, beyond our doors.

The characters in the game are believable, very detailed; they do feel alive, with memories and longings, fears and joys; their selves complex and not vanishing; they are, in short, very human. Flawed, loveable or frightening, with their happiness and their horror; loveable because flawed, perhaps; or we feel pity for them, or we know, somehow, that if someone is hurtful, they are not a mere symbol or type, no, but something has sickened their mind, long ago, even. The relationships between these creatures are represented in all their tenderness and lament.

I found Max Caulfield, whom we may call the protagonist, to be a lovely young woman: tender and dreamy, witty, with shy wings...It was very pleasant to spend the entire adventure in her company, for from each passing remark of hers, and her gestures, her artistic sensibility, and her thoughts - to all the grand emotions that touch her, and with which she must needs touch us, Max feels like a real, living person.

Visually, the game is very pretty; a bit like a painting, in spirit, at least; its visual style is in harmony with the rest of the composition. Its sounds, too, are excellent, from the ambient sounds to the voices. The script is very good: spontaneous, now light-hearted and now heart-wrenching, often whimsical and pretty much always pleasant.

The story if wonderful; so humane, above all, whatever weird things happen, and they do happen. Its twists and turns are now soft, now painful, astounding...Of course, its episodic format is remarkable: each episode takes you on such an emotional symphony that when its ending comes, with its blow rather tender or very hard, you may even cry. Now, I played this when the full game had been released (I played one episode per day) but I can imagine the mental workings of those who had to wait a couple of months for the next episode.

Playing with time, with the power of altering one's past decisions, with all the winding consequences thereof (the manifest effects, and the sublter, unsuspected ones, with the inherent paradoxes and other bewildering philosophical matters), is only one aspect among the profound topics (both lofty and quotidian, till they become intertwined) touched by the game. So much to feel and so much to think of.

The music: a perfect counterpart to the rest. Notwithstanding one's taste for this music, I reckon it enhances the emotions, accentuates them; and half the tears or half the smiles may well be due to the soundtrack.

There are some flaws, of course (notwithstanding those of a, let's say, subjective character). The ones I found most significant where certain plot inconsistencies, which I cannot discuss without spoiling the story; suffice it to say that they are small-ish details which are incoherent and vex the tale somewhat; they are minor and forgettable, whereas the whole work is very memorable, and thus not a big deal; still, they could have been corrected very easily, I am sure, and (indeed) it is striking that they came to be there in the first place.

Lastly, this piece really is a glimpse, a profound and unforgettable glimpse, into human life; not all lives, sure: some will be very far away from a reality like the one here depicted; but many of us will find one, two, or countless affinities... (some other will, doubtless, find it all very close to their own life, save for their lack of time-manipulation abilities; or, what, that too?). Some of us will feel longings, nostalgia...or what? What will you feel, have felt?

Whatever that is, I dare say that nobody will be left feeling nothing after they live this strange piece of life in the company of Max Caulfield.

But, of course, more than one person has once said: 'I am Nobody'. Now smile for the selfie...

reviewText:
So I first played this game by downloading it illegally but now thanks to humble bundle I can finaly have it for real :P
Dontnod is one of my favorite video games studios, and remember me is one of my favorite game, plus I really enjoy games like telltale's The Walking Deaf or The Wolf Among Us (two titles that I recommend btw) so this this game had to be awesome... AND OH GOD IT IS !
Life is Strange is both one of the best game I ever played and one of the best show I ever saw. The gameplay is very relaxing, if you enjoy looking around everywere to find little details or easter eggs you're gonna be amazed, and there are somme puzzles to solve (not very hard ones) that makes it even better.
(*spoiler free*)The story is completly amazing, at first I thought it would get boring but it really doesn't and I never expected anything that happened, the endings though are... well one of them sucks a little, but no worries since it's a choice you can watch both of them and make your choice :)
Every single episode is worth watching and buying (even though I didn't buy all of them yet, im planning to do so but the money's not flowing you see ^^') and they are all so good that I can't decide wich one I prefer :P
TL;DR : This game's awesome, you're gonna laugh, you're gonna cry, and you will always remember this game.

To Dontnod : PLEASE make a silent hill like game, that section where max broke time in the last episode was so awesome and scary :3 And I'm looking forward to play Vampyr too.

reviewText:
I just finished the game about 30 minutes ago and now want to write my review, even though I'm still emotionally agitated.

I think this was the best game I have ever played, because I'm still shaking. And you all can tell, cause the best games are those, who touch us and make us cry, not just make us laugh and entertain, the true masterpieces get right under our skin, straight into our hearts!

I don't even know where to start, maybe the graphics first. Optically, the game is already a beauty with its mix of realistic and comic-art graphics, the colors, the lighting and just everything, it looks so beautiful, although this is not the most important aspect of the game.
Because the most important thing about a great game is the story! And this game has maybe the greatest storytelling I have ever witnessed. You'll get thrilled from the very first minute and the journey gets more and more emotional and touching the further you get. And I can ensure you, that you will spill some tears over this story, tears of joy as well as tears of sadness, this game is just so intense, you almost can't find the words to describe it. There are so many different and difficult decisions to make, that you really have to think about them, since they more or less influence the outcome of the whole story. And some of them are really tough to make. Some decisions make you laugh, some make you angry and some even make you cry! And the story also has some big twist in store. Were partly shocking to me.
Life is Strange features also a nice Indie-soundtrack, that really fits into, cause it accompanies you and even contributes to thrill and touch you throughout the whole storyline.
And at a price of just 20 bucks for all 5 episodes (when not on sale) this is a true bargain, considering how much you get.

I honestly didn't expect the game to be so emotional and thrilling, even though I heard it is really good, but really good"  is the biggest understatement
date: that you could ever make about this masterpiece! After over 21 hours of playtime I finished this emotional journey and I'm also a bit sad
hoursPlayed: this game would last forever. But I think I will start replaying it tonight

reviewText: An episodic story-centric choice story full of choices, Life Is Strange is a great game to play if Telltale games have become a staple in your life .  The story is deep and engrossing with unexpected twists and turns in every episode which include choices that drastically impact the overall experience of the game.\n\nThe major difference between Life Is Strange and others in the genre is that the protagonist, Max, is able to rewind time at will to redo" a conversation or action.  This is not a simple rewind
hoursPlayed: herself
voteText: remembers what happened and can react or alter her actions accordingly.  For example
helpfulPercent: if Max is speaking to a fellow student
votesHelpful: that student may say something to her that she can rewind and work into the conversation without the other party being aware that they were the ones who'd fed her said information in the first place
votesTotal: albeit in another timeline.  It's an interesting mechanic and it works well as the writing is done so well in the game that even with infinite redo option for a chapter you're still never sure if you made the 'right' choice.  This feeling of unease and anxiety over your choices only intensifies as the story seems to get progressively darker as more of the underlying nature of Arcadia Bay is revealed.\n\nI highly recommend this game to fans of dramatic storytelling
votesFunny: and especially to those who enjoy the Telltale template of personalized said storytelling through player choices that alter the experience.  The plot clearly had a lot of thought put into it
commentsCount: the characters are memorable and well written
column16: and the game itself (aside from a few 'puzzle' parts that were time consuming and a bit dull) is an enjoyable experience."

reviewText: Life Is Strange drags you into a world that consumes who you are. Every choice you make, and consequence you face, will carry with you in your normal life. This game will intrique you, capture you, and horrify you when you finally see what your choices have led to. Never have I played a game so life-like, that it causes me to question who I truly am. It is absolutely worth it, to whomever may want to play it. But be careful of what exactly you are signing up for.

reviewText:
Life Is Strange is easily one of the best story driven adventure I've seen in recent years, throughout the game the choices and consequences system works really well as it effects how your story progresses.

As for the Finale, Episode 5, it is a good addition to the rest of the episode but it also feels like it takes all the choices that been made before and throw them out the window, that said, I've only played Episode 5 once and haven't seen what different choices do, especially the outcome of the final choice so I'll defer from real judgement for the time being.

Overall, LiS is an awesome game which I recommend very much to adventure gamers, new & old.

I enjoyed it very much.

reviewText:
This review is being made after finishing the WHOLE game. Might contain a few spoilers there and then but not as much. I hope this helps you with your doubt of buying the game or not
Background about the game: It's a story about a girl that is given rewind powers right after she goes back to school where she used to live and she's reunited with her best friend. The story evolves after they meet again with a lot of plot twists and surprises.  Choices matter for certain events but it doesn't affect your ending that much, you will still have to make the same decision at the end, not depending on the choices you made

What I like about this game I really enjoy playing games that are episodic and story rich, those are my type of games. This was one f the greatest games I've ever played. You get to interact with stuff in the game itself, make choices and you also have a story part to it. I would only recommend it if you like Story-rich, Choice based games if those are not your type of games, you might not like it as much.

Short list of Pros and Cons
Pros:
- Well-written story
- Choice based
- Great Graphics
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=474608759
- Difficult ending
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=546028350
- Plot twists and surprises
- Background music
- Chance to make a different choice

Cons:
- A few minor bugs
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=490333401
- Choices don't matter in the end.
-----------
Summary: As I've already said, it's a really great game but categorized to certain people as not everyone's game interests are the same. It's at a fair price and when it's on sale it's even better and a must grab. Rating 9.8/10

reviewText:
A unique, different, fun and quirky game.
+Nicely hand-drawn graphics
+The supernatural-like time manipulation mechanics are something unique and different.
+The voice acting is very well done.
+The characters are interesting and get more developed as the game continues.
+The choices you make in the game directly reflect future episodes and definitively affect the rest of the game.
+I go “oooooooooh” and “ahhhhhhh each time the game says "This action will have consequences” when I do some little mundane thing.

+/-The first licensed song in the beginning can be a little jarring.
+/-Lots of hipster lingo and references

reviewText:
The game has, so far, been giving of a really cozy feel with the very likeable and realistic characters. It's nice to to be able to really interact with so many of the characters in-game.

You play as Max Caulfield, your regular teenager, until she finds out that she can rewind time. She recently moved back to her hometown 'Arcadia Bay' to study at Blackwell Academy. Right after she discovers her power to rewind time she is also reunited with her childhood friend Chloe Price. Max keeps having these visions of a huge storm coming to and destroying Arcadia Bay.


Visuals, environment:

I really love the environment of Life is strange. The school campus, the lighthouse, Chloe's house.
It really just looks... casual, in a really good way. What makes this a super cozy game to me is the way the creators use the sun to just make every scene so beautiful with the visible sun rays (Not sure if this is what it's called...).
The graphics doesnt have to be requiring a GTX 980 to be good. Life is strange proves that. The game is ridiculously good looking without having those super sick" graphics.  I don't really know how to describe how much I love the visuals.

Visual and environment rating: 10/10 The beautiful scenes are what makes it for me.


Voice acting:

The game has a lot of good voice actors
date: but sometimes the dialogue between the characters can sound pretty awkward.\nAt some times I just don't buy it. At least the voice acting in episode 2 gets a lot better. Overall
recommended:
I still think it's good.
The mouths not syncing with the voices adds to my rating here.

Voice acting rating: 7
hoursPlayed:
5/10


Soundtrack and BGM:

The soundtrack in Life is strange is perfect as it is very "calming" and adds to the cozy feel of playing as a regular teenager. The music itself always seem to fit in with the environment you find yourself in.  I've been listening to the soundtrack non-stop since I played through the first episode.

Soundtrack rating: 9.5/10
voteText:
as I really love it.


Story:

It has really just been a lot of introduction to the story so far and we haven't really gotten that much into it. But there is a storm coming and a lot to unravel.

Story rating (thus far): 8/10

I'll get back to this rating when I've finished the game.

reviewText:
Thrilling, touching, ... Only two words to decribe this masterpiece. After finally playing all episodes I can really recommend it.

You are controlling Max, a high school student who loves taking photos. Someday she discovers that she has a gift... And the rest of the story I won't tell you. The story is very good although I sometimes miss real alternatives in some choices.

I played it with my Gamepad which was very nice. At some moments the vibration made the story more intense and choices are quickly made with the 4 buttons. I have no idea how this is done with mouse+keyboard.

Graphics are nice, sometimes I was not sure if graphic glitches were supposed due to story elements or just bugs. But this didn't matter much to my while playing it.

If you like movie-like story games, similar to Telltale-Games you have to play this, too. And if you are playing this just for achievements, they are easy to get, just follow one of those many guides. But please listen to the story ;)

reviewText:
My Review Of Life Is Strange™ By Uivo(Will be possibly be updated when episodes 4-5 are released and completed)

To be honest, I think this game is by far, one of THE best games i've played this year (so far). Life Is Strange™ has such an amazing story that even gives Telltale Games a run for their money.This game is better then anything Telltale Games has ever done. After playing the first episode I was dying for more as the story had me hooked quicker than any of Telltale's games had ever done and realised i still had two episodes to go through. Now for a list Of Pros and Cons for Life Is Strange™

Pros+
+VERYemotional and sad storyline (That leaves you wanting a whole lot more)
+Interesting characters that you feel for, and ones that make you just want to kick their ♥♥♥
+Beautiful hand-painted visuals
+Cool interaction feature
+Actions that actually have consequences when they are performed (Unlike Telltale)
+Nice, Calming soundtrack
+Interesting rewind mechanic that builds the story and world around you

Cons-
-Terrible, Terrible Lip Sync

In conclusion, Life Is Strange™ is a game every steam user should own, no questions asked, even if you don't like these kinds of games, the story could, would and should have you hooked right from the get-go. Life Is Strange™, quite possibly, is my GOTY already.

I give it 9/10

reviewText:
Thrilling, touching, ... Only two words to decribe this masterpiece. After finally playing all episodes I can really recommend it.

You are controlling Max, a high school student who loves taking photos. Someday she discovers that she has a gift... And the rest of the story I won't tell you. The story is very good although I sometimes miss real alternatives in some choices.

I played it with my Gamepad which was very nice. At some moments the vibration made the story more intense and choices are quickly made with the 4 buttons. I have no idea how this is done with mouse+keyboard.

Graphics are nice, sometimes I was not sure if graphic glitches were supposed due to story elements or just bugs. But this didn't matter much to my while playing it.

If you like movie-like story games, similar to Telltale-Games you have to play this, too. And if you are playing this just for achievements, they are easy to get, just follow one of those many guides. But please listen to the story ;)

reviewText:
Life Is Strange is one of the best story-focused games I have ever played, beating Telltale in their own game of point-and-click adventures. Do note that spoiler tags include actual spoilers for the game.

GameplayLife Is Strange is a game entirely based on the story it presents. You need to understand said story in order to get the best possible results in the game, so there is actually some skill involved. You are required to solve a mystery in the game, and keeping the whole puzzle with all its clues and questions in your head is necessary if you want to succeed.

It's main gimmick, the Rewind ability, allows the player to travel backwards in time by a limited amount, allowing you to replay conversations, in-game situations, and so on. This ability is particularly useful when you make a choice, and you want to see what the reaction of a character is to any given line of dialogue. You can't exploit this ability too much, as you are limited to only rewinding that specific scene" or level

reviewText:
Life is Strange is an episodic adventure game from Dontnod, whose previous game, Remember Me, was also its first.
In the style of most episodic games, Life is Strange relies on a choice-and-consequence narrative in which players take on the role of high school student Max Caulfield - a young woman with the power to rewind time. While the game focuses on Max's school life, it also sheds a light on her relationships and the mysterious disappearance of a local girl.

As Max, players navigate school life through a linear path, interacting with classmates, teachers and friends through choice-driven dialogue. But these decisions aren't set in stone; once a conversation is over, you can choose to rewind" time. You can relive a scenario as often as you like with no consequence
date: though your powers only allow you to back up for a set amount of time.\n\nLet's talk about Life is Strange's most obvious hook: the do-over. We get this a lot in video games
recommended: but it's mostly used as a life-saving mechanic — rewinding to avoid spikey pits
hoursPlayed: fireballs or any number of cartoonish things. With Life is Strange
voteText: Dontnod created a world in which conversation is your greatest foe. I spent a great deal of time picking a path

votesHelpful: and tumbling down the other hole. But you know what? That didn't always make it easier. Sometimes
votesTotal:
I found myself second and triple guessing my responses.

I see great things coming for this game. I recommend this game!

reviewText:
I've had the full version for 3 months now and still haven't updated this review.

It's an RPG without the RPG elements, from the company which is famous for rich stories in games. Life Is Strange isn't really a game, it's an interactive movie. Gameplay is limited to movement, rewind, and your investigative skills -- and that old statement of mine may seem weird, but it has held up as only one time in the entire game are you stripped of your ability to rewind and undo the consequence of failure. The entire package takes about 8-15 hours to complete once, depending on whether or not you try to investigate everything and read all the backstory literature on your first playthrough.

Having played through the game, I feel the creators have somewhat overhyped the importance of choice in this game. Seiken Densetsu 3 had more meaningful storyline branching. Life is Strange's story is ultimately linear, no matter if you're a paragon of virtue or a sociopath throughout the playthrough. What mid-game choices ultimately result in is do X
