reviewText:
Life is strange indeed, so is this game.


Anyone that likes to play point and click adventures should definitely read this review and will probably decide to invest some money into this game, published by Square Enix.

I bought it at greenmangaming.com with a 20% additional discount so paid 15 € for all 5 seasons.

Given the first season is not very long, still I think 5 € (reduced Steam price atm) is a fair deal.


So let's head to the game and the positive aspects:
As I am not a native speaker this game was a good lesson to polish my english language knowledge, though the language used in the game is very urban, so urbandictionary often enough helped me to understand phrases and situations much better than any Oxford dictionary would have done.
That said the language used perfectly fits the setting and their teenage slang, of course.

You play as Max, a girl that's on a college for photography / art, and just turned 18.
Very soon you will find out that you're not only an ongoing talented photographer but also have another gift:

BEING ABLE TO REWIND TIME

This adventure, unlike many many other I've played in the last 25 years, really cares about your actions and they will influence the story.
At the end of the game (Season 1) you'll get an overview that shows which path YOU actually choosed and which of the other possibilities the OTHER PLAYERS have chosen.

Based on this rating, it seems that the majority of players of Life is Strange" do have a very righteous tendency I may say - just like me. I had just one exception from the mass. Interesting to know.

Overall rated the game is a great. It has a refreshing and interesting touch
date: plus is really worth the time and money as some professional reviewers have judged.\n\nI can agree with them and I really liked the sketchy but technically modern graphics (CSQAA / FXAA) based on Unreal 4 engine and I really loved the ambient soundtrack. The characters are stereotypes but well so close to real-life
recommended:
somehow.

There were a few dislikes in this first season:
To be honest I hoped for far more decisions and it gets a bit obvious over time that the decisions sometimes can be "undone" by rewinding and sometimes not. Also in dialogues you have options but they don't really influence the game that much as the about 8-9 key situations the first season offers.

- only 9 hours playing time for the Season 1 (other said they did it in just 3 hours)
- controls on PC with a mouse are not that intuitive as it is designed for controllers / Xbox
- some people report more or less severe issues but the staff has a fast pace responding at the Steam community. I can only file one bug as Fraps does not work with the game (taking screenshots will crash the game for me)
- Graphics are okayish but bear in mind the game intentionally has a sketchy style.
- most actions are not that carefully animated (playing guitar etc.) so in terms of motion capturing I've seen better things.
- the really decisive decisions are not that numerous
hoursPlayed:
and there should be more variants in the next seasons.

But well all the criticsm is moaning on a high level.

The first season of Life is Strange is a good pick for anyone that loves a short distraction and nicely made story.
If you are sure you could fell in love by slipping into the role of a teenager with super powers
voteText: changing the outcome of a story
helpfulPercent:
then buy all seasons at once.
Otherwise just try the first season. If you don't like adventures at all - hands off.

Life is Strange deserves a 9/10

reviewText: I was totally hooked and hyped about this game from episodes 1-4. I play a lot of the Telltale games (highly recommended if you like this one), so my review isn't negative because there wasn't enough freedom or fighting or whatever. It's just that all of episode 5, especially the ending, was so, so, so bad. Avoiding spoilers, I'll just say that suspension of disbelief was not enough to fill the holes (explanation below). Overall, the game is still okay.\n\nExplanation:Was it the changes that Max made that caused the tornado, or was it the time travel itself? What about the other phenomena? If it was the time travel itself (which is possible through suspension of disbelief), then going back to allow Chloe to get shot would only make the storm worse. But at least her corpse would be safe underground from the tornado. On the other hand, it's not believable in any way that Chloe not being shot in the bathroom caused all of the following: the snow, the weird eclipse, the animals dying, and the tornado (I think I'm even leaving one out). If it just caused the storm, fine, but I won't be convinced that all of those things happened in a scientifically explicable way just because she didn't die. Another minor detail: Max's vision of the storm in ep. 1 was from the future? I thought her power was to rewind.

reviewText:
I don't often write these but I'll have to make an exception. I've invested a fair bit of time into Life is Strange, planed to even play it again once all the episodes were released. Praised it, recommended it to my friends, in my eyes this game was “Awesome”.

In many ways it is. The time traveling mechanics, the way choice-consequence is shown to the player, the story, the neat soundtrack, all of it is quite pleasant and worth the time and money. However the deal breaker is Episode 5.

I will not go into details as to avoid spoilers but lets say that episode alone rendered my 23 hour experience into dust. The choices I made in the end didn't matter, the ending comes down to a press A or B and everything else you chose or considered through the entire game is discarded because of how the story goes.

In short, I don't recommend this game because of its poor ending.
Episode 1-4 is fine and pleasant, if you're really curious play them by all means but avoid Episode 5. The ending is nasty and destructive, I understand what the writers tried to do with it but it's still hard to swallow that as a proper way of ending the game.

reviewText:
Now that I've played every episodes, I can finally give my final verdict for this game.

Life is a strange is an episodic time-travel-teen-drama-choose-your-own-adventure. The time rewind mechanic is solid; it let's you rewind as much as you want, but for a limited 'reach'. There are some puzzles, but they are really basic. No, the game is mainly focused on story. Sadly, I think it is also where the game is at is weakest.

Let's talk about the story; from the beginning, it had flaws. The lip-sync was atrocious, the dialogue was cheesier than a solid block of cheese and none of the character were particulary enjoyable, but it wasn't bad. The promise that choice mattered gave some weight to your action. As time went on, it became clear that the game just throws choice in your general direction, forget about it, then change the dialogue a tiny bit depending of your previous choice.

Like Telltale's Walking dead,  the game relies on the illusion of choice, but, unlike Telltale's Walking dead, the illusion of choice is broken relatively early. The problem is linked to time travel in general; it automaticaly nullify the stakes. Whether or not a consequence happen, if it's bad enough, it probably will be fixed with more time travel. Nothing matter; time travel will fix it.

So choices, in a game of choice, aren't important in-universe and on a technical level.

My other problem with this game, as I've mentionned before, is related to the characters. None of them are really relatable or engaging.

-There's Max, but she's so bland and constantly stating the obvious, feeling moved by her actions is hard work. She's too characterized as to serve only to represent the player, but not enough to stand on her own.

-There's Chloe, she's clearly meant to be polarizing, but since she's constantly reminding you of all the time you were not some sort of loyal servant, its becomes harder and harder to care for her. They really nailed the rebel teenager, I just don't understand why the game has decided for me that Max has to like her and that they were now somehow ''besties''.  It really woudn't be so bad if she wasn't the game's most developed character. Or if the game didn't force you to be with her 75% of the time. Or if she was ever useful in any way.

-There are other character, but they are mainly underdevelopped archetype. There's the rival with her followers, the bully, the nerd.... They rarely go beyond their initial settings.

My final problem is the ending. The whole episode 5, to be honest. I won't spoil anything, but it really fails to tie all loose ends. The core concepts of the game are given a backhanded explanation. Some parts don't feel like they belong at all.
The final decision is frankly insulting. You either have the most cliche tropes of time-travel or a straight up incomplete ending.

After episode 4, I was hesitating to recommend this game. The flaw were unavoidable, but it was still an overall nice experience. The ending left a bittersweet taste that I cannot forget.

It's a choice-driven game, except choice are meaningless.
It's a story-driven game without good characters.
It's a time-travel game that can't seem to stay consistent.
I can't recommend.

reviewText:
Below you'll find a SPOILER FREE video and written impression on the game
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9a1I1sPy0_Y

Life is Strange is a narrative driven point and click adventure game. You play as a young girl named Max, in school for photography. It does a good job at portraying modern youth but it does have a twist that you'll find out early into the game. With out saying too much that twist will play a fairly large role in the small instances of puzzle solving that's featured in episode one. You'll also be making choices through out the game and each choice will have an impact on the overall outcome.

I'll be honest, I didn't really expect to like the game to much based solely on the theme of the game. I ended up getting it because of it's low price and great looking visuals. I really do like the art design in this game. I features an almost acrylic hand painted texture style that really carries the game's aesthetic.

I'm glad I ended up getting it and playing it through. Life is Strange is well written, the characters, though typical in archetype, has a lot of depth. Both the main and supporting cast all show flaws, and strengths. Traits that may seem obvious, then get's contradicted by a story revel. It is the level of intricacies in each character that I enjoyed the most.

Overall, Life is Strange is a surprising little gem. The theme might not be for every one, but what it does it does pretty well.

Pros:
- Great art style
- Unexpected turns
- Fair payment model
- Good characters

Cons:
- The Special ability" of this game is under used
- Mechanically

reviewText:
Finally a game that takes the Telltale games formula (think both seasons of Walking Dead) and actually does it a bit differently. While it is a bit slower and less actiony, it still provides us with some choices that will make you think about them for a while - and if you don't like the outcome - you can rewind time to choose another one!

While the story is not very orignal (timetravelling - Butterfly Effect comes into mind), its presentation and atmosphere together with a set of likeable characters make it very unique. A mystery, which slowly unveils and presents us with new traces and very often shocking events, really keeps the player wanting to know what happens next. I have to admit that the choices could matter a bit more in the long run, however.

Unlike Telltale games, Life Is Strange contains more gameplay segments with actual puzzles to solve (even if they're somewhat simple) and a lot of exploration and world building via interactive objects. The sheer amount of in-game brochures, newspapers and the like is just huge!

The graphic style might not appeal to everyone, but it certainly has its charm with its bright colors. It isn't very outstanding from the technical point of view though.

I would recommend this game to people who enjoyed playing Telltale games, but also to people who enjoy a bit crazy stories. While the high-school setting can be a bit offputting to some, it would be a mistake not to give this game a chance. The devs really deserve this!

reviewText:
I like the concept of episodic games. Telltale Games' episodic efforts from 2006 onwards did their part in revitalizing the ailing adventure game genre. However, in order to reach a wider audience, the tricky, show-stopping puzzles gradually had to give room for more story-focused experiences that emphasized player choice and consequence.

A yet unsurpassed high point was reached with 2012's The Walking Dead Season One, and since then we've seen other studios start to flex their episodic muscles as well. The strongest new contender in the field is definitely Dontnod Entertainment with Life is Strange.

Life is Strange tells a refreshingly grounded story about a high school student who discovers she can turn back time. Despite featuring an apparent superpower, the scope and tone of the game are kept relatively unpretentious. Everything is happening in a small coastal town, with events unfolding in a very laidback fashion.

LiS spends a lot of time building its atmosphere, succeeding admirably. The graphics are stylized but not cartoony, with several very well framed shots (photography is one the main subjects of the game, after all) that use color to great effect. The indie soundtrack cements the tone further with several wistful coming-of-age tunes.

The ability to rewind time allows for some occasional puzzles, but relationships with other people always take precedence over other mysteries. Life is Strange features some highly memorable supporting characters that you genuinely learn to loathe or love. There are some tough decisions to make especially during the midpoint of the season, which I felt was the strongest part of the game.

As Life is Strange moved to its final act the tone got way darker with skeletons tumbling out of the closets. I totally think the game earns the progression and the groundwork is laid well, but unfortunately the scope and theme veered too far into science fiction territory for my liking. The last episode felt very fragmented, trying to accomplish too much in too little time and forcibly nudging the game to be larger-than-life.

The conclusion of the series was still satisfactory, but with a stronger home stretch Life is Strange would have had a real shot at dethroning The Walking Dead. After all is said and done, as a whole LiS stands as one of the few truly great episodic games of recent years, a story totally worth experiencing, clearly crafted with love. Telltale needs to take notes; This is what the genre needs right now.

reviewText:
Life is Strange gets better with each episode. It starts as a somewhat innocent seeming teenage-high school drama but builds layers upon layers as it progresses. A brooding, unsettling feeling is established very early on in the game. Not everything is quite right in the seemingly idyllic and sleepy Arcadia Bay, and not everyone is as they seem. Life is Strange explores the strength of friendship and the darkest depths of the human condition through the lens of an aspiring young photographer with a special gift that allows her to rewind time and try to do what we'd all like to: correct the mistakes of our past.

The game offers a tremendous amount of content to analyze and ponder in a thrilling, riveting mystery-adventure format featuring a touching coming of age story populated with interesting, multi-dimensional characters. These characters are developed naturally, rather than with clichéd exposition found in lesser narratives. Even very minor characters have the potential for interesting development depending on player interaction. These characters are clearly not only a product of their births, but also of their experiences.

Life is Strange conducts itself with minimal moralizing and recognition of the complexities of human nature. Critiques by reactionary misogynists seem to be unfounded as strong, sympathetic male characters emerge over time (somewhat dependent on player choice). All the while it explores the very real dangers and abuses women suffer by the hands of some psychotic, entitled and insecure men.

Decidedly less 'feminist' concerns such as bullying, corruption, man's ignorance and hubris towards our environment, and how society marginalizes its ill are also tackled masterfully. Topics within science and mysticism are a recurring theme and are handled in a balanced, mature manner and seemingly without much bias.

Equipped with a fantastic, fitting and seamlessly immersive soundtrack including Indie selections and original compositions from Jonathan Morali, excellent (for the most part) voice acting and a beautiful, handpainted feel to the visuals. Technical mishaps (most notably the lip syncing in earlier episodes - *now fixed in a recent patch*) have been vastly improved upon in later episodes.

While still early, this could very well be one of the greatest games ever made and is definitely one of the strongest showpieces for video games as art. The unique impact of LiS could not be replicated by any other medium and shows how interactivity is critical to the poignancy and transcendent qualities of this artform when it is at its finest.

Highly recommended

*A couple of quick notes on EP 5 that I will rewrite into the review at a later date:
+ Two emotional 'grey' endings. Somewhat 'predictable' (I prefer to say 'foreshadowed' - how else would it end?). Thankfully no cop out 'happy endings' that insult the player's intelligence with a Hitchcockian explanation of the phenomena and choices in the game (juxtapose with the ending of the Hitchcock film 'Psycho' - the psychoanalysis). Could have really used a plant influenced ending though, clearly not watering the plant and letting it die should have turned the storm into a nuclear holocaust. ;)
+ Phenomenal art direction, particularly in the nightmare / penultimate segment.
+ Themes and philosophical content remained consistently poignant (lack of taking sides on religion / science, environmental concerns etc)
- Minor quibbles with some of the antagonist's dialogue and actions near the beginning but developed well. Will probably resolve with further reflection.

So again 10/10 and we need a sequel.

reviewText:
Life is Strange is one of the best ‘experiences’ I’ve had for a long time. I say ‘experience’, because Life is Strange is a real mix between game, story and movie. They creators have taken the best things from those three things and combined them into a game where the choices you make throughout the whole story influence everything that will happen after you have made that choice. And with the power of Max, turning back small portions of time, they have given you… doubt… Did you make the right choice? Should I rewind and make a different one? What will be the effect?

Max is a typical teenager, but while witnessing the murder of a girl in the bathroom of her school, she gains the ability to rewind time and this gives her the chance to change events, minor and major ones.

The story she gets herself into goes from normal teenage drama (do people like me? Do I fit in?), to a psychological drama (the disappearance of a girl and the state of depression of another) and the end of a city because of the scariest tornado you can think of.

Choices you have to make are hard and while you think it might be the good one, you always have this nagging feeling something bad will happen because of it. And you might be right about that!

The story reminds me of the movie ‘The Butterfly Effect’ (you know, the only movie where Ashton Kutcher could actually deliver a perfect role).

I recommend people to play the game one episode at a time. I think that makes the experience even better, because you will think about the choices you have made and gives you time to really ‘feel’ the story.

I started playing as soon as episode one was released and played the game episode by episode while they were released. And I decided to write this review only after finishing the game to make sure I wasn’t biased by endings of episodes.

Now that I have finished the story I can only say it was completely worth every minute, penny, agony and doubtful moments this game has cost me. And while others might b**ch and moan about the ending, this couldn’t have gone otherwise! I think people will need some time to think about it and, like the ending of Soprano’s and the ending of the non-Hollywood cut of The Butterfly Effect, then agree that it couldn’t have gone otherwise.

Since I have started playing I haven’t been able to put this game out of my head and I haven’t been able to shut up about it in conversations with friend and co-workers. This game deserves to be game of the year and more.

Hopefully the team at Dontnod will be able to surprise us with their next project just as much as they have with Life is Strange, and no, I do not want a season two… That would be a mistake (or at least, I think it would be a mistake to try and top this one).

reviewText: I don't write reviews. I don't have the way with words to properly convey my thoughts. Even writing this now I pause and erase and try to find the right thing to say. That's probably why Max resonates with me so strongly, she echoes my own fears and doubts. This game, story, and these characters have touched me in a way no other game has. To not write a review (even as late as it has taken me to get to it) is unthinkable. If my words can inspire even one other person to feel the joy, heartache, and love I felt on this journey then i must put them out there. This game is not for everyone. You may not like it, but you owe it to yourself to give it a try.

reviewText:
Good game, worth the price x2. If you like story based games where you guide the story, this is a game for you.
Life Is Strange™ is just one of those games that you don't see often, from the developers Dontnod Entertainment[en.wikipedia.org], and published by Square Enix[en.wikipedia.org]. The game has 5 episodes, with the possibility of a season 2.

Following Maxine Caulfield, a 12th grade student at Blackwell academy, the game dialogues the strange happenings in Arcadia Bay, Oregon; one of them being Max's ability to rewind time.

This game is great, and if you arn't 100% sold, please go watch the WTF is episode from TotalBiscuit feat. Genna Bain

reviewText:
Ich hab beim ersten Teil von Life is Strange einfach mal nen Review hingeklatscht und dachte es wäre ok, nächstes Spiel..

Dann kamen die Kapitel 2-5 und ich dachte mir: Das is das beste Spiel das du bisher gespielt hast also schreib **** nochmal nen richtigen Review!

Life is Strange.
----------------------
Im ersten Kapitel denkt man, ganz cool, eine Schul-Story wie jede andere..
Doch was danach geschieht, is einfach krass..
Man kann sich (ich zumindest) so perfekt in die einzelnen Rollen hineindenken und mit ihnen mitfühlen.. 10/10

Die Story ist echt packend und mitreißend und die einzelnen Figuren ergeben eine Perfektion.

Die wichtigste Entscheidung  im spiel ist : Pencakes oder Egg and Bacon!? ♥

Ich kanns nicht oft genug sagen und ich denke einfach dass kein Review der Welt die Gefühle beschreiben kann die man in diesem Spiel erlebt.

Schnappt euch das Spiel, holt euch Taschentücher für Kapitel 5 und macht euch ran!

Gesamtbewertung 15/10  , never forget.

♥

reviewText:
English
------------
Deutsch

Video games as an art form. The best example when this happens is Life is Strange. Definitely my game of the year 2015, and alot better than the Telltale series. For my review I've waited for the release for the 5th and therefore last episode.

The story starts calmly, you get to know the characters and you're allowed to browse in the protagonists diary, learn everything about her life and hobby and take some pictures or talk with your classmates. You just try to be part of the whole typical school life we all have (or had once). Until the next episode starts and you feel like your emotions are going from 0 to 100, you have to make tough decisions no one of us wants to make and live with the consequences. Till the end you're wondering things like Why?" "How could you?" "I thought". Who's looking for difficult puzzles

reviewText:
Life is Strange is about two teenagers, Max and Chloe, who were childhood friends, coming together to solve a mystery. A girl named Rachel Amber has gone missing and Chloe is the most determined person in Arcadia Bay to find her. Meanwhile, Max keeps having visions of a tornado destroying Arcadia Bay and she also discovers that she has the power to rewind time and change actions/outcomes.

The game mechanics involve exploring various settings and making important decisions that affect the game's story. The graphics are awesome and many times very beautiful.  The soundtrack was fitting, as it features many indie music groups and artists, and Max attends Blackwell Academy, which is an prestigious art and science school.

I really enjoyed seeing diversity in this game. There were some people of color. I, personally, would've liked to have seen more than just a few people of color, but at least it isn't a completely whitewashed game. There were a few overweight characters, which is definitely a rarity. Usually, everyone is thin and perfect"-looking unless they're a villain or comic relief character. Then
recommended: there's the same-sex undertone between Max and Chloe
hoursPlayed:
and also Chloe and Rachel.

reviewText: If you're a fan of TellTale's type of gameplay, then you'll feel right at home with this remarkably entertaining game from developer Dontnod. To be honest, I didn't have a lot of interest in playing this one. So, with some trepidation, I reluctantly played it ... and I was hooked from the beginning! The animation and artwork is incredible.  The voice acting is spot-on and the writing is witty and compelling. This game is quite simply ... amazing.  Gorgeous even. And a LOT of fun. I'm looking forward to future episodes.

reviewText:
Life Is Strange is a very easy to hate game, which is why I'm glad it's receiving a lot of good reviews and I'm happy to one to the pile.

Story-driven, adventure games have always been my favourite genre and with recent titles like The Walking Dead and The Wolf Among Us, the standard has become a lot higher than it used to be.

I feel like Life Is Strange is just as good as these games, that all focus on how your choices effect the story. This one has an interesting mechanic, one you almost certainly know about, in which the main character can turn back time and undo decisions meaning you can replay conversations and change your answers. There are a couple of reasons why I like this; occasionally in TellTale games I would regret the choice pick (or accidentally select one I didn't mean to) and wouldn't want to reload my save just to go back. The second is that I like to explore as much as I can in these type of games. For example, in The Walking Dead, you pick one option and the conversation moves on whereas here, you can go back and explore, meaning you hear more dialogue and learn little extras about the characters. Also I am a huge baby who does not like upsetting fictional characters.

Speaking of which, I will be honest, the lines can occasionally be pretty cringy, especially in the first episode with a few phrases such as 'waaambulance' and 'noob' being thrown around a few times. Despite this, I really like the cast, especially since it's mostly women and am engaged enough to see where their stories go.

One thing I will say that I didn't like at first and am currently on the fence on is the mouse controls. To interact with objects, you look at them, where your cursor is placed inside a circle with icons such as interact/examine/etc. You then press down mouse 1 and drag the mouse to which you'd like to pick and at first I thought the game was broken because I couldn't figure it out. This however feels like a minor complaint and is most likely me just being dumb than the game's fault.

All I can hope for is that the ending doesn't turn bad, especially since this is a story regarding the sudden ability of time-travel.

reviewText: Where do I start? This game is one hell of an emotional roller coaster. The first two episodes pull you into this adorable teenage photographer's life and her past. The last three episodes punch you in the face with choices that will alter the timeline you currently reside on, some good some bad. They all add up to one ultimatum. An ultimatum which will crawl into your eyeballs and pull out the little tears you have because you're a manly man that doesn't cry. But you will cry. And you'll laugh. And you'll think really hard about yourself and why you care so much about a fictional character. Eventually you'll be happy again, but the feel train comes back around every so often. And feels you will have.\n\ntl;dr: 10/10 Endings could of been a little better, but I can't stop thinking about it and I am extremely confident in         saying it's the best game I ever played.

reviewText:
If you have forgotten just how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ your teenage years were, or you are a teenager having a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ time, then this game will resonate with you.  You play as Maxine Caulfield, a photography student who discovers that she has the ability to rewind time at any moment.

This indy game has spectacular graphics and reasonable, if not terribly challenging puzzles.  However, the soundtrack  composed by Jonathan Morali of the band Syd Matters, adds a very cool vibe to the whole thing.

The choice and consequence aspect of the game adds an interesting playability, especially when combined with the option of rewinding and choosing yet more options.

Recommended, if only to support indy game developers. Especially French ones.

reviewText:
Emotionally devastated. 10/10 no joke.

It begins as a simple girl-on-high-school simulator with rewind-powers. But that's bullcrap. Don't let that affect your decision on getting this game. This isn't only a game, in one of the few times that I say this, it crosses the line between just playing and seeing/influencing true art. Some characters you might wanna appeal to and some not. But is that really what you want? All is your choice and it's hella worth it. I wish there were other words to make you get this game, but there simply aren't any right ones. It was seriously hard for me to go and play this one again because I remember how much I cried the first time (several times in the story actually.) It simply WAS worth it.

Soundtrack is amazing. Voice acting makes it all feel so realistic you'll get lost between what's real and what's not. Though the graphical side of this game doesn't focus on looking authentic, it certainly does evoke many feelings. Like true art. Life is Strange stays with me forever. That I can say.

If instead of Chloe was the man I am going to marry, I might have chosen the non-existent third option - shoot myself in the head in stead of having the selfish or the good ending choice.[spoiler/]

reviewText:
Let’s begin with saying that, in my opinion, Life Is Strange is something unique, wonderful and touching.

Technically speaking it is (just) an “adventure game”, with some innovative game mechanisms and some less innovative, still good, elements; and yet, “adventure game” would be an unfair and limited definition, that would pay no justice to the real value and depth of the whole experience.

The fact is that there is great intensity in this game: it lies in the story it tells, and in the way it tells it, with a captivating plot, a well paced timing of events and often surprising twists. And there is a kind of magic in the way the game brings to life the main characters Max and Chloe, with their feelings, emotions, personal dramas, contradictions, memories, dreams, fears and choices.

Also the supporting  characters are well conceived, and they contribute, along with a high level of attention in detailing Blackwell Academy and Arcadia Bay, the places in which the story is set, to the feeling that while playing you are inside a rich and believable environment, with hints of real life happening everywhere.

From an artistic point of view the graphic style, with its “painted” colors and careful photography, is a perfect match for the nostalgic mood of the game… as is the soundtrack, which is a fantastic set of atmospheric songs, both delicate and powerful in lyrics and music, that really enhance your emotional perception of the game.

Life is Strange is a story about so many things. Just to name a few, friendship and love, choices and consequences, liberty and fate, good and evil, childhood and youth, dreams and reality, conquest and loss, who you are and who you pretend to be, happiness and despair… in other words it is a story about Life, in the deepest and richest meaning of the term.

Believe me, this is a game that will give you much, much more than you dare to expect. For you, lucky people who have yet to play Life is Strange, I do hope that you will gradually let yourself go in living the story of Max and Chloe, let your emotions flow freely… and you’ll obtain in return a richness that will stay with you for long after you’ve finished the game.

You will understand what I'm saying when you’ll get there; in the meanwhile, I am sure you will enjoy the trip.
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is simply amazing. I cannot recommend it highly enough. Seriously, it is my favourite game of all time by far. But it is hard to explain what makes Life is Strange great without spoiling all those incredible things.
To start, Life is Strange is beautiful art as much as it is a game. Visually, the hand-drawn aesthetic builds a wonderful atmosphere along with the cartoonish but charming particle effects and rich lighting.
The soundtrack also deserves recognition because it was simply fantastic.
The gameplay was focused around choices and the protagonist's ability to rewind time. This allows you to remake every choice in the game and see where all your options lead, but the rewind was limited to just the last few moments, so you must consider the future and live with the consequences of your actions later. The game has mechanics similar to that of Gone Home, where the player is free to explore and hunt for hidden clues. The world is just bursting with hidden content just waiting to be noticed and throughout the game you are encouraged to take your time and experience everything and interact with everyone.
Initially the story feels like a generic teen school drama, but don't let that put you off; it quickly spirals down somewhere deeper and darker. The game made me feel awful. More than once, too. The endings are so powerful I was raging at multiple points in the game. I was angry for a whole day after I finished the game. It hits you out of nowhere and brings out emotions like regret, guilt, and depression that you never thought video games could. Life is Strange is powerful and compelling; there is so much more to say, but anything not super vague is a major spoiler. In fact, stay away from the trailers, most reviews, and pretty much any forum about the game; they are full of spoilers. Just take my word (and the other bazillion positive reviews), and give this game a shot if you have even enjoyed any sort of adventure game and any sort of narrative, because this is the best one there is. Besides, Episode 1 is only $5 even without any sale.
Calling Life is Strange a game" almost diminishes its value; it contains beauty and themes like no other game I have experienced. I cannot recommend this higher."

reviewText:
Life Is Strange is easily one of the best games I have ever played. At the time I finished it, I wish I had never played it. I held no malice towards it, I simply wish it was not a thing that had happened to catch my eye. It hurt me. I fell in love with the characters especially, but everything about it, from the visuals to the soundtrack, was just amazing. And when it ended, I lost all of that, and it hurt. Both going back to my own disappointing life, and the memory of how my time in this one ended.

In this world, there's no turning back time. So much of Life Is Strage was about rewinding the past and changing what you didn't like for the better, but here you can only change the present. This experience was unique, even formative. After finishing this game, I wished I could go back to Arcadia Bay, and have things turn out differently. But I couldn't lie to myself like that. The scars were there to stay. I would have undone that hurt if I could, but I couldn't. And I made peace with that.

This game caused me (and my college best friend, who I tricked into playing it while I was still upset about how it ended) to question who we were, and has honestly been a big part of my recent efforts to turn my life around.

Life is Strange.

reviewText:
Let’s begin with saying that, in my opinion, Life Is Strange is something unique, wonderful and touching.

Technically speaking it is (just) an “adventure game”, with some innovative game mechanisms and some less innovative, still good, elements; and yet, “adventure game” would be an unfair and limited definition, that would pay no justice to the real value and depth of the whole experience.

The fact is that there is great intensity in this game: it lies in the story it tells, and in the way it tells it, with a captivating plot, a well paced timing of events and often surprising twists. And there is a kind of magic in the way the game brings to life the main characters Max and Chloe, with their feelings, emotions, personal dramas, contradictions, memories, dreams, fears and choices.

Also the supporting  characters are well conceived, and they contribute, along with a high level of attention in detailing Blackwell Academy and Arcadia Bay, the places in which the story is set, to the feeling that while playing you are inside a rich and believable environment, with hints of real life happening everywhere.

From an artistic point of view the graphic style, with its “painted” colors and careful photography, is a perfect match for the nostalgic mood of the game… as is the soundtrack, which is a fantastic set of atmospheric songs, both delicate and powerful in lyrics and music, that really enhance your emotional perception of the game.

Life is Strange is a story about so many things. Just to name a few, friendship and love, choices and consequences, liberty and fate, good and evil, childhood and youth, dreams and reality, conquest and loss, who you are and who you pretend to be, happiness and despair… in other words it is a story about Life, in the deepest and richest meaning of the term.

Believe me, this is a game that will give you much, much more than you dare to expect. For you, lucky people who have yet to play Life is Strange, I do hope that you will gradually let yourself go in living the story of Max and Chloe, let your emotions flow freely… and you’ll obtain in return a richness that will stay with you for long after you’ve finished the game.

You will understand what I'm saying when you’ll get there; in the meanwhile, I am sure you will enjoy the trip.

reviewText:
This game is simply amazing. I cannot recommend it highly enough. Seriously, it is my favourite game of all time by far. But it is hard to explain what makes Life is Strange great without spoiling all those incredible things.
To start, Life is Strange is beautiful art as much as it is a game. Visually, the hand-drawn aesthetic builds a wonderful atmosphere along with the cartoonish but charming particle effects and rich lighting.
The soundtrack also deserves recognition because it was simply fantastic.
The gameplay was focused around choices and the protagonist's ability to rewind time. This allows you to remake every choice in the game and see where all your options lead, but the rewind was limited to just the last few moments, so you must consider the future and live with the consequences of your actions later. The game has mechanics similar to that of Gone Home, where the player is free to explore and hunt for hidden clues. The world is just bursting with hidden content just waiting to be noticed and throughout the game you are encouraged to take your time and experience everything and interact with everyone.
Initially the story feels like a generic teen school drama, but don't let that put you off; it quickly spirals down somewhere deeper and darker. The game made me feel awful. More than once, too. The endings are so powerful I was raging at multiple points in the game. I was angry for a whole day after I finished the game. It hits you out of nowhere and brings out emotions like regret, guilt, and depression that you never thought video games could. Life is Strange is powerful and compelling; there is so much more to say, but anything not super vague is a major spoiler. In fact, stay away from the trailers, most reviews, and pretty much any forum about the game; they are full of spoilers. Just take my word (and the other bazillion positive reviews), and give this game a shot if you have even enjoyed any sort of adventure game and any sort of narrative, because this is the best one there is. Besides, Episode 1 is only $5 even without any sale.
Calling Life is Strange a game" almost diminishes its value; it contains beauty and themes like no other game I have experienced. I cannot recommend this higher."

reviewText:
Wonderful game, with a very good and engaging story, wonderful and perfectly fitting soundtrack, and a solid easy-to-get gameplay, despite some very few, not so important bugs.

The story centers on two friends - Max, an aspirant photographer; and Chloe, a young rebel who drops the school - girls who didn't see each other from the past 5 years, and who followed different paths, since one of them moved to Seattle, and the other had to struggle with the loss of her father and her best friend. Now they're together again, and the disapearence of a beautiful girl puts the two friends on a mistery case involving the Arcadia High School, his students and the whole city in an exciting time travel adventure.

The story focus on friendship, and the consequences of little actions in our human relations.
To supporting it, the game successfully bring to us a story based, choice and consequence gameplay style, where we can interact with a lot of the environment elements and characters, most of them part of the story or the choice-consequence tree.

Some choices didn't matter, leading at best at different dialogues, some environments have pointing glitches, the skip-dialogue mechanic may bug and freeze (so don't use it), but these are all the problems" you can find.

I recommend you to jump in this awesome experience prepared to play several hours at a time
recommended: because you'll get really involved by the game mood and soundtrack
hoursPlayed: like if you're watching (and playing) a good indie movie."

reviewText:
Life Is Strange is a very easy to hate game, which is why I'm glad it's receiving a lot of good reviews and I'm happy to one to the pile.

Story-driven, adventure games have always been my favourite genre and with recent titles like The Walking Dead and The Wolf Among Us, the standard has become a lot higher than it used to be.

I feel like Life Is Strange is just as good as these games, that all focus on how your choices effect the story. This one has an interesting mechanic, one you almost certainly know about, in which the main character can turn back time and undo decisions meaning you can replay conversations and change your answers. There are a couple of reasons why I like this; occasionally in TellTale games I would regret the choice pick (or accidentally select one I didn't mean to) and wouldn't want to reload my save just to go back. The second is that I like to explore as much as I can in these type of games. For example, in The Walking Dead, you pick one option and the conversation moves on whereas here, you can go back and explore, meaning you hear more dialogue and learn little extras about the characters. Also I am a huge baby who does not like upsetting fictional characters.

Speaking of which, I will be honest, the lines can occasionally be pretty cringy, especially in the first episode with a few phrases such as 'waaambulance' and 'noob' being thrown around a few times. Despite this, I really like the cast, especially since it's mostly women and am engaged enough to see where their stories go.

One thing I will say that I didn't like at first and am currently on the fence on is the mouse controls. To interact with objects, you look at them, where your cursor is placed inside a circle with icons such as interact/examine/etc. You then press down mouse 1 and drag the mouse to which you'd like to pick and at first I thought the game was broken because I couldn't figure it out. This however feels like a minor complaint and is most likely me just being dumb than the game's fault.

All I can hope for is that the ending doesn't turn bad, especially since this is a story regarding the sudden ability of time-travel.

reviewText:
'Thanks for crying!' say the credits for Episode Four of Life is Strange, replacing the traditional 'Thanks for playing!'. It's an apropos message, because I absolutely did cry. A raw, shuddering, and terribly viscous affair. Life is Strange is that kind of game. However, the subversion of 'playing' is germane in another way, which DONTNOD probably didn't intend. Because they clearly prioritized the story, and its emotional impact, over engaging gameplay. The reciprocal message encountered at the beginning of each episode declares the game to be about meaningful choice, and, at the risk of being crass, that's marketing BS.

Truthfully, the decisions you make are mostly window dressing. You will experience nearly the same story as everyone else, with minor nuance. The game only occasionally attempts to leverage its identity as a video game to its advantage, and in most cases, it is clumsy and halfhearted. The majority of puzzles are weak, usually being arbitrary in conception, and insubstantial in implementation. There are few occasions where the decisions made have real, lasting impact, and you are never given agency to act outside the narrative corridor you are forced down. This is not uncommon to certain genres, but that's not what most players felt they were promised. However, it is my belief that if you are prepared to forgive the game its shortcomings, and set your expectations appropriately, you will be rewarded with a rich, incisive, moving, and eminently worthwhile experience. If you're into that kind of thing.

The story revolves around Max Caulfield (Hannah Telle), an 18 year old girl returning to Arcadia Bay, the small Oregon town where she grew up, after having moved to Seattle five years prior. She has returned to enroll in a prestigious private High School, Blackwell, hoping to kickstart her passion for photography into a burgeoning career by enrolling in the program directed by the acclaimed artist Mark Jefferson (Derek Phillips). But Life is Strange (hah!), and it seems that God, destiny, chance, the Spirit of the Land, or the Flying Spaghetti Monster have decided Max be granted the ability to alter time, as she discovers in a moment of frightening duress.

She soon reunites with her childhood friend, Chloe (Ashly Burch), and together they begin an investigation into the disappearance of Rachel Amber, a local girl who vanished 6 months prior. But as they learn more, and Max experiments with her new powers, things only become more complicated. Who can they trust? What is the meaning of the impossible phenomena that plague the town? Who are the Prescotts, and what are they up to? Why did SquareEnix think it was a good idea to plug a terrible fourteen year old movie, in one of the most ham-fisted attempts of petulant propaganda I've ever seen?

The game is nominally a mystery, but truthfully, it's more science fiction tale, and in my estimation a damned good one. It hearkens back to a lot of the books I read growing up (it's no accident Ray Bradbury is name-dropped repeatedly), and has a lot of similarities to similar explorations of time travel, memory, or both. Touchstones include Donny Darko, Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, the Butterfly Effect, and To the Moon. It explores intriguing and provocative ideas in an intelligent way, but with a strident focus on character development.

I initially cringed at Max's character, but by the end of the game, I was deeply invested in her. If there is a benefit to Life is Strange being a video game rather than a TV show or movie, the proof is in Max. She is given personality and life by blending the intimacy of text, the expressiveness of animation, and the empathetic characterization of voice acting, while allowing you to co-habitate the space she does. You can't do all of that in any other medium, and it works well.

Her dialogue is good, but even more effective is the journal, where she writes her personal thoughts on the plot, as it develops. It's a more compelling read than a summarization of events you just experienced has any right to be. The graphic artists are able to give her character mostly through broad body language, as they simply don't have the tools for facial nuance, but it is still an effective presentation, and one that succeeds due to Telle's portrayal of Max's pain, anxiety, joy, and eventual growth. These all come together to give the game the emotional core it needs. Because you can only guide her, Max ends up as one of the stronger protagonists in gaming, simply because she has her own personality, rather than being a blank slate for the player to inhabit. There is little more bittersweet about Life is Strange than that we probably won't ever see any more Max Caulfield.

Playing Lois Lane to your Superman is Ashly Burch's Chloe, who is difficult to countenance for the first two and a half episodes. It's a tall order to present a petulant, irresponsible, and selfish teenager, and expect the average player to identify with her. Incredibly, Burch does accomplish this, persevering until  given the chance to redeem the character with some truly raw and deeply affecting performances. The end result is a character you like not just because of who she is, but of who she clearly will be. You want to watch her to grow, and achieve the great potential she has.

The rest of the cast is comprised mostly of one-note characters, such as the nerds, the jocks, the preppies, the hippies, the conservatives, the punks, etc. etc. A few stand out, like the performance of the drug dealer Frank (Daniel Bonjour), or that of Phillips' Jefferson, but even more important is the town of Arcadia Bay, represented by greasy spoons, woods both dark and adventurous, cold beaches, and comforting domiciles. I have to say that I certainly would not mind more games set in the Pacific Northwest during Fall.

The graphics are not flashy, but they are emotive, focused more on lighting, color, and mood, than verisimilitude. Very much like a movie. The sound design is especially persuasive, featuring an unusually potent implementation of diegetic music. The soundtrack was carefully selected to provide a calm, contemplative ambiance appropriate to the quiet, nostalgic, connotation most people ascribe to the Pacific Northwest. This introspective mood is closely entwined with the introverted Max, as she uses the music to center herself, or to bond with others. This gives a casual feel to the majority of the game, inviting you to set your own pace while you unravel the mysteries of Arcadia Bay.

While it would have been nice for the game to have a few more ideas on how to engage the player with meaningful interaction, I feel the story and humanity imbuing it to more than make up for this, making it easy to recommend, regardless of its flaws. However, before I finish this review, I must briefly discuss the ending. Episode Five was the dealbreaker for a lot of players, so I feel a warning is in order. Remember, your decisions do not truly matter. Do not expect they will. If you are prepared for this, perhaps you will appreciate the story as much as I have. It's not perfect, but I think it's efficacious, giving additional meaning and depth to the entirety of what came before, and completing Max's character arc. I even think it's rather clever for a game that explores the possibility of predestination to have the ending be circumscribed.

Life is Strange is not a uniformly cheerful game. It's full of loss, regret, and darkness. But darkness is only given meaning by light, and so those moments of pain and powerlessness give rise to lessons of acceptance, perseverance, and the importance of memories, good and bad. 'Don't take people for granted' the game tells you. 'Live life to the fullest.' It's a story worthy of the telling, a powerful memory in which we call can share, left to us by the creativity, imagination, emotion, and hard work of those who gifted it to us.

reviewText:
I don't usually write reviews, but just after finishing this game, it's my moral duty to do so.

This game has hands down the best story I have ever encountered in a video game. I have never seen a story more intricate, touching and rich. The fact that we can choose how the story unfolds is the best part.

PROS:

1. Best story ever seen in a video game by me.
2. Amazing characters, voice acting and plot.
3. Brilliant choice based mechanics.
4. Cool superpower.
5. Unlike most games, you will connect completely with the protagonist.
6. Absolutely phenomenal ending of each of the 5 episodes (shoutout to episode 3 and 4).
7. Soul satisfying break from other rigourous video games.
8. Can be played multiple times even after finishing the game by taking different choices.
9. Amazing visuals.

and yes,

10. Brilliant soundtrack, just like the game tag says on the store page.

CONS:

1. Lip syncing is off for majority of the dialogues in the game. (I have heard it can be fixed though)


Best 10$ I ever spent on a video game so far.

reviewText:
Life is strange.. and sometimes gaming is weird. When I think about this game I get goosebumps, and yet, I cannot really say this is the masterpiece everyone is talking about. Just to be clear, this is an awesome game, a gaming experience I'd recommend to anyone... but at least in my book, a masterpiece is something else.

Let's start with the mechanics: Life is Strange is the love child of all the Telltale games, a wonderful narrative experience but finally with a (little) bit of the good old puzzles. Nothing too hard to figure out, but it's definitely a start for all the graphic adventures fans out there. Maybe this is the step in the right direction we were all waiting for, maybe the future of graphic adventures starts here. I sure hope so. Max's power can be tricky, and the first couple of times it can be challenging to understand exactly what to do. Sadly, after that it's always the same thing.

About the setting: I hated the setting, but that's probably me, and it does not compromise the enjoyment of playing Life is Strange. Maybe I'm too old for these games, maybe I'm just an arid person, I don't know xD but I often find the game is trying way too hard to play the teenager/internet generation card, falling almost always into boring stereotypes. Or maybe it just does not resonate with me.

The story: Now this is different. The actual chain of events and the way they are fed to the player cannot be described in any other way than MAJESTIC. The narrative experience is just over the top, beautifully crafted and it flows naturally from the first frame to the last. The game tackles some of the most important and problematic issues of the newer generations, from bullying to euthanasia, and in some way even omosexuality and religion. Everything is always tasteful, even when extremely sad and making a choice becomes really hard, but to be completely honest I also feel that it never really adds anything to the table. Not that it would be a strict requirement, obviously, but then, remember what I said about masterpieces? Life is Strange succeeds 100% in creating an emotional bond between the player and the protagonists, to deliver a highly enjoyable, very well written, emotionally powerful (incredibly powerful) narrative experience.

The choices: another great thing. The game is full of choices, and even a small detail can have a huge impact down the way, creating a high re-playability value. Another big improvement from the Telltale games.

The graphics: I put the graphics in the end because I don't really care about it, generally. Graphics are nice, nothing extraordinary, technically speaking, more than once it happened to me to listen to dialogues without the model even moving its lips, but it's not that big of a deal to me. Art direction? That's a totally different matter, and Life is Strange excels in it. The game art style, the composition of the different shots, everything contributes to deliver the right vibe in every situation. A+

To make it painfully short: Garden State meets Donnie Darko meets Telltale Games.

Recommended. It's awesome.

reviewText: Where do I start? This game is one hell of an emotional roller coaster. The first two episodes pull you into this adorable teenage photographer's life and her past. The last three episodes punch you in the face with choices that will alter the timeline you currently reside on, some good some bad. They all add up to one ultimatum. An ultimatum which will crawl into your eyeballs and pull out the little tears you have because you're a manly man that doesn't cry. But you will cry. And you'll laugh. And you'll think really hard about yourself and why you care so much about a fictional character. Eventually you'll be happy again, but the feel train comes back around every so often. And feels you will have.\n\ntl;dr: 10/10 Endings could of been a little better, but I can't stop thinking about it and I am extremely confident in         saying it's the best game I ever played.

reviewText:
If you have forgotten just how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ your teenage years were, or you are a teenager having a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ time, then this game will resonate with you.  You play as Maxine Caulfield, a photography student who discovers that she has the ability to rewind time at any moment.

This indy game has spectacular graphics and reasonable, if not terribly challenging puzzles.  However, the soundtrack  composed by Jonathan Morali of the band Syd Matters, adds a very cool vibe to the whole thing.

The choice and consequence aspect of the game adds an interesting playability, especially when combined with the option of rewinding and choosing yet more options.

Recommended, if only to support indy game developers. Especially French ones.

date: a photography student in Blackwell Academy. After Max discovers that she could rewind time after saving a girl from being shot in the girl's bathroom
recommended: she tries to unravel and understand the mystery of her unique "gift". Her choices now shape the past
hoursPlayed: the present and the future.\n\nThe world of Life Is Strange is incredibly beautiful. Though its not that much of an open-world

The characters are well developed as you find yourself wondering at some times what happened to that certain character. reviewText:
Simply the best media-content I've experienced for the past several years.

Beautiful art style, fully absorbing atmosphere, excellent music, good voice acting, interesting character development, huge attention to details. And most of all - pure emotions!

A lot of present-day problems are touched in the game, so I guess everyone can find something to relate to.

And I want to thank and wish the best luck for Dontnod Entertaiment in their future projects.

reviewText:
Those who know me (you as reader most likely not) would not say I’m not a emotional or weak hearted person. Movies, series and games are usually something I enjoy to get my mind of things or to just get some rage out of my system. But this game….It learned me what a ‘emotional rollercoaster’ actually is.

In the game you play a young girl/woman by the name of Max. She is a general hipster kind of person who want to become a photographer and moved back to  her childhood town to study at Blackwell Academy. Starting at the beginning of the game, certain events will happen and you will find out that you have the power to mess with time. A interesting concept but not the greatest thing this game has to offer (Mind you the time mechanics are still very good, other things are simply even better). I will not spoil any of the story details but when you are playing you can expect to be: Gasping for air in surprise, smiling with joy to your screen and (I’ll be man enough to admit this) fight back a tear once in awhile. Those different emotions are what makes this game so amazing. The story, characters and voice acting are so well done that they will grab you, tear you along and spit you out just to do it all over again in the next episode.

I’m aware that there are movies, series and books claim to do this. I agree that there are some books and movies around that can make people think or feel certain things. However its a set story, you cannot change or alter it. You can just read or watch along and hope all will end well. This game ads the power of interaction. You will constantly have to make decisions and those will have major (and unforeseen) consequences throughout the entire game (choices from episode 1 still mather in episode 2, 3, 4, and 5). This is what truly got me and what no game or movie ever achieved before. When I finished a episode I would just be staring to the end credits, and later the menu screen. Wondering if I choose the right things and what impact those might have in the episodes to come.

As for some technical things:
The soundtrack is amazing
The art in this game is amazingly well done
Voice acting / story are 10+ (specially with the killer soundtrack)
I took about 4 hours per episode (so A total of 20 hours for the game)
Before playing this: don’t ready walkthroughs, don’t watch youtube for it, don’t go google...just play the game first and let it happen
Best to be played alone and with good sound (A good headset or some serious speakers)
DON’T play all episodes in one go. Play a episode and then wait a day or two before starting the next. Have your mind ponder about it a little and see what happens.
All in all I would say this game is a must play and in my opinion it should be game of the year.

reviewText:
I have played PC-Games since the early 90s and seldom if ever before a game has managed to touch me on an emotional level like Life is Strange did. Thus i felt compelled to write my first review for a game to help others decide if it is worth buying. If you wanna skip the different points I considered you can find my verdict at the end.

-Story (contains VERY mild spoilers)
Life is Strange follows young Max Caulfield, a student of photography at Blackwell Academy in the fictional small town of Arcadia Bay, Oregon. Confronted with a life-threatening situation she finds out that she has the power to rewind time. This ability allows her to change the outcome of many situations but is accompanied by apocalyptic visions of destruction. Reunited with an old childhood friend, Max soon finds out that under the idyllic surface of Blackwell Academy and Arcadia Bay there are darker facets.

-Gameplay
It is played in 3rd person perspective. Classic WASD for moving around, Shift for running, points of interaction (and there are plenty of them) are activated by left-clicking with the mouse and dragging towards the desired action. Pressing the right mouse button rewinds time, adding shift rewinds faster, Ctrl fast rewinds to the last point of decision.

-Visuals
Life is Strange was clearly inspired by the Telltale games like Walking Dead, The Wolf Among Us or Game Of Thrones. The difference is that Life is Strange is truly a beauty to behold. The visuals are very atmospheric, the camera angles and the lightning are top notch. I dare say it reaches a quality regarding atmosphere that is seldom found in PC gaming (mind you-it does in no way try to be photorealistic and has its own art-style).

-Audio
Voice acting is generally on a high level and satisfying. I found one minor character with a sub-par performance, however his part was so small that it didnt affect the overall experience at all. What truly shines is the excellent indie soundtrack. There are plenty of atmospheric pieces, both instrumental and vocal. I still regulary listen to the soundtrack. Even if you dont buy the game try out the soundtrack on YT.

-Pacing
Life is Strange has a slow pace, it takes its time to develop its characters and invites the player to explore the surroundings thoroughly. This is both a strong and a weak side of the game. In its best moments it allows total immersion. However, in a very few situations it deprives the necessary feel of urgency. If you come to terms with that and accept that you are supposed to play it slowly and explore you will be fine.

-Choices
Plenty of choices to make. Not all of them really do mattter much, but there a enough that really do matter. The rewind button is a nice substitute for a quicksave button. In fact you dont need to save at all, the game does this for you.

-Puzzles
Of course there are occasional puzzles to solve. Most of them are solved by observation, one or two outstayed their welcome as they stalled the progression of the story.

-Characters
In my opinion the strongest side of the game. The lead characters transport that awkward feeling of being a teenager in a plausibel manner and one quickly develops a bond. I cant remember when I last felt that attached to the main characters of a pc game. The supporting characters may at first glance look like stereotypes (the bad guy, the geek etc.) but that changes during the course of the 5 episodes. Every character shows facets that you wouldnt have expected. The stereotypical acting of some supports especially in episode 1 is almost a necessity to get acquainted with the quite numerous people that live on campus and in town. It changes in the later episodes.

-Writing
Best story I played/read in years. It is really that good. Takes its time to develop but then it hits you in the guts. What begins seemingly as a classical highschool story develops into a coming of age drama that explores the dark side of humanity, the boundaries of friendship, and asks the question how far one would go to save the people one loves.

-Verdict
Life is Strange is not a game for everyone. It takes time to develop, forces the player to take his time and explore his surroundings thoroughly if he wants to achieve the immersion necessary to truly digest this game. If you manage to get absorbed without distractions from outside and are willing to emotionally invest you will certainly have a great experience. Life is Strange is a coming-of-age drama with mystery elements that draws inspiration from movies like Donnie Darko, Butterfly Effect and Juno or David Lynchs masterpiece Twin Peaks. Catcher in the Rye bei J.D. Salinger is also among the inspirations, both protagonists even share the last name. If you know and like these you will like Life is Strange. The writing is superb, the soundtrack is fantastic and the artstyle is beautiful. It explores dark themes that some people may find disturbing but it does so in a tasteful way, never for sensationalism. I truly can recommend this game. It just worked for me and the emotional impact of certain choices and outcomes really hit hard. Probably my personal candidate for game of the year 2015.

reviewText:
The story so far up into Episode 3 is definitely one that adds to my 'favourites' book. The story is well and truly captivating and the harsh reality many of the students within the game face can be seen as sad and heartbreaking, rude and jock-ish, or funny and heartwarming.

Whilst I am waiting for episode 4 to come out, Episodes 1, 2, and 3 have all had their own shares of gut wrenching, nail biting moments. The characters are all seperate, no two of them alike, and whilst a few do follow the cliche of your typical school-like group of cliques, and yet they all work well in tandem with eachother.

The game mechanics are very nice, the plot is interesting and daunting, and I'm personally happy to say that the game runs extremely smoothly on my PC even on higher settings and ever during more detailed scenes where you would expect framerate drops. The plot-based mechanic of controlling time is also very interesting, a think I've never seen done so well in a game.

The story itself runs very linearly with sides of stories and events branching off. Whilst you will end up in similar situations, the decisions aren't deceptive in that they don't effect the game. In fact, a choice you decide to make at the very start of Episode 1 haunts your words and choices by the end of Episode 3, and decisions from Episode 1 and 2 could either make or break some key moments in Episode 3, and I've never felt so ashamed of myself for having messed up" my decision making

reviewText:
I didn't choose this game myself. I got is as a present. A present which offered me few hours of gameplay. And it was me who turned its potential into something special, my ability to trigger emotional changes. Curiosity, sympathy, surprise and disappointment. Fear, panic, grief and guilt. And especially empathy!

DONTNOD Entertainment worked hard to create this masterpiece and I believe that they did a really good job. They created something what truly has a potential. But not everyone can fully unleash it. I recommend Life is strange to everyone who might be interested in high school drama with science fiction elements. To people who don't want to take full control over the story and suppress their feelings. To people who are able to forget about their own world for a while, sit comfortably in their seats and activate their empathy mode at full power! ;)

As reaction on some of the comments full of disappointment after episode 5 I would like to say that I believe it doesn't matter how the story ends, because I/we don't really want it to end, right? We are experiencing our own small variations of the story which leads us to our final decision. The game is focused on story telling more than on choices which really matter.

But.. It's hella fun!
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm man enough to admit when a game about an introverted, prepubescent-looking teenage girl becomes the most emotionally-affecting form of entertainment I've ever consumed.  Sure, the characters suck you in, and you fall in love with Arcadia bay, but it's much bigger than that.

Life is Strange struck an emotional chord at a very deep, personal level for me. Every decision I made not only affected characters that I was invested in, but I subconciously projected these decisions onto experiences of my own past.  While these game-to-life experiences  were not anywhere close to being literally similar, they each shared an emotional theme. My journey through LiS left me in a stunned contemplation, one that I am still in days after finishing the story.

I learned some life lessons from this game, and wish I could formally thank DONTNOD for a few of the realizations it helped surface.  Life is, indeed, strange, and we just need to let go and enjoy the ride.

reviewText:
4.5/5

This is absolutely beautiful and innovative, and has fast become one of my favourite games of all time.

The 5-part episodic story set in Arcadia Bay works seamlessly from one part to the next.
From the moment you start you will be questioning your actions and making decisions that will ultimately decide the fate of your friends, your family, your teachers, enemies, and those you don't even know.
Each part of the storyline is riveting and portrayed with such love and care by the creators.
Every character is unique and totally believable - You'll all know the players, probably having met them before in your own life, like the Kate's, the Warrens, the Anna's, the Nathans, the Amy's and the David's of the world, hell, you may even be one of them.

This game is so emotional and believable because of those characters. If you had the power to change things. Would you? And would the consequence of those actions be for the good? The bad? Or the just downright chaotic?..

This game feels so much like a detective, thriller, drama, sci-fi and love story all rolled into one by all those famous novelists and you are right inside that novel, living it, breathing it.

You will laugh; you will cry; you will enjoy; you will hate; and then, you will go back and do it all again..

The graphics work so well with the game, but the soundtrack is absolutely amazing and worked so beautifully with each story (You just have to watch the trailers to see/hear what I mean).

I would say, if you are a conscientious person who has feelings and cares about your actions and others, you will love this game; If you are a person without conscience and doesn't give a rat's a** about others, then you probably aren't going to like it.
If you're not sure - purchase episode 1, and, if like me, you'll be hooked and buy the rest..

Kudo's to DONTNOD and Square Enix.. One of my best player experiences in a hell of a long time..

reviewText:
Max: The cutest girl

Chloe: The trouble maker but the best friend ever

Even though episode 5 ends the game way too fast ( I guess some financial problems with the developers? Thanks, Square Enix) but it won't change my positive evaluation of this game. 20/10 This game totally worth 20$ if you do like AVG or interested in time travel. GOTY.  上面的都是废话，买就对了。

reviewText:
This game is one of (if not the) best games I have ever played. The game is so amazing and beautiful in every way you can imagine. I have never seen a better written story in my life, and this comes from someone who practically grew up on a theatre. The characters in the game feel so real that a lot of people, me included, are having separation anxiety now that the game is over.

Not only is the story outstanding, but the game also features absolutely gorgeous sceneries that perfectly fits in to the moment. You just know that you have found yourself a beautiful game when you could take a screenshot at any moment and it would make for the perfect wallpaper. I have taken over 200 screenshots so far, and there are many photo oppertunities I have missed. Remember: always take the shot!

Pro tip: Don't just watch the game on youtube, buy the game and play it for yourself. Altough some people may feel like there isn't really a big differense, it really is. You will get so much more from the game by actually having the controlls in your own hands.

Warning: This game can make anyone very emotional. Trust me, LiS is not the innocent high school drama it may seem like in the beginning...

reviewText:
Разработчики LiS по прежнему остаются ребятами-у-которых-почти-получаются-офигенчики-но-увы

Впрочем игра мне довольно сильно понравилась, поэтому сначала о хорошем, а потом уже продолжу в свой недовольный бубнеж.

Прежде всего на пользу проекту идет без малого уникальная механика манипуляции со временем. Манипуляции эти одними отматываниями фейлов не ограничиваются, а предлагают нам порядочное количество интересных и свежих сцен, в которых мы, например выуживаем определенную информацию, а потом отматываем время назад и юзаем ее на ни о чем не подозревающей жертве. Или играемся с концептом причина-->следствие (например методом проб и ошибок избегаем потасовки). Или еще какой интересной фиговиной занимаемся.

Также у этих ребят вторую игру подряд все очень хорошо с окружением и вниманием к деталям. Тут они вообще заманьячились и создали такое себе livable space с кучей приятных деталей, каждую из которых героиня еще как нибудь прокомментирует.

Понравилась главгероиня и большое количество всяких разных второстепенных персонажей. Некоторые прям вообще милахи (например бедняга Кейт Марш), некоторые просто живые, к которым проникаешься какой-никакой симпатией со временем (например отчим Хлои).

Порой игра может порядочно так дать right in the feels (особенно мне этим конец второго эпизода и первая половина четвертого запомнились). Порой - порадовать годными твистами. В конце авторы не удержались и накрутили годной психоделики (не зря у героини имя Макс, лол).

Теперь о плохом и очень плохом.

Во первых, в игре безобразная лицевая анимация, много хуже даже теллтейловской (!!). Порой очень мешает, особенно в драматические моменты. Непонятно почему разрабы сэкономили на этом, учитывая что в целом мокап очень качественный (много лучше теллтейловских одинаковых анимаций).

Во вторых, игра порой не может определится - она кинематографичный сериал или кондовый пойнтэндклик. И поэтому происходит странное - вот у нас вовсю кипела жизнь и действо, а вот мы шаримся полчаса по помойке и ищем пять чертовых бутылок под одинаковые повторяющиеся реплики ГГ. Когда Макс раз в пятнадцатый мне сказала тут рядом где-то кострище ололо" - хотелось долго и продолжительно ругаться матом. Makes wonders to pacing.

Ну и третья (и главная) синеволосая проблема носит имя Хлоя и является вторым (если не первым) по значимости персонажем в игре. Героиня вышла какой-то откровенно противной

reviewText: OK. I really tried very much *not* to like this game, because of all the hype etc. (I'm fiercely fighting against all the overhype and exaggeration, you know.) But... it's simply great. reviewText:
TL;DR
I've played tons of games, from Commander Keen, Deus Ex and Half-Life to Mass Effect, GTA and TellTale adventures and, in my opinion, this is the most wonderful videogame of all time. Even better than Monkey Island, Half-Life, Bioshock, Mass Effect and The Talos Principle, just to name a few.

100/100 thouroughly deserved.
Still here? Scroll up and buy it but wait for Episode 5 to come out before you start playing.


A real masterpiece, the perfect example of a modern, episodic emotional adventure game.
This is going to be a very looong review but I'll try to do my best not to bore you, but to help you understand why I think this is the greatest game I have ever played. I have been playing since I was two years old, and not once I encountered a game who could make me emphasize so much with its characters that I actually ended up laughing and crying together with them.

But, first things first, the technical aspects:

Gameplay - Apparently simple, it involves one of the most efficient and believable" time-travel mechanics you will find in a videogame. One click and Max will rewind time to make different choices that actually matter with VERY different consequences and outcomes.
Graphics - Astonishing hand-drawn visuals that make you appreciate the world of LIS and its characters. It's like living in a painting by Monet or Renoir. The lighting effects are superb and the character animation is top-notch; I believe it is way better than TellTale's. All of the people in Arcadia Bay look alive
