reviewText:
EDIT 2/1/16 - I’ve changed my mind about the endings. There’s a beauty in them I didn’t see before. LiS is a lovely game full of wonderful characters and, despite how emotionally exhausting it was for me, I will always remember it fondly.

***
The first thing I said upon completing Life is Strange was, “@#^& this game. I will never ever replay it. I’m not even sure I’m happy I played it at all,” when just a few days prior I had been telling the same person how much I loved the game, and how nervous yet excited I was for the final episode….

***
Life is Strange is a journey. Episodes 1-4 will suck you in, and you’ll quickly fall in love with its setting and characters. The story will make you feel happy, sad, anxious, angry, and maybe a little bit sick sometimes. The problem is that, in the end, it feels like DONTNOD didn’t care about its own story and characters as much as you will.

(potentially vague SPOILERS ahead)

While I loved most of episode 5, it suffered from gameplay and writing issues not found in the previous episodes. It felt rushed, and a lot of the story and lore were thrown out the window. The way you come to whatever ending you get will (and has) upset a lot of people. However, I think there was a lesson DONTNOD was trying to teach us with it. Whether you appreciate this lesson or feel like it has no place in a video game is another story. I found a sort of solace in it--the sort of solace that can only be found by finally accepting reality for what it is instead of hiding from it.

That said, the endings themselves feel unbalanced and incomplete. One of them was obviously given a lot more thought and energy, but that’s not to say it’s better. It’s not. All the endings feel like a slap in the face, albeit for different reasons. You can justify them by saying “it’s about the journey”, and it is, but when you consider everything you had to go through to get there you wonder if the journey was even worth it.

(end SPOILERS)

***
Life is Strange will emotionally break you, or at least drain you, over and over again, and I can’t honestly say if it was worth it for me. Perhaps there are too many things in the story that I can personally relate to, which is why it exhausted me, and why the ending(s), especially one of them, felt so cruel and punishing.

Yes, I’m still recommending it, but it’s with some hesitation. The end may or may not ruin it for you, but there is no denying it’s still a great game. I loved the setting. I loved the characters. I loved most of the story. But I stick with what I said when I first finished it: I will never ever replay it and I’m not sure I’m happy I did at all.

This might be the most ambivalent review on Steam, but a fictional story has never left me feeling more jaded or cynical about life, or made me care less about being a good person.

reviewText:
Life Is Strange is easily one of the best games I have ever played. At the time I finished it, I wish I had never played it. I held no malice towards it, I simply wish it was not a thing that had happened to catch my eye. It hurt me. I fell in love with the characters especially, but everything about it, from the visuals to the soundtrack, was just amazing. And when it ended, I lost all of that, and it hurt. Both going back to my own disappointing life, and the memory of how my time in this one ended.

In this world, there's no turning back time. So much of Life Is Strage was about rewinding the past and changing what you didn't like for the better, but here you can only change the present. This experience was unique, even formative. After finishing this game, I wished I could go back to Arcadia Bay, and have things turn out differently. But I couldn't lie to myself like that. The scars were there to stay. I would have undone that hurt if I could, but I couldn't. And I made peace with that.

This game caused me (and my college best friend, who I tricked into playing it while I was still upset about how it ended) to question who we were, and has honestly been a big part of my recent efforts to turn my life around.

Life is Strange.

reviewText:
From the developers of Remember Me to time-travel adventure “Life is Strange”. It’s pretty big step of retrying new things. It captures real-world interactive drama, teenage school life and impressive dialogues.

Episode 1: Chrysalis
You played as Max Caulfield who returns to attend in BlackWell Academy to progress on her photography career. As you progress through the story, she finds out something strange inside as she has ability to reverse time. This ability plays major role of the story. You can rewind any past event to resolve your mistake, solve the puzzles, and change how to story should progress. The game is about collect information and use to support major choice to find out most satisfied outcome for the player. It’s like Memory Remix of Remember Me, but focus on different consequence for future episode. The overall gameplay feels very relax, there’s no pressured timer like Telltale games.

The first episode leaves my impression with world setup and character development. The old paint-like graphics, drawing like UI, and beautiful music create relaxing experience and be a “part” of Max’s journey.
Sure, there are few mistakes like lip-sync issue for most characters and some awkward dialogue which I feel out of place.
Life is Strange is amazing experience. You will enjoy with different choices, warm welcome and real world setup. This game is definitely worth to pick it and I’m looking forward for future episodes.

reviewText:
Oh boy. Life is Strange is a lovely change of pace from the usual shooty shooty stabby stabbys. I write this review just after completing the third episode and I have to say I have had my moneys worth already!

I would recommend this game if you enjoy a slow-paced game that is story rich with a wide variety of characters. If you're looking for constant action, look elsewhere.

To summarise what the game entails, you play as a student at Blackwell Academy called Max. We follow and control her decisions through her daily life - decisions that can have heavy consequences. Max later finds out that she has a power to rewind time and leads to lots of crazy shenanigans. Feels included.

Do I recommend this game? Duh its cool, why would I write a review for it?

(Don't buy it solely based my review though, I may have mislead you all because I enjoyed this game too much)

reviewText: HELLA YES I RECOMMEND THIS AMAZING FKN GAME! (╯°□°）╯ (Chloe: *screeches* NO EMOJI)\n\nOkay, let me just say this game is just..beautiful, k? It mght not have the MOST AMAZING GRAPHICS and the most ACCURATE lip sync, but I tell you what - it has a damn good story in my opinion. And the characters in it are flawed, but also perfect in their own ways.  This game is just too amazing. It's fun, it's sad, it's funny, it'll make you angry, it'll make you cry. It's got everything.  It is everything. I've gotten so attached to these two pixels called Max and Kate. I've gotten so attatched to their backgrounds, their voice actresses, and their design, their flaws, their devolpment over the episodes - just everything. This is one of my all time favorite games. In my list, it is right beside The Last of Us.  And TLOU is #1 on my list. This game might actually bring it down to #2, though. I'm cereal.  Also, this game has a beautiful and unique art style you don't see in most games. The surroundings and the textures are meant to look kinda similar to watercolor paint or pastel. And I just love that. I love everything about this game. If you aren't sure if you'll like it, just try to first episode yourself, okay? You might just change your mind.. <3

reviewText:
I've updated my 3D Vision fix for the final episode of Life Is Strange. 3D adds so much to a lot of games, but there some games like this one that become truly amazing in 3D... Plus I'm a perfectionist so you can be sure all my personal fixes are very high quality :)

http://helixmod.blogspot.com/2015/01/life-is-strange.html

This game is absolutely amazing. Even if you don't own a 3D setup I highly recommend playing it - it has a great story and some of the best developed characters ever in a video game. I'm so happy to be a part of this entertainment medium and seen it really grow up over the last 30 years so that a game like this can exist today. My only criticism would be the ME3 style ending... but I don't want to spoil that.

Highly recommended!

reviewText:
10/10 - A Masterpiece, A Perfect Experience!

I waited so long to play this game, pushing it aside, to play something better". After completing this game I can say that there honestly isn't much that could be better! This is bar far one of my favorite games ever!

You are an 18 year old
recommended: who figured out she had the ability to turn back time. This was a surprising twist since this game is dripping with choices to make. This time the choices really impact the stories outcome. Strap in
hoursPlayed: high school has never been so dark
voteText:
dangerous and cruel.

If you aren't sure about this game try grabbing episode 1 for cheap and give it a go. If you completely finish the first episode you will definitely want to pick up the other offerings because the story just keeps getting better and better.

There is nothing that will turn out exactly how you think; this story is carefully woven like a spider’s web. The path will unfold based on your choices. Will you rewind time or hold firm with your decisions and face the consequences.?

Worth $50 -You can pick up all (5) for $10-20!

reviewText:
This game is truly a hidden gem, if you are into Telltales games such as The Walking Dead or The Wolf Among Us then you will feel right at home playing Life Is Strange.
Just from playing the first episode I can already tell this game has so much promise, you feel so involved in the story and the whole game has a nostalgic feel to it. You can relate to the characters in certain ways and reminds you of your school years especially with noticable cliques that they have throughout the game.
Overall very good game with brilliant voice acting and a amazing soundtrack that really tugs at your heartstrings I highly recommend you go to this playlist on youtube and listen to the tracks in full.
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLaSQREdOVdpKy-_rlzy_0hVB2hHhKYC2W

reviewText: Okay, to be honest this is the first time I write a review. And the reason is, that I think Life is Strange is one of the few games nowdays that worth their price. I have never been so satisfied with 3 hours spent in front of my computer, playing the first episode. This simple story about a girl, with typical girl-ish problems, like boys, school, relationship, and choices, mixed with her supernatural time-rewinding power totally got me. It makes me think about my own life too, what would I do with a power like this, or more importantly, how should I live my own life in a way that I don't even have to use it. This is obviously not the best choice-consequence game I've ever played, but I have to admit, that this game is exeptional, and totally worth buying, and playing through. I honestly recommend it to everyone, because it's so addictive, and deep. The only downside most people mention is the bad lip-syncing, but seriously, who cares about it, if you are playing a game? Personally, I didn't even notice it until someone mentioned it in a discussion. The comic-like graphics aslo splits the community, but I just don't care :D I love every second of the game, and this was the only single-player-only product on Steam that I felt worth buying. Of course, this is only my personal opinion.

reviewText:
I was a bit disappointed at the end of the first episode because I thought it was just a teenage-drama story with some super powers. However, hearing about the different opinions about it I gave it a try and now I am really glad I did : the characters are well developed, stress and lack of understanding are omnipresent, making each decision a difficult one.
There are also many interesting elements that add something to the genre like the very complete journal, the phone, the side photos...

If you enjoy the Telltales kind of game or simply like to just follow and influence a (good) story, I recommend this game for you.

reviewText: Life is Strange is an episodic game that stars a teenager with a polaroid camera and her angsty pal, Chole. The game uses a time travel mechanic that assists you with solving puzzles around the city of Arcadia Bay. My favorite aspect of the game is the fantastic soundtrack featuring notable artists such as Alt-J, Bright Eyes and Angus & Julia Stone. The writing is pretty sub-par and I feel as if it were written by a BuzzFeed intern but nonetheless it's an enjoyable game with a few particular characters that really tug at the heart strings.\n\n7/10 got my money's worth

reviewText:
This only concerns Episode 1 for now.
I love this game so far. Immensely. It's smooth and flowing in many gameplay, animation (except for lip sync :(), controls, choices and choice making and even the new and refreshing time system. The game knows what it wants to be and achieves it better than other games of its kind at this moment can. Especially with the way it introduces such new and refreshing mechanics into this kind of standard Storydriven gameplay. It basically revolutionized it, even though it should not become the new standard, if you know what I mean.

This first episode gave me hours of enjoyment and still some replayability. I am 100% hooked to this world and story.
10/10 for sure. This is an example of a game that is loved by it's creators. This is very evident.
Worth every bit of the price.

reviewText:
This game...is unique. That's all I can say. I have split this review up and update as I play the episodes. All episode reviews are brief and have no spoilers. I'd like to address the reviews saying bad things because of lip-sync issues. Although this is not a lie, it does not affect any story if you're listening to their voices not watching their lips. This can also be expected as the developer is French, so they do not natively speak English.

Episode 1: Chrysalis
A great episode that introduces you to the mechanics and characters, giving you choices that do not really change the story in many ways. This eases you smoothly into the game I'm sure you will love and will be a favourite of your library.

Overall a 8 out of 10 as of Episode 1: Chrysalis

Episode 2: Out if Time
It starts to throw you into the rough water, forcing you to make harder choices, and the characters always make you feel guilty after you choose dramatic decisions. The ending is truly a challenge, and will require you to pick up tiny details of plot to decide which ending you receive.

Overall a 9 out of 10 as of Episode 2: Out Of Time

Episode 3: Chaos Theory
My god... this game steps up the difficulty, stuffing harder choices into your already full arms, with a shocking plot detail at the end that will give you chills to the bone. It is a truly sad ending, and I can't wait to see what happens next. Gameplay still amazing.

Overall a 10 out of 10 as of Episode 3: Chaos Theory

Episode 4: Dark Room
More of a cinematic episode, this episode has a huge plot twist at the end. A definite high point in the series. It gets you wondering how there could be another episode, then bam. A strike to the brain. Not as moving as some events in Episode 3, but still sad.

Overall a 10 out of 10 as of Episode 4: Dark Room

Episode 5: Polarized
One of the most shocking and moving finales to a series, TV or games, as long as you choose the right ending. One ending is, in my opinion, disappointing. However, there are plenty of tear jerking moments between all different characters, with some Bioshock-Infinite-style segment. Events in this game are more dark than previous episodes. More emotions are added to the mix, like love, anger and confusion. A must buy!

Overall a 10 out of 10 as of Episode 5: Polarized

I play @60fps on Highest Graphics Settings for best effect. Seriously recommended. My Build:
A8-5600k 3.6-3.9GHz quad-core APU
Gigabyte R9 270 2GB Overclock Edition
8GB Kingston HyperX RAM
ASUS A88X-GAMER Motherboard
Seagate 1TB

I hope you enjoyed reading my review!

reviewText:
Life Is Strange is simply an amazing game. It's an episodic storytelling game. Did you play the walking dead? Toss that piece of ♥♥♥♥ in the trash. Life Is Strange has set a new industry standard

Game? Wrong word. Experience. Epoch. Genius of a storytelling device. 100/10. The next evolution of the genre of everything.

Life is strange. Buy it. Play it. Jesus H Christ on a Popsicle stick I just finished the fourth episode and I don't know what to do with myself.

I'll buy it for every one of my friends if I have to, I've never experienced anything on the level that is Life Is Strange.

This game has made me laugh, cry, angry, humiliated, pitiful, envious, and terrified.

It's left me shaking with adrenaline and just plain shaking, and the edge of my seat is pretty much vacant, it has me standing up instead.

I can't count the number of times they have wrenched my heart out of my chest, twisted it like a wet towel, and put it back in sideways. With plot twists, with characters I care about going through rough times and with moments where you wish you could have done one thing different.

The experience of a book and the experience of Life Is Strange, I've compared them previously. I've said it's almost exactly like a book. No, I'm wrong. A book could never deliver like this game has delivered. That's why I say it's the next evolution of storytelling.

We went from books to movies to video games, took everything we learned from all of that, and poured it into this experience.
voteText: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText: No offense to TellTale, but I find Life is Strange a way better episodic game than any of theirs. Every choice you make has unforseen consequences and rewards in the following episodes, while most minor choices in TellTale games only effect the current episode. The key example of this is that you can actually prevent characters from dying (not naming any names to avoid spoilers for newcomers), which is great as I find you actually have time to learn about and get attatched to all of the characters you meet (both minor and major). The storytelling of the game coupled with the great voice acting creates a world that you can immerse yourself and spend hours upon hours in without even noticing, and the constant plot twists keep you on your toes. I could go on, but I'll save everyone some time by wrapping up my review here:\nIf you're a fan of episodic games, Life is Strange is a must have.

reviewText:
I've had a hard time deciding whether to recommend this game or not, because it's overrated (storywise) but at the same time was very enjoyable up to episode 4.

I found the ending choices VERY predictable. It's actually the first thing that came to mind once it was revealed that Max can travel through time. It's the epitome of time travel cliches. Basically the moral of the story is (spoiler alert, maybe): Don't mess with time even though you have this mysterious power that we can't explain. -_-

With that said, I like Max, and I like her power. It's unique. She can only travel to certain moments caught in pictures and can only rewind a few seconds back in time to reverse immediate actions. It made the game experience very enjoyable and refreshing.

I found it extremely disappointing that my choices had absolutely no impact on the endings. Especially the ones involving Alyssa. I save her every single time and the 'butterfly' icon shows up telling me this will have an impact on later events. Where the hell exactly? That never happens. I just keep saving her over and over. What a useless character. Choices involving other character impact other events through episodes 1-4, but episode 5 just gives you the middle finger because none of that matters when the ending is only affected by the very last choice you make, and nothing else.

Spoiler alert: The 'good' ending involves you (Max) undoing all the changes you have ever created by not doing the very first 'superhero' action you have done, saving Chloe. Thus erasing all the events that took place later on including everything you've done in the first 4 episodes. Yep, nothing mattered eventually. The 'bad' ending is the same except instead of saving the world you save your punkrock sidekick and drive into the sunset (and possibly kiss if you've picked the right choices >_>) while everyone you've seen in the story is dead.

Episode 5 was the worst. It wasn't particularly bad in and of itself but since it included the ending(s), I didn't enjoy it. However I enjoyed the game thoroughly up to episode 4 (excluding a few times where I got stuck in stupid tedious uncalled for missions like the bottle collection - It might've been an excuse to force us to explore the area, but I naturally do that anyway). I can't bring myself to give this game a negative rating because I truly enjoyed the first 4 episodes. In those, you can clearly see how much your choices impact later events. Episode 5 threw all of that in the garbage with that ending.

When it comes to game design, I have to say I like the controls in this game. Using your mouse to drag to the 'look' or 'use' functions wasn't something I got the hang of quickly, but it's innovative and fits the theme of the game. Keep in mind that this is my very first storybased game. I never played games like The Walking Dead and Game of Thrones and Telltale games, so I can't compare it to them.

TL;DR:
If you're expecting some mindblowing Sci Fi themed story from this game, look elsewhere, only disappointment ahead. Otherwise, play it, for whatever other reason. It's enjoyable even if it was slightly disappointing story-wise. I'm giving it a thumbs down because it doesn't deserve all the credit it's been given especially for that half-♥♥♥♥♥ ending.

/This is the longest review I've ever written, and I have no sense of structure whatsoever, just jumbled thoughts, sorry.

reviewText:
So, I played through the first three episodes on Life is Strange and it has so many extremely strong points : superb character development, realistic creepy atmospheric town, nice art style complimented by excellent use of lighting and an incredible story.

Unfortunately, some of the puzzles are cumbersome (e.g stumble about collecting 5 empty bottles) but on the other hand some of the puzzles which involve using your abilities can be quite awesome.  There is a lot to look at within the world and a lot of it won't progress the game, but there for the purpose of increasing the world immersion.  At times, checking all the items can feel a bit frustrating as most of the game is fairly slow-paced.  Some of the cut scenes I'd recommend to treat as if you are watching a movie, grab some popcorn or snacks and relax.  Make sure you're in the mood to swap between the tasks of watching and playing.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=467114369

Having said this, this is the only critism I can make, but it is one that lessened my immersion within the game at certain points.  Certainly not ruined it though.

The strong points I previously mentioned hold together a fine piece of art that occasionaly plods along, but mostly has me believing this twin-peaks type game-world really exists!

The last part of episode three was really fantastic, and now I get to wait like 3 weeks or so for the next episode.  I can't really wait.

I thoroughly enjoyed and rated The Walking Dead S1.  I think Life is Strange could be on a par with TWD S1.  I will wait until I have played all episodes to call this though :)

reviewText: Life is Strange has the shape of the game I want to play - but whether or not it ends up being the magnificent sculpture that I hope it is, is dependant upon the next four episodes yet to be released. Still, it's a strong start for Dontnod Entertainment's sophomore effort and I am cautiously, optimistically charmed by this rendering of a small Oregon seaside town. It's pretty much all plot setup for the first episode of the game: meeting all the characters, taking a walkabout the setting and getting absorbed into a world.\n\nThat said, some of the writing is a little bit awkward. A lot of a bit awkward, really. Most of it is intentional (I think) since it's a story primarily about teenagers transitioning into adulthood and all the wonderful awkwardness that period of life entails. The story keeps a whole lot of balls in the air: high school drama and the unspoken social hierarchies, rich high school kids with too much money and not enough sense, loners and the alternate crowd" who are not nearly as rebellious as they think they are
date: and all of them with private lives they keep hidden to project these "proper" images of themselves. Some (a lot) of it is perhaps a little bit straightforward (the rich ♥♥♥♥♥ turns out to be a lonely girl
recommended: the jerkass jock is a bundle of psychological issues) but it's nice to see a game that lets you explore these tiny minutiae of everyday life at a slower

If you enjoyed some of the TellTale games, this is one league above.

The game is so beautifuly crafted, the art, the music, the characters, the dialogs, everything fits. You will care for the people you meet, be happy with them, and sad... you will try to fix some situations with Max's super power by rewinding time, and then wonder if you did the right thing, and maybe go fix it again?

This game is a beautiful butterfly effect.

reviewText:
Brilliant.

What is it?  Is it a game?  Is it a movie?  Is it a modern day choose-your-own-adventure?  Is it simply art on showcase?

These are the questions that I asked myself after completing Episode 1.  After a few minutes of fiddling with the controls I quickly became accustomed to the physics.  Movement is well designed and fluid.  The controls are very natural and intuitive.

The visuals are semi-realistic with a monet-esque blur that truly transmits the aura of a dream-state.  Clearly a great deal of attention was put into the visual presentation of the story and the theme was consistent from one stage of the story to the next.  The sounds of the game from the hallway murmur to the chirping of birds outdoors was well-timed, realistic, and engaging.  The music throughout was excellent.  It fluidly merged with the visual presenation forming a cohesive whole that drove the plot.

I am very impressed with the overall presenation.

I really enjoyed the story as it unfolded and look forward to the remainnig 4 episodes which I will certainly buy for myself and for my sister.  I'm glad that I finally checked out this amazing title.  Even though the total entertainment time was short I'm more than happy with the price range.

Perhaps the only drawbacks to my experience was choice limitation and a somewhat rushed plot develpoment.  It felt, to me, as if there were only two choices per event.  I would have liked to have seen more.  I also would have liked to have seen the plot develop a tad more slowly.

Anyway, I hope the early choices made form a family tree-like" divergence in final outcomes.  Since I have only com pleted episode 1 I shall have to wait and see.  I'm not going to replay any of the episodes until I have completed the entire story from start to finish but I do look forward to finding out how the different decisions impact the ultimate conculsion.

After the credits ran I was thanked for playing by the development team--that was a nice touch.  They showed me  appreciation and I will return the favor.

Well done.

Thank you for making this game.


"

reviewText:
This game is about Max, who discovers she can rewind time. She discovers that when she saves her best friend Chloe, who she hasn't seen for a few years. They both are doing research to find a fellow student (and good friend of Chloe), that has been mysteriously disappeared. They more the discover, the more in danger they become.

In this game you have to make desicions, and that may have some consequences in the future. If you rewind time and do things differently in the past, then it will alter the present and future. And that may be quite drastic. This game has five episodes, and I really liked the storyline and characters. I also thought the music they used were very suiting, and matched perfectly for the right atmosphere and mood. If they would sell a Life is Strange soundtrack I would buy it ^^

Anyway, I would recommend this game. I had lots of fun playing it, even though some parts in the game made me emotional :') It was worth it!

reviewText:
Life Is Strange really is something else. It's the first game, at least that I have played, that gets the interactive game-but-really-a-movie right. A big part of this is the rewind mechanic. It fits in perfectly with the surreal, kind of magic realism feel it's going for, but it also allows you to explore any and all choices you make without any (immediate) consequences. That's always been a big turn-off in Telltale Games: sometimes the protagonist will word things differently than you expected and you'd wish you could make a different choice. Well here you can, and it actually makes sense from the story's perspective.

The game feels like the interactive love child of Juno and Veronica Mars, with hints of The Butterfly Effect. The visual style really works for this kind of story and the audio is spot-on. Max is really fleshed out as a character and is not just a carta blanca waiting to be filled in by your imagination, which is great.

Play this game, and watch your sympathy for hipsters grow. I expect the full game to last about 15 (well filled) hours for a single, slow-pace playthrough, so take from that what you will.

Post-finale addendum

It's great. The final few episodes are one heck of a rollercoaster. All in all I can tell you that the story isn't particularly innovative, the graphics aren't the greatest, and sometimes the dialogue gets a bit too Dawson's Creek for my taste.

But beyond that the voice acting is amazing and the music is incredibly atmospheric. The characters are very believable and relatable and even though the story may not be innovative, it's done very well. I won't soon forget this little gem.

reviewText:
I normally try to go into games with an open mind - but after seeing how try-hard and edgy this was in media and such, that was actually a really hard thing to do. The entire first episode I was laughing at how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and cringe-worthy the dialogue was. It definitely improved in the second episode, but it wasn't until the third episode where it seemed like the characters actually began speaking and interacting like human beings. That's also the point where I got absolutely hooked.

The story was definitely better than I expected, and the further in you go the better it gets. Pair that with the overall solid performances, and it's pretty entertaining. Unlike similar games by other companies, choices actually matter beyond changing some dialogue. Also unlike similar games, this game actually has a game - with puzzles and ♥♥♥♥ rather than just picking dialogue and performing quick time events. The rewind feature is also cool, though at times felt tedious and tiresome. It also gets points for being absolutely gorgeous, using a (mostly) unique art style that looks great at almost all times.

The episodes are long, entertaining, and well-crafted (aside from dialogue in early episodes, as mentioned) - definitely worth their individual or bundled price tags. PLUS, IT HAS A DEMO. You don't have an excuse to not even try it out. Play the demo, and if you like it snag up the first episode. And if you like that, get the season pass.

reviewText:
Think a mixture of Steins Gate X Veronica Mars X Donnie Darko (a bit).

Life is Strange is increasingly becoming one of my favourite games. If you're a big fan of Telltale games, Life is Strange is definitely worth checking out. As much as I love Telltale, this game allows the choices we make to actually have an impact on story, which a few of the Telltale games do fall short on. Whether there is alternative endings for the choices we make is still unclear. (I have a feeling there will be but who knows. I do hope there are alternative endings)

The game feels so cinematic. From the soundtrack, to the way they create each cutscene in the story (the shots/cinematography really make it feel like you're watching a film). The vibe from the game is essentially a highschool indie film. Yes, the characters revolve around teenagers and a bit of highschool drama, but being an adult myself, I don't feel like it takes the appeal away.

EDIT:  I 110% stand by what I say above, and I have to add that the latest episode is amazing. The way the game has allowed us to become a part of the story with the discovery of mysteries is brilliant and we really do feel emotionally involved when everything connects in the end. Ok bye.

reviewText:
It took me forever to finally play Life is Strange, but man I'm glad I did. I can say that this is my personal pick for Game of the Year 2015. I avoided every YouTube videos to prevent spoilers, so I walked in absolutely not knowing what to expect. This will be a short and unorganized review (because I suck at writing reviews) and I'll try to keep it spoiler free.

First things first, I gotta get it outta the way. I absolutely love the artistic style of this game. As a person who loves art and knows a little bit about photography it's great to see the amazing shots during the cutscenes and the game's use of depth of field. Every photo that you look at are beautifully hand painted. The game overall is just gorgeous to look at.

The beginning of Episode 1 started off pretty slow, but that's to be pretty much expected, so that wasn't a big deal. I was being introduced to a majority of the main characters. A couple of minutes in and I already like the main character. First thing that I do notice and like is how well the game puts the player in this school atmosphere. I felt like I was a part of the class.

Episode 2: Probably my favorite episode and most hated episode overall, probably due to it being mostly about my favorite character in the game. I have never felt so nervous and tense in a while from a video game. But I'm happy with the result that I received. So, why do I also hate this episode? ♥♥♥♥ the bottle sequence! That part was tedious, stupid and it took me forever to find all of them.

Episode 3: I WAS EATING THOSE BEANS! But seriously, don't mess with Frank and his beans. I was pretty mixed on this episode. But of course, the ending got me again. Man... ♥♥♥♥ rewind powers.

Episode 4: I ♥♥♥♥ing knew it! God, I never been so ♥♥♥♥♥♥ at a character before in my life. I legit wanted to strangle the ♥♥♥♥ outta the jackass dude when I found those pictures of my favorite character. But aside from my anger at the series of events... Great episode! The beginning made me shed a tear.

Episode 5: ♥♥♥♥... (Sorry, not much can be said, you just have to play for yourselves)

My overall feelings towards the game. I absolutely loved it! Normally I don't like time traveling because that topic is always complicated as ♥♥♥♥, but I felt like the rewind mechanic was great. You telling me I get to talk ♥♥♥♥, spill your food and beer, rewind and pretend I didn't do any of that? Awesome, sign me up! But it's also interesting that I can always take back the previous choice that I've made. That alone made me really overthink my decisions. Do I want this? But maybe this would be better in the future..." I literally spent 10 minutes thinking to myself over the final choice. Also
date: another thing I loved is the fact that the game DOESN'T ♥♥♥♥ING RUSH ME TO MAKE A CHOICE. ♥♥♥♥ off Telltale

reviewText: This isn't just a game, it's a journey, it's a mind f*ck, it's a heart warmer and a heart shattering, it's an amazing gift and a broken promise. I love this game beyond a doubt, and I wish more if not all games were more like it. The whole story up to the end you can see your choices matter and have effects which ones you live with is up to you. It's deep and pulls you in, they nailed this game, it's all kinds of amazing. As I mentioned before though it is a shattered dream, because as amazing as the whole game is and I still appreciate the endings. I see where they were going with an openish end with direction so the story kind of still goes on even though it ends. However the end is only decided by your last choice which is slightly betraying. In this game you will sit there and think which choice you should take, and that's where it feels like a betrayal. Your choices do affect the whole story up until the ending, the ending is decided by one decision. On one hand the story you've experienced obviously affects your final decision, but this game is all about the big picture. So at the same time the power being all in that one choice is almost against the game's logic. I love this game, but the disconnect at the ending may be off putting.

reviewText:
Sigh. What to say about a game that decided to throw all of its potential into the trash with the very last episode?

Smart, I guess, since the game had everybody hooked with the first four episodes. But like the great Freddie Mercury sang: “It started off so well”…

First, the good.

Life is Strange is a game that depends on the relationships between characters, and the attachment that grows between player and characters. What made Life is Strange powerful for me was the coming-of-age story that it is – for teenage characters to come to terms with, and confront, difficult concepts like grief, loss and ultimately, acceptance, was great to see and executed with a bittersweet, very human touch. Chloe is a beautiful example of this – she starts out as an angry, defiant hellraiser, even with her estranged best friend, but develops into a mature, appreciative woman in a matter of days through the difficult events that are testing the residents of Arcadia Bay.

There’s a lot to explore in the quaint little coastal town of Arcadia Bay and its high school, Blackwell Academy. Through exploration, you discover more about the backstories and problems of minor characters – even if they have given you reason enough to dislike them in the main narrative. It’s easy to pass up or miss some of these opportunities, but it wouldn’t make the game quite so good if you did. DONTNOD have created a sufficiently immersive world in that regard, because it feels like something’s always simmering in the background in Arcadia Bay. Max’s adventures are not all there is to the world; some of her schoolmates are wrestling with their own demons too.

Of course, the rewinding of time is a neat little mechanic too. What makes Max’s powers poignant to me is how they mainly exist to help her grow and mature as a character. What starts out as a convenient power to have then teaches her the danger involved in defying ‘fate’ and the difficulties involved in trying to shape events that should be beyond anybody’s control. The ability to use your rewind powers in tiny situations – such as when you’ve upset an acquaintance – is a nice human touch, because who hasn’t wished they could take things back? Who hasn’t ever hoped for a chance at a do-over? Even one of the core mechanics to the game is intended to appeal emotionally to the player.

Then, the not-so-great.

At times, the twists are unnecessary and feel as if they exist purely to shock – but that I could handle, because they do still serve a purpose in the story, and in this game, the objective really seems to be the growth and development of all characters involved. Still, the dialogue and the events could’ve used a more subtle, nuanced touch at certain points, but most people would be willing to overlook these flaws because the focus has always been on the people and relationships in the narrative. One criticism has been that the dialogue can be forced and cheesy.

Finally, the dealbreaker.

I regret to say that the closing episode really killed the entire game for me. I’ll always have fondness for the first four episodes, but in Episode 5, the game tried too hard to be things that it was not and decided to shelf the minor details in favour of the main ‘story’ about Max and Chloe. Perhaps a prudent decision, but not particularly satisfying or helpful lore-wise when you remember that many potential plot points, like the overarching influence of the Prescott family, the strange popularity of the missing girl Rachel Amber, and the native American symbolism woven like a thread throughout the fabric of the game, all remained woefully underused. Even things that were directly mentioned in the game went neglected in the final episode.

Bearing in mind the deeper sufferings and motivations of even the side characters, the story’s main villain was a mere caricature by the beginning of Episode 5. The first half an hour or so was a mad rush of exposition and nonsensical ramblings of a madman. Not exactly the best use of your time and resources, DONTNOD. Then, the game takes you through a series of trippy dreamscapes – very out-of-place, considering that although Max’s powers are very magical, she’s always dealt with reality and the myriad possibilities that are constantly in flux through the narrative. The hour or so of navigating unrealistic nightmares suddenly felt very foreign and overused to me – what is with everyone who wants the player to experience some kind of bizarre psychological acid trip within the game? (Far Cry 3 boss battles anyone?) Also, it was a poor choice to spend all that time recapping the ‘crucial’ moments of the game while the episode was in progress. People forgave the atrocity of this episode precisely because of the attachments they had formed to Chloe and Max – there was definitely no need to remind us of the emotional moments again. Then, the classic Mass Effect 3 mistake. Red, Green or Blue (although there were only two choices in this game) that served to negate every single meaningful decision in this game. Perhaps it was fitting that Chloe has to remind Max that we live for the journey and not the destination – perhaps they anticipated the criticism and meant that to be a direct message for the player, because that definitely reverberated through the fourth wall and felt like a patronizing, direct slap to the face.

Sorry, DONTNOD. I’ve been known to revisit games and replay them countless times, but Episode 5 wasn’t a closer, it really was the nail in the coffin.

Rating: “Was it all wasted, all that love?” 5/10, 5 whole points taken off for the disappointing finisher. Play for the first four episodes and just write your own fanfic ending afterward.

reviewText:
It took me forever to finally play Life is Strange, but man I'm glad I did. I can say that this is my personal pick for Game of the Year 2015. I avoided every YouTube videos to prevent spoilers, so I walked in absolutely not knowing what to expect. This will be a short and unorganized review (because I suck at writing reviews) and I'll try to keep it spoiler free.

First things first, I gotta get it outta the way. I absolutely love the artistic style of this game. As a person who loves art and knows a little bit about photography it's great to see the amazing shots during the cutscenes and the game's use of depth of field. Every photo that you look at are beautifully hand painted. The game overall is just gorgeous to look at.

The beginning of Episode 1 started off pretty slow, but that's to be pretty much expected, so that wasn't a big deal. I was being introduced to a majority of the main characters. A couple of minutes in and I already like the main character. First thing that I do notice and like is how well the game puts the player in this school atmosphere. I felt like I was a part of the class.

Episode 2: Probably my favorite episode and most hated episode overall, probably due to it being mostly about my favorite character in the game. I have never felt so nervous and tense in a while from a video game. But I'm happy with the result that I received. So, why do I also hate this episode? ♥♥♥♥ the bottle sequence! That part was tedious, stupid and it took me forever to find all of them.

Episode 3: I WAS EATING THOSE BEANS! But seriously, don't mess with Frank and his beans. I was pretty mixed on this episode. But of course, the ending got me again. Man... ♥♥♥♥ rewind powers.

Episode 4: I ♥♥♥♥ing knew it! God, I never been so ♥♥♥♥♥♥ at a character before in my life. I legit wanted to strangle the ♥♥♥♥ outta the jackass dude when I found those pictures of my favorite character. But aside from my anger at the series of events... Great episode! The beginning made me shed a tear.

Episode 5: ♥♥♥♥... (Sorry, not much can be said, you just have to play for yourselves)

My overall feelings towards the game. I absolutely loved it! Normally I don't like time traveling because that topic is always complicated as ♥♥♥♥, but I felt like the rewind mechanic was great. You telling me I get to talk ♥♥♥♥, spill your food and beer, rewind and pretend I didn't do any of that? Awesome, sign me up! But it's also interesting that I can always take back the previous choice that I've made. That alone made me really overthink my decisions. Do I want this? But maybe this would be better in the future..." I literally spent 10 minutes thinking to myself over the final choice. Also
date: another thing I loved is the fact that the game DOESN'T ♥♥♥♥ING RUSH ME TO MAKE A CHOICE. ♥♥♥♥ off Telltale

I love this game beyond a doubt, and I wish more if not all games were more like it. The whole story up to the end you can see your choices matter and have effects which ones you live with is up to you. It's deep and pulls you in, they nailed this game, it's all kinds of amazing. reviewText:
Welp. Add this game to the very very short list that actually had me in tears (ps: Mass Effect is the other one)

The game starts out as a classic young adult drama with a supernatural twist. The further you get into the game, the more you will see that it goes way, way beyond that. If the first one or two episodes made you think 'meh, what's the big deal?', I strongly advise you to keep playing.

The writing is absolutely amazing, and the game perhaps contains one of the best pieces of character development I have ever seen. None of the characters you encounter in the entire story has a flat personality: They all have their own layers, faults, imperfections, which makes it entirely realistic and not at all annoying. Even the know-it-all hipster main character shows you that there is much more to it than that.

Sometimes the game gets a little bit overdramatic and emo, especially when you choose actions such as sitting on a tree trunk or a bench in the park. However, later on, this turns out to be rather valuable to your own perception of the story and the character itself.

The gameplay is a bit confusing at the start. It takes a bit to figure out what to do. After a while you pick things up much more quickly, yet the puzzles" still stay complicated enough to make you think and reconsider every now and then. There was perhaps a bit too little rewind action in the general story for my likings
date: though.\n\nThe decision-making-system is great in the sense that you can rewind and undo bad mistakes. The main character will
hoursPlayed: make you doubt whether you made the right decision in the first place. There are hardly any black or white decisions

reviewText:
GOTY 2015

At first, I wanted to keep my review like this. Two words, one line. But it's impossible.

Do you know these kind of games that lay their arm around you, pull you into a tight grip and then never let you go again? It drags you everywhere, it won't let your mind rest after playing, it wants you to know and see everything.

You might think at the start that this is just another average minor puzzle, major exploration, choice-influenced story heavy game, but believe me, this is what lifts the genre into a whole new light.

Life is Strange is THE choice-influenced story heavy game, standing out of the crowd with its brilliant writing, tricky and twisted story and characters that aren't simply good or bad.
There is never an absolute feeling of having done everything right. You will find yourself at the point of wanting to replay everything for at least a single important decision more often than you might expect. And believe me - it's worth it.

The differences of your choices carrying over into further episodes is visible, the way the other characters interacts with you and end up is based on more than just two or three things you say.
How you act defines who you are and how things will turn out in the long run.

Don't believe the impression that this was a game mainly for girls. It's not true. I have more male friends than female friends who play this and they would all agree within seconds and without hesitation.
Give this game a try, you won't regret it.

reviewText:
tl;dr:

This game is extremely well written and carefully put together to bring us one of the best story-driven game to date. The sheer amount of secrets and details which await at every corner of Arcadia Bay is mind blowing. You are missing out on the speculations and the anticipation until the next Episode if you're not already playing this before the release of Episode 5, but you're very welcome to start playing this afterwards too.

Life Is Strange is an interactive story telling game about high school drama, making decisions, drugs and alcohol, mobbing, time travel and mysteries.

I've never come across a game that told me watering my plant would have consequences. 10/10

Long Version:
Contains minor spoilers from the beginning of Episode 1 (blacked out)

Life Is StrangeLife Is Strange brings us indeed the strangest story about Life spiced up with just the right amount of fiction. You're playing as Maxine Caulfield, the main protagonist, who is an 18-year-old aspiring photographer and senior at Blackwell Academy. You've been in Seattle for a while but went back to your childhood town Arcadia Bay to study photography.

The game starts with you waking up in class after a nightmare where you're seeing a storm. Everything seems fine and boring as always. You're in middle of class and don't know the answers to the question the teacher is asking. So after class finishes you walk through the hallway to the bathroom to splash some water onto you're face. This is where the magic happens. A beautiful blue butterfly flies through the window and you get the photo opportunity of your life. The butterfly seems to glow and you feel something strange. Suddenly a boy gets into the girls restroom and is panicking about something you're about to find out. Another girl is coming in and they get into a dispute until the boy brings up his weapon and shoots. You're reaching out a hand as if it could change anything and then it happens.

The game starts with you waking up in class after a you've witnessed a girl die in the bathroom. Everything seems fine and boring as always except you're highly tensed and hoping that you've dreamed again. You're remembering and retracing everything that had happened(?) in class before and try out your newly discovered ability. Congratulations, you're a human time machine! You don't want that poor girl in the restroom to die and have to prevent the boy from shooting her. Yet again you're going to the bathroom but this time it's with other intentions. You retrace everything: splash you're face with water, a butterfly flies through the window, you take a photo and the boy comes in. This is it, you have to do something. Afraid that the boy could hurt you, you trigger the fire alarm and everyone gets out of school. You've successfully altered time. Later you find out that this girl is Chloe Elizabeth Price, your childhood friend that you've left alone when you moved to Seattle with your parents.

From now on things are getting stranger and stranger as you play through each of the chapters and episodes. Episode 1 gives you plenty of time to sit down and relax and in general just allow you to enjoy the atmosphere of the game. From the second Episode onwards, you discover a fair amount of secrets about Arcadia Bay, it's characters and secrets. The story-telling is mesmerizing and I couldn't stop playing just because I wanted to find out what it is going on in that town.

Every choice you make actually affect the past, present and future.

Characters
Max
Maxine Caulfield is the main protagonist and has the ability to manipulate time and space by rewinding and changing her choices. She loves photography and art.

Chloe
Chloe Elizabeth Price is Max's childhood friend and a rebel. She was best friends with Rachel Amber who disappeared suddenly a while ago. Chloe has blue hair and cool punk clothes. Do I have to say more?

Rachel
Rachel Dawn Amber was best friends with Chloe before she disappeared. No one knows where she went or if she is still alive. The police already stopped searching but Chloe is still desperately looking out to find her.

Nathan
Nathaniel Joshua Prescott is a student at Blackwell Academy and has rich and influential parents. Why did he meet up with Cloe and what is wrong with him?

These are just a few of the main characters and there are many more to discover in the game. The story around these characters is well written and we get to learn about both their good and bad sides. We have a fair amount of time to discover the secrets and mysteries which contribute well to the main story of the game.

Music
The music in this game fits so well with the characters and the story like no game I've ever played. It adds a ton to the atmosphere and character development as we find out about their miseries and feelings. Each and every track and it's lyrics fit perfectly to the situation and have a much deeper meaning and ongoing message to transmit if you listen cautiously. These are instant must haves as you listen to them and they stick in your heads with each mind blowing new discovery you make.

Conclusion
I've already spent a lot of time with this game and am shocked by all the little details the developer thought of. There are a lot of tiny secrets waiting in every corner of Arcadia Bay to be found by you. The concept of time traveling mixed with the case of a lost girl keep you eager to play just a little more until it's too late to get enough sleep for work/school.

This game is both emotionally and story-wise very heart touching and intense. The consequences of each decision you make are so real that you keep finding yourself rewinding time over and over again to weigh up the pros and cons of the choice you make. And you're only going to find out what happens next if you've decided and are ready to move on. This already is a lecture for life and the game offers so many more.

Life Is Strange is an interactive story telling game about high school drama, making decisions, drugs and alcohol, mobbing, time travel and mysteries.

I've never come across a game that told me watering my plant would have consequences. 10/10


If you need any help or want someone to talk please feel free to visit http://lifeisstrange.com/talk/

reviewText:
Life is strange is an interative story driven game fixated around a girl named Max Caulfield and her ability to rewind time.
Each episode the game consistenly presents interesting characters and an amazing dramatic storyline. The characters are all so diverse and well written it is easy to develope strong emotions/relate towards many of them and the game includes many difficult decisions that cause the story to be extremely thought provoking and engaging.

The games final scenes are so emotional and beautiful storywise, yet somewhat dissapointing as how the are presented. This is my only negative issue of the game, the fact that the decision to how it will end is based off only two final choices and personally this causes me to feel all others that i have made are obsolete. Regarding that fact, this game is incredible and I reccommend it.
Ps I love you Mr Jefferson.

reviewText:
Okay, so I have had a bit of a love-hate relationship with this game. But not because it's terrible, nor that its characters are written badly or anything like that; it's because I get so immersed in the story and the characters that I couldn't help but feel annoyed about ____ happening or freaking out when presented with a scary choice that could impact the story. I personally had no problem with the conclusion of the story, I saw it coming. It was meant to happen that way and I think the main reason some people probably don't like the ending is because it made them feel something, and that something was definitely not a happy feeling (at least for me), but it was predictable (there were a lot of hints to that being the ultimate choice).

If you like immersive, great storylines then get this game. If you've been through or witnessed any situation in this game then you will more than likely feel something or connect with the game in some way, I certainly did at numerous points.

For me, I was initially annoyed at the terrible teenage stereotypes that were prevalent throughout the story to begin with - but the thing is, the characters develop into complex people with their own issues, insecurities and problems. It depends on both your mindset that you have going into the game and the choices you make as to whether you reveal the multidimensional aspects of a character or not. I think the main reason as to why I was initially annoyed at the stereotypes was because it's a disappointing reflection of reality in some cases, so I guess connecting those situations to real situations probably was what annoyed me, and I think it was a good thing that it did annoy me - it meant I'd connected with the game on some level.

The game has both a great storyline and a sufficiently large, but not overwhelming, range of environments/minor storylines to explore and sometimes missing small details in these can affect the future, perhaps even without you realising. I know that in my first playthrough I had no idea about some choices you could make because they weren't obvious and required thorough exploration (which I didn't initially bother to do, because I was so sucked into the main storyline). I bought the complete season pass a while ago, I don't regret doing so. I will do it for season 2 (I believe there is a season 2 coming up) because LiS has definitely gotten me interested in this genre.

I will say this though. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ THOSE CHOICES GIVING ME HEART ATTACKS! I would literally sit there thinking oh my god what do I do" and leave the choice up for a good 5 - 10 minutes before deciding to follow through with one. Prepare to have mild strokes every time you get presented with a choice.

TL;DR: Get this game. It's good fun

reviewText:
Life Is Strange really is something else. It's the first game, at least that I have played, that gets the interactive game-but-really-a-movie right. A big part of this is the rewind mechanic. It fits in perfectly with the surreal, kind of magic realism feel it's going for, but it also allows you to explore any and all choices you make without any (immediate) consequences. That's always been a big turn-off in Telltale Games: sometimes the protagonist will word things differently than you expected and you'd wish you could make a different choice. Well here you can, and it actually makes sense from the story's perspective.

The game feels like the interactive love child of Juno and Veronica Mars, with hints of The Butterfly Effect. The visual style really works for this kind of story and the audio is spot-on. Max is really fleshed out as a character and is not just a carta blanca waiting to be filled in by your imagination, which is great.

Play this game, and watch your sympathy for hipsters grow. I expect the full game to last about 15 (well filled) hours for a single, slow-pace playthrough, so take from that what you will.

Post-finale addendum

It's great. The final few episodes are one heck of a rollercoaster. All in all I can tell you that the story isn't particularly innovative, the graphics aren't the greatest, and sometimes the dialogue gets a bit too Dawson's Creek for my taste.

But beyond that the voice acting is amazing and the music is incredibly atmospheric. The characters are very believable and relatable and even though the story may not be innovative, it's done very well. I won't soon forget this little gem.

reviewText:
Long Review: This game is many in one, for one it is beautifully crafted, for the environment is so beautiful and amazing, and the voice acting is very good, I did not cringe towards any of the voices and felt they fitted the characters very well, and the character design is nice, each major person is distinct, but many of the filler characters have many resemblances, but that isn't too bad because they aren't completely the same. Also, the story is slow at first, but once you get to Episode 3, it draws you in, keeping you more interested, and Episode 1 and 2 are more of tutorials, where they show you functions in the game, one being learnt very early on which is using dialogue heard once, going back, and saying it to them. Now would be a good time to pick it up since all Five episodes are out and playable, and throughout my play, I hadn't encountered any glitches so Dontnod has that safe for me :D:. Another thing, this is a warning, the game touches many soft subjects, for examples constant bullying, and don't pick it up if you are a person who either dislikes anything involving that, getting affended, or has experience with it and feels as if it will bring bad memories.
One amazing thing about it is the soundtrack, after each great indie song I heard, I looked it up, found the artist, listen to their songs, and enjoy all the music, the people in charge of music choice did such an amazing job in picking songs, props to them :LIS_flower:. Now I would support watching videos on it to see if it is your thing, but I would NOT support watching any videos past 2, at most, because all after that is way better going through blind. Finally, the game contains both straight and gay/lesbian kissing, so if one is against that, they may not like it, but it is optional for both so you can avoid it if wanted.

reviewText:
tl;dr:

This game is extremely well written and carefully put together to bring us one of the best story-driven game to date. The sheer amount of secrets and details which await at every corner of Arcadia Bay is mind blowing. You are missing out on the speculations and the anticipation until the next Episode if you're not already playing this before the release of Episode 5, but you're very welcome to start playing this afterwards too.

Life Is Strange is an interactive story telling game about high school drama, making decisions, drugs and alcohol, mobbing, time travel and mysteries.

I've never come across a game that told me watering my plant would have consequences. 10/10

Long Version:
Contains minor spoilers from the beginning of Episode 1 (blacked out)

Life Is StrangeLife Is Strange brings us indeed the strangest story about Life spiced up with just the right amount of fiction. You're playing as Maxine Caulfield, the main protagonist, who is an 18-year-old aspiring photographer and senior at Blackwell Academy. You've been in Seattle for a while but went back to your childhood town Arcadia Bay to study photography.

The game starts with you waking up in class after a nightmare where you're seeing a storm. Everything seems fine and boring as always. You're in middle of class and don't know the answers to the question the teacher is asking. So after class finishes you walk through the hallway to the bathroom to splash some water onto you're face. This is where the magic happens. A beautiful blue butterfly flies through the window and you get the photo opportunity of your life. The butterfly seems to glow and you feel something strange. Suddenly a boy gets into the girls restroom and is panicking about something you're about to find out. Another girl is coming in and they get into a dispute until the boy brings up his weapon and shoots. You're reaching out a hand as if it could change anything and then it happens.

The game starts with you waking up in class after a you've witnessed a girl die in the bathroom. Everything seems fine and boring as always except you're highly tensed and hoping that you've dreamed again. You're remembering and retracing everything that had happened(?) in class before and try out your newly discovered ability. Congratulations, you're a human time machine! You don't want that poor girl in the restroom to die and have to prevent the boy from shooting her. Yet again you're going to the bathroom but this time it's with other intentions. You retrace everything: splash you're face with water, a butterfly flies through the window, you take a photo and the boy comes in. This is it, you have to do something. Afraid that the boy could hurt you, you trigger the fire alarm and everyone gets out of school. You've successfully altered time. Later you find out that this girl is Chloe Elizabeth Price, your childhood friend that you've left alone when you moved to Seattle with your parents.

From now on things are getting stranger and stranger as you play through each of the chapters and episodes. Episode 1 gives you plenty of time to sit down and relax and in general just allow you to enjoy the atmosphere of the game. From the second Episode onwards, you discover a fair amount of secrets about Arcadia Bay, it's characters and secrets. The story-telling is mesmerizing and I couldn't stop playing just because I wanted to find out what it is going on in that town.

Every choice you make actually affect the past, present and future.

Characters
Max
Maxine Caulfield is the main protagonist and has the ability to manipulate time and space by rewinding and changing her choices. She loves photography and art.

Chloe
Chloe Elizabeth Price is Max's childhood friend and a rebel. She was best friends with Rachel Amber who disappeared suddenly a while ago. Chloe has blue hair and cool punk clothes. Do I have to say more?

Rachel
Rachel Dawn Amber was best friends with Chloe before she disappeared. No one knows where she went or if she is still alive. The police already stopped searching but Chloe is still desperately looking out to find her.

Nathan
Nathaniel Joshua Prescott is a student at Blackwell Academy and has rich and influential parents. Why did he meet up with Cloe and what is wrong with him?

These are just a few of the main characters and there are many more to discover in the game. The story around these characters is well written and we get to learn about both their good and bad sides. We have a fair amount of time to discover the secrets and mysteries which contribute well to the main story of the game.

Music
The music in this game fits so well with the characters and the story like no game I've ever played. It adds a ton to the atmosphere and character development as we find out about their miseries and feelings. Each and every track and it's lyrics fit perfectly to the situation and have a much deeper meaning and ongoing message to transmit if you listen cautiously. These are instant must haves as you listen to them and they stick in your heads with each mind blowing new discovery you make.

Conclusion
I've already spent a lot of time with this game and am shocked by all the little details the developer thought of. There are a lot of tiny secrets waiting in every corner of Arcadia Bay to be found by you. The concept of time traveling mixed with the case of a lost girl keep you eager to play just a little more until it's too late to get enough sleep for work/school.

This game is both emotionally and story-wise very heart touching and intense. The consequences of each decision you make are so real that you keep finding yourself rewinding time over and over again to weigh up the pros and cons of the choice you make. And you're only going to find out what happens next if you've decided and are ready to move on. This already is a lecture for life and the game offers so many more.

Life Is Strange is an interactive story telling game about high school drama, making decisions, drugs and alcohol, mobbing, time travel and mysteries.

I've never come across a game that told me watering my plant would have consequences. 10/10


If you need any help or want someone to talk please feel free to visit http://lifeisstrange.com/talk/

reviewText: This game changed me in so many ways, I can't even begin to describe. The multiple choices I've made, no matter how good the final results are, still makes me doubt. Life is Strange got me weeks thinking, creating and discarding theories. Not only the beautiful-vintage scenery or the pitch perfect soundtrack, but the story along the character that makes this game so intensely important. Why do I recommend this game to absolutely everyone? Because of all the things you can learn from it, which can be resumed in this: 'Everyone is fighting a battle you don't know about, be kind, always'. This beautiful yet painful story will teach you a lot of values you'll need for you everyday life, will teach you to make the right decisions because no matter how little they are, your decision matters. I can't even say the many things this game have tought me. Captivating, exciting, sad, overwhelming. This game is a masterpiece worth your time and money. I will make my kids play this, I will...

reviewText:
This game. Oh god this game right here. Let me explain to you the love that I have for this game in the best way I can: This game is literally everything I have ever wanted in a game. It has the best story I have ever seen in a game, and I mean that as a lover of all the telltale games, mass effect, any story rich game thats out there I have probably played and loved. As a matter of fact The Walking Dead was my favorite game of all time. WAS. Then this game happened.

The feels that this game makes you feel are unlike any feels you have felt at a game. Everything in this game is so relatable and real. The focus of this game is around friendship and average teenager life, and everyone can relate to that because they have been through it. This game is one you show to your friends because you know they can relate to it and love the game as much as you do. This is the only game that has truly messed me up so bad that I couldn't sleep because I was thinking about what I had just seen (looking at you episode 4). You may not have the same impact I did because you may not be able to relate as much as I did to this game, but there is a good chance you will.

Oh and don't even get me started on the soundtrack. The soundtrack on this game will change your music preferences. Seriously its that good. This game uses a combination of liscensed and original music and does it really, really well. I mean really well.

Now about the voice acting. Holy ♥♥♥♥ the voice actors are phenomenal. They do such a good job of displaying emotion in very pivotal scenes in the game and you can just feel it. Its so good. Not to mention the art style and the way the characters act and look work very well. Its a very immersive game in that regard. There's nothing thats going to pull you out of the immersion in the game and it does very well in episodic format. You should take this game in chunks, episode by episode, so you don't stop in the middle an episode and pull yourself out of the game. You won't get the same impact that way.

If you are thinking about getting this game, do yourself a huge favor and do. It is so worth it if you want one of the most special, beautiful, heartfelt, and real gaming experience you have ever had. That is if you like story based games and are ok with not having quick time events or heavy amount of interactivity at all times. If you are ok with that, then buy this game as soon as you possibly can. Seriously do it.

reviewText:
This game is about Max, who discovers she can rewind time. She discovers that when she saves her best friend Chloe, who she hasn't seen for a few years. They both are doing research to find a fellow student (and good friend of Chloe), that has been mysteriously disappeared. They more the discover, the more in danger they become.

In this game you have to make desicions, and that may have some consequences in the future. If you rewind time and do things differently in the past, then it will alter the present and future. And that may be quite drastic. This game has five episodes, and I really liked the storyline and characters. I also thought the music they used were very suiting, and matched perfectly for the right atmosphere and mood. If they would sell a Life is Strange soundtrack I would buy it ^^

Anyway, I would recommend this game. I had lots of fun playing it, even though some parts in the game made me emotional :') It was worth it!

reviewText:
Life is Strange has one of the most compelling stories I've seen in a video game for a long time, and the mechanic of time travel is such an unusual, yet seamless feature that really brings the story to life.

Characters are well fleshy, and the voice-acting is top-notch; even if the lip-sync can be a bit off at times.
Dialogue can get camp at times, and the slang can be grating; but overall it brings a charm and suits the game well.
The atmosphere of the game is incredibly immersive, the feel of small-town charm mixes effortlessly with the indie soundtrack; the perfect compliment to the autumnal visuals that make up Arcadia Bay.

You really feel your choices and their weight in this story, even when the story gets heavy; just don't go into this game expecting everything to be wrapped up in a neat little bow - there is a definite sense of ambiguity, and whether or not that's a dealbreaker is up to you.

reviewText: Best Global Warming Simulator Ever\n\nSeriously though, Life is Strange is one of the best adventure games that is out there. As you come to expect, it's a game that starts in a rather average pacing, yet achieves to grapple your attention with the first episode. It bears the micro-physics of an every day adventure game, yet the character development, climactic turnabouts, and the choices that will leave you in a hiatus, and make you stare at the screen hopelessly, are well-put. This is an important game that will be remembered as a milestone in the gaming industry. It's good to see that Dontnod's efforts finally put forth fruit.

reviewText: This isn't just a game, it's a journey, it's a mind f*ck, it's a heart warmer and a heart shattering, it's an amazing gift and a broken promise. I love this game beyond a doubt, and I wish more if not all games were more like it. The whole story up to the end you can see your choices matter and have effects which ones you live with is up to you. It's deep and pulls you in, they nailed this game, it's all kinds of amazing. As I mentioned before though it is a shattered dream, because as amazing as the whole game is and I still appreciate the endings. I see where they were going with an openish end with direction so the story kind of still goes on even though it ends. However the end is only decided by your last choice which is slightly betraying. In this game you will sit there and think which choice you should take, and that's where it feels like a betrayal. Your choices do affect the whole story up until the ending, the ending is decided by one decision. On one hand the story you've experienced obviously affects your final decision, but this game is all about the big picture. So at the same time the power being all in that one choice is almost against the game's logic. I love this game, but the disconnect at the ending may be off putting.

reviewText:
Very few games draw me in and immerse me enough to engage me on an emotional level. This game achieved this in spades. During my game I was drawn in to the point of being unaware of things going on around me, when I was playing I was in the game I was Max and I reacted as Max.
I unravaled a mystery written for the best noir detectives and left to a high school girl with time travel powers. None of which feels at all out of place, it's just another seed in the mystery.
I can't recommend this game enough, when Max felt pain, felt loss I felt it right along with her. When there was a victory I swelled with pride and when there was danger I was worried even if I could turn back time there was the possibility I wasn't going to be able to or wouldn't be fast enough.
10/10 - might be my game of the year.

reviewText:
Probably one of the best story games ever. You play as Max, a young photographer who returns to her hometown to attend art school. One day in class you have a vision and events unfold.

+Great atmosphere, from the music to the graphic style, you can lose yourself in this world.
+Your choices matter and can impact a lot of things later on in the game.
+This Story. You feel really attached to the characters and all the events in this game.

-You can notice the limitations of the game engine.
-Some frustrating parts of the gameplay (e.g. you want to change your last choice and need to redo whole conversations and cut scenes).


Worth every cent, probably even more. Buy this game to support the amazing developers.

WARNING: Your feels will hurt....A LOT
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I normally try to go into games with an open mind - but after seeing how try-hard and edgy this was in media and such, that was actually a really hard thing to do. The entire first episode I was laughing at how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and cringe-worthy the dialogue was. It definitely improved in the second episode, but it wasn't until the third episode where it seemed like the characters actually began speaking and interacting like human beings. That's also the point where I got absolutely hooked.

The story was definitely better than I expected, and the further in you go the better it gets. Pair that with the overall solid performances, and it's pretty entertaining. Unlike similar games by other companies, choices actually matter beyond changing some dialogue. Also unlike similar games, this game actually has a game - with puzzles and ♥♥♥♥ rather than just picking dialogue and performing quick time events. The rewind feature is also cool, though at times felt tedious and tiresome. It also gets points for being absolutely gorgeous, using a (mostly) unique art style that looks great at almost all times.

The episodes are long, entertaining, and well-crafted (aside from dialogue in early episodes, as mentioned) - definitely worth their individual or bundled price tags. PLUS, IT HAS A DEMO. You don't have an excuse to not even try it out. Play the demo, and if you like it snag up the first episode. And if you like that, get the season pass.
