reviewText: Conta a história de uma jovem fotógrafa cujo o nome é Maxine Caulfield, Max volta para a sua cidade natal Arcadia Bay após vários anos de partida para cursar em uma das melhores academias de Artes e Ciências dos EUA, a  famosa academia Blackwell. Após alguns acontecimentos incluindo a aparição de uma borboleta azul Max se vê em um pesadelo quando assisti a sua melhor amiga de infância Chloe Price ser assassinada na sua frente, nesse momento o desespero de Max é tão grande que sem querer ela acaba ganhando um poder misterioso de voltar no tempo, e acaba mudando todo o ocorrido, mas como o tio Ben fala com grandes poderes vem grandes responsabilidades"  é missão de Max  ajudar sua amiga Chloe a desvendar os mistérios

reviewText: Life Is Strange is one of the best games I have played in a long time. The story is just amazing with its characters and you choosing your path for the main character. A game like this with a mix of The Walking Dead and other amazing story choice games should turn out brilliant, when all of the episodes come out. I recommend this to anyone who is interested in this type of game. Have fun.

helpfulPercent: there is really no bad voice acting in the game. It's all far above par. In fact
votesHelpful: I'm fairly sure that there is no time that a background piece of dialog is ever repeated. The amount of detail that goes into the audio of this game is incredible. There is one example that comes to memory: a cell phone placed near a speaker makes the distinct clicking of radio wave interference. Combine that level of detail with the music choices and you're left with a nearly-perfect soundscape that immerses you completely.\n\nVisual and level design is great. As I stated earlier
votesTotal: each episode feels like a distinct piece of the story
votesFunny: even though many of the scenes occur in the same locations. Part of the reason why this is tolerable is because the world is so beautifully decorated. You can make your playthrough last twice as long if you "look" at every object (which cues the narrator to talk briefly about her thoughts on the object).\n\nAll in all

reviewText:
Think a mixture of Steins Gate X Veronica Mars X Donnie Darko (a bit).

Life is Strange is increasingly becoming one of my favourite games. If you're a big fan of Telltale games, Life is Strange is definitely worth checking out. As much as I love Telltale, this game allows the choices we make to actually have an impact on story, which a few of the Telltale games do fall short on. Whether there is alternative endings for the choices we make is still unclear. (I have a feeling there will be but who knows. I do hope there are alternative endings)

The game feels so cinematic. From the soundtrack, to the way they create each cutscene in the story (the shots/cinematography really make it feel like you're watching a film). The vibe from the game is essentially a highschool indie film. Yes, the characters revolve around teenagers and a bit of highschool drama, but being an adult myself, I don't feel like it takes the appeal away.

EDIT:  I 110% stand by what I say above, and I have to add that the latest episode is amazing. The way the game has allowed us to become a part of the story with the discovery of mysteries is brilliant and we really do feel emotionally involved when everything connects in the end. Ok bye.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
SummaryLife Is Strange™ is a game that is pretty much a interactive movie that is in 5 parts. It is very similar to the Telltale games, You have choices, and they affect the story and the world around you. but, there is a twist. You can reverse time.

You play as Max Caulfield, an eighteen year old photography senior who left her mum and dad in Seattle for the little town of Arcadia Bay, where she grew up as a kid. After she watches her childhood friend Chloe Price get shot, Max finds out she can reverse time, and she saves Chloe from dying. Max and Chloe soon find themselves in more and more trouble in Arcadia Bay as they slowly find out the truth behind the disappearence of Chloe's friend, Rachel.

Max starts to have visions of the future, a future doomsday. Max slowly learns that using her powers and changing the past can sometimes lead to a devastating future. and that her actions, will affect everyone's lives, even if it is just a simple choice.

My Opinon Of The GameThis is one of the best games I have ever played, the story was so rich, I found myself falling in-love with the characters and relating to them. It kept me wanting to play. As much as the puzzles and stuff annoyed me, it was still a good load of fun!

I will warn you, this game is very emotional. and had me in tears at certain points, I even had points in the game, where I wish i could of hugged the characters, because they looked like they needed it.

All and all. I rate this game 10/10. It truly is amazing!

reviewText:
Life is Strange in a beautifully immersive game that sends you into a whirlwind of emotions and indecisions. There will be times where you will want to pause the game and beg that you don’t have to make a decision.

This is a one-way ticket on the feels train. No stop. It’s no wonder they have an offer for support groups scrolling at the bottom of the menu page :/

Pros:
- Storyline is in-depth and beautifully crafted by the writers.
- The graphic style of the game is unique and artful.
- Characters are interesting, some more complicated than others (You’re going to want to punch a few of them in the face).
- Level of drama and tension is epic.

Cons:
- If you are a sensitive soul, this game might chew you up and spit you out at times.
- Gameplay might become tedious if played through a number of times.
- Controls can be finicky sometimes, making it difficult to finish quests.

Overall, this game is addictive and unforgettable. It covers significant themes which is relatable to all in some way or another. The protagonist is curious and the overall story is deliciously dramatic.


Side note- I think I might need to go to therapy now.

reviewText:
Alright, this game was pretty great, but after episode 4, this jumped to a solid 10/10.

I've never seen a more accurate depiction of teenage life and drama until this game came along - even though some of the terms used by the characters might seem corny or outdated, it never feels disingenuous or 'try-hard' when trying to emulate how teenagers speak and interact.

Combine this with story twists and turns, and dark elements interspersed with light-hearted teen drama really make this game a fantastic episodic thriller, with high quality, decent length episodes that really push the boundaries of storytelling in video games, and emotional connection with pixels on screen.

Love it dearly,

1000/10

reviewText:
I’m absolutely in love with Life is Strange. That status that says “Overwhelmingly Positive” is rightfully earned, and I’ll go into a bit more detail soon. I have a video review about 9 minutes long you can check out if you would actually like to see that, if not I have a written review below the video.

Written Review Below

(NO SPOILERS)
https://youtu.be/edgnxUWjgrA

You might already know this, but Life is Strange plays like the recent Telltale games that have been released (i.e The Walking Dead, Wolf Among Us) and basically improves in certain areas. I personally think this floors those games though because in this game your choices actually matter. There is no illusion of choice. There is just choice.

Choice & Consequence
The choice and consequence part of the game is very well done in my opinion. They give you plenty of time to think of what you’re going to say, which is a good thing because you know… your choices actually do matter. They also make it very obvious when what you’re about to do is very important. This makes it so that the player isn’t making choices that they weren’t even aware they were making.

Characters & Story
Biggest reasons you should get this game. I’ve seen some people confused as to what this part is like, and in all honesty just try to picture reading a choose your own adventure kind of book where there are different paths to take within a given setting. That setting, is a small town named Arcadia Bay. Up front this may look like it’s about high school drama, but it’s really about the entire town and its story through Max Caufield’s eyes. Max is a wonderful character to play as and she can be very relatable at times. Old school girl living in a modern age. Might sound pretentious when put like that but she really is an enjoyable character, she just likes what she likes. The characters you get to interact with are pieced together in a very exceptional way and it’s interesting to talk to every single one of them. This town has a history that you can learn more and more about just through conversations and hints strewn about the environment.


Setting
The setting is amazing as well. The music, graphical style, everything combined just puts together an amazing aesthetic (even with the more low res textures, which doesn’t matter in my opinion). They took common character archetypes and put them in here, but I don’t think it will be an issue for most people.

End
So yes, you should definitely buy this game, I’d recommend it over watching a Let’s Play. If you see spoilers but decide you would’ve loved the game, that’s going to be a shame. Life is Strange is the exact kind of game you really wouldn’t  want to be spoiled for you, because it could make it outright unplayable to some people. So I think you should just purchase it when you get the chance.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText: What can i say about Life is Strange?  Well, I went into this game with certain expectations, and I was blown away with the characters and story.  It's a rare gem of a game that can get you so emotionally invested in it's characters that you are thrilled and terrified about the final chapter.  Well written with real feeling characters, it may require a box of tissue or two and a few moments where you will need a break to compose yourself.  Can't reccomend this for everyone as it is beyond alot of people's ability to comprehend the deeper story, but if you're mature enough and have a basic understanding of how the world can be from the fringes this is for you.    I give it 12  ><)))*> out of a purrfect 10.

reviewText:
AFTER PLAYING THE LAST TWO EPISODES MY LIFE HAS CHANGED.
THIS ISN'T A TYPICAL HIGHSCHOOL DRAMA GAME.
Life Is Strange™ is very underrated and I'd say it's worth more.
I originally bought the full game for a whopping $20 when it first came out.
Safe to say I never regretted that decision.

Overall this game is a solid 9.5/10 for me.
The soundtrack is one of its greatest qualities along with the pretty enjoyable graphics. The story line gives a nice Butterfly Effect feeling as others would agree is pretty interesting. The user interface is a solid effort as well. Very easy to find your way around and such.

I would recommend this to all those looking for a relaxing game full of twists and turns. You can happily finish an episode in one go as it's entertaining enough to keep your attention.

reviewText: Episodes 1 - 4: Beautiful, in-depth and driven (even tho the teenage angst was annoying at times). Episode 5? A rushed, blurry, repeated mess with no point at all.\nMostly reviewed this because of my disappointment in Episode 5, what a frustrating letdown! What I loved about in the previous episodes; the ability to absorb and appreciate every nook and cranny of your surroundings, the interactions you have with other characters and objects, the mellow vibe and indie-folk music, all aspects were lacking in Polarized. I rushed through the episode just to get it over with (the puzzles were unnecessary and such a distraction from the agony and desperation I was supposed to be feeling), only to end up with an unsatisfactory conclusion to what could have been a beautiful and emotional story.

Life is Strange is the exact kind of game you really wouldn’t  want to be spoiled for you, because it could make it outright unplayable to some people. So I think you should just purchase it when you get the chance.

reviewText: Episodes 1 - 4: Beautiful, in-depth and driven (even tho the teenage angst was annoying at times). Episode 5? A rushed, blurry, repeated mess with no point at all.\nMostly reviewed this because of my disappointment in Episode 5, what a frustrating letdown! What I loved about in the previous episodes; the ability to absorb and appreciate every nook and cranny of your surroundings, the interactions you have with other characters and objects, the mellow vibe and indie-folk music, all aspects were lacking in Polarized. I rushed through the episode just to get it over with (the puzzles were unnecessary and such a distraction from the agony and desperation I was supposed to be feeling), only to end up with an unsatisfactory conclusion to what could have been a beautiful and emotional story.

reviewText:
Ep's 1-4 completed.

Woh.

First off, Chloe is total babe/10. 100% want to wife totes homo.

Was going to hold off playing this game till around Christmas, but I was bored on my day off, and didn't want to just play CSGO for 5 hours.

I try to take things that have MAJOR hype around them, with a grain of salt. That being said, this game lives up to the hype. My biggest issue is, like other story telling games with many choices, it encourages you to go back and play it again, taking a different path. With a game like The Walking Dead, I found that easy. Even with all the twists and turns, and knowing what was going to happen, I felt like I was able to grind through the game easier, see the endings, and walk away knowing everything about the game.

I don't see that being easy with this game.

While I don't think the story is AMAZING like many do, it's much more involving, much more gripping, and much, much, more interesting than The Walking Dead. When you're hit with a twist, you're hit. You feel it. I feel much more connected to these characters, than I did Lee and Clementine. I didn't feel sad at the end of The Walking Dead. It was sad, I knew it was sad, but I didn't feel sad. I do dislike how every character remembers tiny key things you did hours/days ago, like in The Walking Dead, and it effects their disposition towards you, forever.

When something major happens in Life Is Strange, I feel much more emotional about it, which is why I feel like playing through it again, will be much harder, and almost boring. It does offer many more outcomes than The Walking Dead, but that's almost an issue. On one hand it may feel like I'm playing a whole different story, but at the same time, the key events are still going to be mostly the same.

I felt the same way after STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl. It was such a good game, that playing it a second time, was boring. The fear of the unknown was replaced with knowing where early guns are, knowing who I could, and should fight, and who I should avoid for a while. Ignorance was replaced with experience, and it made it so I got about 5 hours into my second playthrough, before uninstalling the game.

All of this being said, the game is so far past worth playing, even if you only get one true playthrough. I've only predicted one key event early, and I wasn't even fully correct on it. You're left in the dark just long enough, that as soon as you think you're figuring things out, the game slaps you, forces you to take a step back, and rethink your last hour of playing.

reviewText: Having played some big-budget, ultra-hype titles this year it's simply great to play a game like Life is Strange. It not only has a suspenseful story, which reminded me of the classic Twin Peaks, it has just the right amount of interactive gameplay which similar games from Telltale lack in my opinion. But there's even more to it. The game may contain some stereotype characters and elements of your typical High-School-drama, but it presents them in an authentic way dispite the supernatural story. Life is Strange radiates a wholeheartedness and a down-to-earth mood which I enjoy very much. Max Caulfield's tale is presented in such a believable fashion and with so much attention to the little things which constitute human life, it's enchanting and enables a degree of identification rarely experienced in digital media (ok, The Witcher 3 managed that too). I'm not only looking forward to play future episodes, now I even want to pick up my camera and shot pictures right away. This is the gaming equivalent of contemporary tv-shows. Thank you Dontnod!

reviewText: If you're a fan of narrative driven adventure games with some sci-fi time travel thrown in, you will love LiS. The story will make you go through a roller coaster of emotions as it plays out in 5 episodes. Gameplay wise there's not much to it, and it does have it's flaws. The puzzles are pretty interesting when combined with a time travel mechanic, but they aren't too terribly hard. Sometimes you wish it would get out of the way so you can delve deeper into the engrossing story. It plays out like a choose your own adventure game a la The Walking Dead. The choices you make can change how other characters relate to you in the future, but in the grand scheme of things it is pretty inconsequential. There is a leaderboard that compares the choices you've made to others online which is interesting to look at. What LiS does have in spades is a deep and engaging story with superb writing and a cast of memorable characters that you will fall in love with (or hate). As far as this type of game goes it has to be easily one of the best games out there.

reviewText: Very few games have the power to tug at your emotions, or move you in a way beyond just enjoying a good fun game.  I won't be afraid to admit I've teared up at a good number of movies and books, but there has only been 2 games before now that have ever effected me in that way.  This is not only the 3rd one, but I still have tears as I write this, 34 year old man sobbing at his PC desk.  But you know what I don't care.   This game is completely about immersion, this game is completely about absorbing everything around you. Catching all the details, all the beautiful moments and there are lot of beautiful moments, haunting moments, distubing moments, joyous moments... Getting to know all the people and making you care about them, hate them or love them, some more than others.  Yes this story has a base foundation of teen drama and I like many I imagine do probably let out a few sighs at first..but do not let that stop you, please do not you'll be robbing yourself,  keep going you will not regret it.  This game has taken my emotions to all sorts of places in every which way possible. But in the end I would have to say this is has been one hell of a ride and I have some new favorite video game characters when others think of Link, Solid Snake, Master Chief or Lara Croft,  I will be thinking the likes of Chloe Price and Max Caulfield.  I commend you ‎Dontnod Entertainment you made yourself a fan.

reviewText: Life is Strange is the best episodic adventure game I have ever played and I have played just about all of them. Dontnod Entertainment, a small developer based in Paris France, has taken the episodic genre to new levels of excellence in story, character development, art style, music and soundtrack, so let me discuss those topics.\n\nStory: Life is Strange is about a girl age 18, Max Caulfield, who wants to study to become a professional photographer. She learns that a school in her hometown, Blackwell Academy, has hired one of her favorite professional photographers Mark Jefferson, and she decides she needs to move back to her hometown to enroll in his classes. That is the normal part about this story and nothing else in the story can be considered normal" in any way shape or form. Each new episode takes the story in a surprising direction that the player will be astounded by
date: and never able to predict which way the story will go. This is practically unheard of in game stories because most of them are so predictable and cliche by the time you get to the end of the game you know exactly what will happen. Life is Strange is 100% different in that category.\n\nCharacter development: The main characters in this game are so well done that you will form emotional bonds to them and if something happens to these characters you will feel it as though it is happening to you. Be prepared because you WILL NEED a box of tissues for your tears close by in LiS
recommended: and that is a guarantee. Nearly every single person I have conversed with on the Steam forum for LiS has admitted to shedding tears and lots of them
hoursPlayed: yes the characters and the story are that good rivaling even great best seller novels I have read
voteText: and I have read thousands of novels.\n\nArt style: The art style in Life is Strange is not photorealistic like many games now days attempt to achieve instead it is very stylish in the way the Dontnod team has done it and it is perfect for a game like this. Along with the amazing camera work in LiS I think it deserves awards in all three categories I have mentioned so far. All the art in the game is hand drawn and hand painted and it really does show in the finished product
helpfulPercent: in fact I have a folder on my PC with about 400 screenshots from LiS that I run on a 5 minute timer for my desktop background. I finished playing LiS back in October of 2015 when the final episode released and I STILL have that folder running as my desktop background the art is amazing!\n\nMusic/soundtrack: The music in Life is Strange is modern day artists and one of them Syd Matters
votesHelpful: the Dontnod team worked closely with the lead person in that band Jonathan Morali and he adapted some of their songs specifically for LiS. Because they use current artists is adds yet another level of realism to the game because you are hearing songs that young adults age 16 to 25 would be listening to in their every day lives. The music selection also really sets the mood for the game and again it deserves an award for the excellence and quality.\n\nAbout the only thing I would mention as a "con" to Life is Strange is that the lip sync quality is not very good. However in interviews with the Dontnod team they said they spent the games budget in areas they felt would better serve to make the game a work of quality and the story
votesTotal: characters
votesFunny: art style
commentsCount: and soundtrack are so good that you will hardly notice the poor lip sync

reviewText:
Life is Strange.

I believe all of us can relate to this statement in one way or another.
No spoilers in this review.

+ Now, this just happens to a fantastic game. A really, really, fantastic game.
One that once played, is very difficult to unassociate yourself with, forget and the like.
I would even go as far to say, the best choice and consequence game, I have ever played.

+ The moment you step into the life of our young protagonist Max, you should expect to find yourself there for all five episodes, and to find yourself reeling after the reveal.

+ Some seriously deep, thought-inspiring, heart wrenching moments, better described as being 'in abundance,' keep the story-driven experience brightly focused on your subjects.

+ Character depiction is wonderful; detailed, easily relatable, enjoyable unique - I can assure you that you will come to care deeply for all involved, and get your heart broken.

You WILL be tested over your sense of self-worth, WILL doubt your own decisions, WILL probably cry; as they say, 'with great power, comes great responsibility.'


A total of five episodic chapters have been released, each with their own definition of awesome, and all combined, lead to a tense climax. I really hope for more games of a similar format to be released by this developer.
Sincere thought has been put into the making of this one.

I recommend taking your time, and paying specific attention to detail. There are so many hidden gems that even the most discerning player may miss.

I do not recommend reading the store page description - just plunge in head first! Sometimes it is better to view the darkness without a candle.

Life is Strange remains to be my favourite find of 2015.
Highly, highly recommended to all, there is very little text involved aside from choice-making, so reading should not be too much of an issue.

Especially recommended to those who enjoy story-driven play, intricate scene details and discovering their meaning, metaphorical narrative, and intense periods of emotion; but as previously mentioned, no matter your preferred genre of game, I highly recommend obtaining this one.

Worth every penny, but purchasing is simple.
The real difficulty, is letting go.
